unitSample.question: This is a sample question for General Orders Unit Sample. What is X?
options: X
Y
Z

unit1.question: What is the purpose of the Denton Police Department's General Order on Law Enforcement Authority?
unit1.answer: To affirm the authority of members to perform their functions based on established legal authority.
options: To expand the authority of members beyond established legal limits.
To detail tactical procedures for high-risk situations.
To outline the department's community policing philosophy.
To affirm the authority of members to perform their functions based on established legal authority.
unit1.reference: GO 100.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The purpose of this order is to affirm the authority of the members of the Denton Police Department to perform their functions based on established legal authority.

unit1.question: According to the department's policy, how should officers exercise their power to make arrests?
unit1.answer: Officers are encouraged to use sound discretion in the enforcement of the law.
options: Officers must make an arrest for every observed violation.
Officers are encouraged to use sound discretion in the enforcement of the law.
Officers should avoid making arrests to maintain community relations.
Officers only have the authority to issue citations, not make arrests.
unit1.reference: GO 100.2 POLICY: While this department recognizes the power of peace officers to make arrests and take other enforcement action, officers are encouraged to use sound discretion in the enforcement of the law.

unit1.question: What is the Denton Police Department's stance on the abuse of law enforcement authority?
unit1.answer: The department does not tolerate abuse of law enforcement authority.
options: It is permitted in exigent circumstances.
It is left to the discretion of the individual officer.
The department does not tolerate abuse of law enforcement authority.
It is allowed with supervisory approval.
unit1.reference: GO 100.2 POLICY: This department does not tolerate abuse of law enforcement authority.

unit1.question: Under which Texas code are sworn members of the Denton Police Department considered peace officers?
unit1.answer: Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 2.12 and Tex. Occ. Code § 1701.001 et seq.
options: Texas Penal Code § 19.02
Texas Transportation Code § 545.01
Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 2.12 and Tex. Occ. Code § 1701.001 et seq.
Texas Local Government Code § 143.001
unit1.reference: GO 100.3 PEACE OFFICER POWERS: Sworn members of this department shall be considered peace officers pursuant to Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 2.12 and Tex. Occ. Code § 1701.001 et seq.

unit1.question: What is the geographical extent of a Denton peace officer's authority?
unit1.answer: The authority extends to any place in the State of Texas.
options: Only within the city limits of Denton.
Only within Denton County.
The authority extends to any place in the State of Texas.
The authority extends to Texas and its contiguous states.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3 PEACE OFFICER POWERS: The authority of any such peace officer extends to any place in the State of Texas and assigns the duty to every peace officer to preserve the peace within the State of Texas and their jurisdiction through all lawful means.

unit1.question: When can a Denton police officer make a warrantless arrest for an offense committed in their presence or view?
unit1.answer: At any time for any offense.
options: Only for felony offenses.
Only during daytime hours.
Only with a supervisor's approval.
At any time for any offense.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(b): Without a warrant for any offense committed in an officer's presence or within their view (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 14.01).

unit1.question: When can a Denton officer make a warrantless arrest based on a magistrate's order?
unit1.answer: For a felony or breach-of-the-peace offense observed by the magistrate.
options: For any offense, as long as the magistrate orders it.
Only for traffic violations observed by the magistrate.
For a felony or breach-of-the-peace offense observed by the magistrate.
An officer cannot make a warrantless arrest based on a magistrate's order.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(c): Without a warrant when ordered by a magistrate to make an arrest for a felony or breach-of-the-peace offense observed by the magistrate (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 14.02).

unit1.question: According to policy, an officer may arrest without a warrant if they find a person in a suspicious place who has committed an offense under Tex. Penal Code § 49.02. What is this offense?
unit1.answer: Public intoxication.
options: Disorderly conduct.
Public intoxication.
Assault.
Theft.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(d)(a): Finds a person in a suspicious place and under circumstances that reasonably show that the person has committed a felony, a breach of the peace, an offense under Tex. Penal Code § 49.02 (public intoxication)...

unit1.question: An officer may make a warrantless arrest for an assault resulting in bodily injury if they have probable cause and what other belief?
unit1.answer: That further injury may occur if an arrest is not made.
options: The victim requests the arrest.
The suspect has a prior history of violence.
That further injury may occur if an arrest is not made.
The assault occurred in a public place.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(d)(b): Has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an assault resulting in bodily injury to another and that further injury may occur if an arrest is not made.

unit1.question: An officer may arrest without a warrant for a violation of a protective order under Tex. Penal Code § 25.07 under what circumstances?
unit1.answer: Regardless of whether the offense occurs within the presence of the officer.
options: Only if the offense occurs in the officer's presence.
Only if the victim signs a complaint.
Regardless of whether the offense occurs within the presence of the officer.
Only if a supervisor is present to approve the arrest.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(c): Has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense under Tex. Penal Code § 25.07 (violation of certain court orders or conditions of bond in a family violence, sexual assault or abuse, indecent assault, stalking or trafficking case), regardless of whether the offense occurs within the presence of the officer.

unit1.question: When can an officer make a warrantless arrest for an offense involving family violence?
unit1.answer: When the officer has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense involving family violence.
options: Only if there are visible injuries on the victim.
Only if the victim wishes to press charges.
When the officer has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense involving family violence.
Only if the incident occurs in a private residence.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(d): Has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense involving family violence.

unit1.question: An officer can make a warrantless arrest if they have probable cause to believe a person has interfered with another's ability to do what, even if not in the officer's presence?
unit1.answer: Place an emergency call.
options: Leave the premises.
Speak to a lawyer.
Place an emergency call.
Sign a written statement.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(e): Has probable cause to believe that a person has prevented or interfered with another individual's ability to place an emergency call, even if the offense is committed outside the presence of the officer.

unit1.question: A warrantless arrest may be made when information is provided by a credible person that a felony has been committed and what other condition exists?
unit1.answer: The offender is about to escape.
options: The offender is about to escape.
The felony resulted in property damage.
The credible person is a law enforcement officer.
The felony occurred within the last hour.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(f): Without a warrant when the officer is provided information, by a credible person, that a felony has been committed and that the offender is about to escape (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 14.04).

unit1.question: Under what authority can a Denton police officer make a warrantless arrest for an observed 'Rules of the Road' traffic offense?
unit1.answer: Subtitle C, Texas Transportation Code.
options: The Denton City Charter.
The Texas Penal Code.
Subtitle C, Texas Transportation Code.
The U.S. Constitution.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.1(g): Without a warrant when the officer observes a person committing a traffic offense under Subtitle C, Texas Transportation Code (Rules of the Road offenses) (Tex. Transp. Code § 543.001).

unit1.question: What is required of an officer after making a warrantless arrest outside their primary jurisdiction but within Texas?
unit1.answer: Notify the agency having jurisdiction where the arrest was made as soon as practicable.
options: Immediately transport the suspect to the Denton city jail.
Notify the agency having jurisdiction where the arrest was made as soon as practicable.
Request a supervisor from Denton PD to respond to the scene.
Complete the arrest report before leaving the other jurisdiction.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.2: An officer making an arrest under this subsection shall, as soon as practicable after making the arrest, notify the agency having jurisdiction where the arrest was made (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 14.03).

unit1.question: A Denton officer may enter which of the following states in fresh pursuit of a felony subject?
unit1.answer: Louisiana, New Mexico, or Oklahoma.
options: Arkansas, Colorado, or Kansas.
Louisiana, New Mexico, or Oklahoma.
Arizona, Nevada, or Utah.
Mississippi, Alabama, or Georgia.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3(b): When an officer enters Louisiana, New Mexico or Oklahoma in fresh pursuit of a felony subject (La. Code Crim. P. art. 231 (Louisiana); 22 O.S. § 221 (Oklahoma); NMSA § 31-2-1 (New Mexico)).

unit1.question: After making an arrest in another state, what is the officer's responsibility concerning the arrested person?
unit1.answer: To take appropriate action to see that the person is taken to a magistrate or judge in the county where the arrest was made.
options: To immediately transport the person back to Denton for booking.
To release the person after notifying the local authorities.
To hold the person until a Denton supervisor arrives.
To take appropriate action to see that the person is taken to a magistrate or judge in the county where the arrest was made.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3: Whenever an officer makes an arrest in another state, the officer shall take appropriate action to see that the person is taken to a magistrate or judge in the county where the arrest was made as soon as practicable...

unit1.question: All Denton Police Department members must observe and comply with every person's clearly established rights under which constitutions?
unit1.answer: The United States and Texas Constitutions.
options: The Texas Constitution only.
The United States Constitution only.
The United States and Texas Constitutions.
The Denton City Charter only.
unit1.reference: GO 100.4 CONSTITUTIONAL REQUIREMENTS: All members shall observe and comply with every person's clearly established rights under the United States and Texas Constitutions.

unit1.question: What is the purpose of General Order 101 regarding the Chief Executive Officer?
unit1.answer: To provide guidelines for the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer.
options: To outline the Chief's daily duties.
To set the Chief's salary.
To provide guidelines for the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer.
To list the requirements for all executive staff.
unit1.reference: GO 101.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This order provides guidelines for the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer of the Denton Police Department, who is required to exercise the powers and duties of the office as prescribed by state law.

unit1.question: At the time of appointment, what is the minimum years of experience required for the chief executive officer?
unit1.answer: A minimum of 5 years' experience as a law enforcement officer.
options: A minimum of 2 years' experience.
A minimum of 10 years' experience.
A minimum of 3 years' experience.
A minimum of 5 years' experience as a law enforcement officer.
unit1.reference: GO 101.3 CHIEF OF POLICE REQUIREMENTS: In addition, at the time of appointment, the chief executive officer must have a minimum of 5 years' experience as a law enforcement officer...

unit1.question: A newly appointed Chief of Police must be eligible for what level of TCOLE certificate?
unit1.answer: An intermediate TCOLE certificate or its equivalent.
options: A basic TCOLE certificate.
A master TCOLE certificate.
An instructor TCOLE certificate.
An intermediate TCOLE certificate or its equivalent.
unit1.reference: GO 101.3 CHIEF OF POLICE REQUIREMENTS: ...and be eligible for an intermediate TCOLE certificate or its equivalent as determined by TCOLE (Tex. Local Gov't Code § 143.013).

unit1.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding the Oath of Office?
unit1.answer: That department members affirm the oath as an expression of commitment to constitutional rights and dedication to duties.
options: That only sworn officers are required to take an oath.
That the oath is a formality with no legal standing.
That department members affirm the oath as an expression of commitment to constitutional rights and dedication to duties.
That the oath can be modified by any supervisor.
unit1.reference: GO 102.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department that, when appropriate, department members affirm the oath of their office as an expression of commitment to the constitutional rights of those served by the Department and the dedication of its members to their duties.

unit1.question: In the Oath of Office, what documents must a member swear to preserve, protect, and defend in addition to the US and Texas Constitutions?
unit1.answer: The Charter and ordinances of this City.
options: The Department's General Orders.
The Law Enforcement Code of Ethics.
The Charter and ordinances of this City.
The directives of the City Manager.
unit1.reference: GO 102.3 OATH OF OFFICE: ...preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States, of Texas, and the Charter and ordinances of this City...

unit1.question: What phrase may be omitted from the Oath of Office if a member is opposed to it?
unit1.answer: "so help me God"
options: "I, (state name), do solemnly swear or affirm"
"faithfully execute the duties"
"to the best of my ability"
"so help me God"
unit1.reference: GO 102.3 OATH OF OFFICE: If a member is opposed, the words "so help me God" may be omitted.

unit1.question: What are the two official names for the manual containing the Denton Police Department's policies, procedures, and rules?
unit1.answer: The General Orders or the manual.
options: The Officer's Handbook or the Blue Book.
The General Orders or the manual.
The Code of Conduct or the Standard Procedures.
The Denton Police Rulebook or the Guideline.
unit1.reference: GO 103.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The manual of the Denton Police Department is hereby established and shall be referred to as the General Orders or the manual.

unit1.question: How are the provisions of the General Orders manual to be considered, unless expressly stated otherwise?
unit1.answer: As guidelines.
options: As strict, inflexible laws.
As optional suggestions.
As guidelines.
As a temporary set of rules.
unit1.reference: GO 103.2 POLICY: Except where otherwise expressly stated, the provisions of this manual shall be considered as guidelines.

unit1.question: The disclaimer in the General Orders states that the provisions are NOT intended to create what?
unit1.answer: An employment contract nor any employment rights or entitlements.
options: An employment contract nor any employment rights or entitlements.
A basis for department discipline.
A higher standard of care for civil liability.
A set of rules for the public to follow.
unit1.reference: GO 103.2.1 DISCLAIMER: The provisions contained in the General Orders are not intended to create an employment contract nor any employment rights or entitlements.

unit1.question: Violations of provisions in the General Orders shall only form the basis for what actions?
unit1.answer: Administrative action, training or discipline.
options: Civil liability against the officer.
Criminal charges against the officer.
Administrative action, training or discipline.
A lawsuit against the City of Denton.
unit1.reference: GO 103.2.1 DISCLAIMER: Violations of any provision of any order contained within this manual shall only form the basis for administrative action, training or discipline.

unit1.question: Who holds the ultimate authority for the content and adoption of the General Orders manual?
unit1.answer: The Chief of Police.
options: The City Council.
The City Manager.
The Chief of Police.
The Accreditation and Compliance Unit.
unit1.reference: GO 103.3 AUTHORITY: The Chief of Police shall be considered the ultimate authority for the content and adoption of the provisions of this manual and shall ensure compliance with all applicable federal, state and local laws.

unit1.question: For the purposes of criminal charges under the Penal Code, how is an 'Adult' generally defined in the General Orders?
unit1.answer: Someone 17 and older.
options: Someone 16 and older.
Someone 18 and older.
Someone 21 and older.
Someone 17 and older.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Adult - Generally, for the purposes of criminal charges (Penal Code), an adult is someone 17 and older.

unit1.question: For purposes other than criminal charges, at what age is someone considered an adult according to the General Orders?
unit1.answer: 18 years old.
options: 17 years old.
18 years old.
19 years old.
20 years old.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Adult - ...Otherwise, someone is not considered an adult until 18 years old.

unit1.question: In the General Orders, what does the term 'May' indicate?
unit1.answer: A permissive, discretionary or conditional action.
options: A mandatory action.
A prohibited action.
A permissive, discretionary or conditional action.
A suggested, but not required, action.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: May - Indicates a permissive, discretionary or conditional action.

unit1.question: Which term in the General Orders indicates a mandatory action?
unit1.answer: Shall or will.
options: May.
Should.
Could.
Shall or will.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Shall or will - Indicates a mandatory action.

unit1.question: What does the term 'Should' imply in the General Orders?
unit1.answer: A generally required or expected action, absent a rational basis for failing to conform.
options: An optional action.
A strictly mandatory action.
A prohibited action.
A generally required or expected action, absent a rational basis for failing to conform.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Should - Indicates a generally required or expected action, absent a rational basis for failing to conform.

unit1.question: How many days after publication do General Orders become effective?
unit1.answer: 30 days.
options: 15 days.
30 days.
45 days.
Immediately upon publication.
unit1.reference: GO 103.5 ISSUING THE GENERAL ORDERS: General orders shall be effective 30 days after publication.

unit1.question: Within how many days of being published must each member acknowledge they have had access to new general orders?
unit1.answer: Within 30 days.
options: Within 7 days.
Within 14 days.
Within 30 days.
Within 60 days.
unit1.reference: GO 103.5 ISSUING THE GENERAL ORDERS: Each member shall acknowledge that they have been provided access to and have had the opportunity to review the general orders and Departmental Directives within 30 days of being published.

unit1.question: Who is responsible for ensuring the General Orders are periodically reviewed and updated?
unit1.answer: The Chief of Police.
options: The City Manager.
The Accreditation and Compliance Unit.
The Chief of Police.
The Professional Standards Division.
unit1.reference: GO 103.6 PERIODIC REVIEW OF THE GENERAL ORDERS: The Chief of Police will ensure that the General Orders are periodically reviewed and updated as necessary.

unit1.question: When are revisions to the General Orders provided to each member?
unit1.answer: On or before the date the order becomes effective.
options: Within 30 days after the effective date.
During the member's annual performance review.
On or before the date the order becomes effective.
Upon the member's request.
unit1.reference: GO 103.7 REVISIONS TO ORDERS: All revisions to the General Orders will be provided to each member on or before the date the order becomes effective.

unit1.question: Where should a department member forward written suggestions for revising the General Orders?
unit1.answer: To the Accreditation and Compliance Unit.
options: Directly to the Chief of Police.
To their immediate supervisor.
To the Training Division.
To the Accreditation and Compliance Unit.
unit1.reference: GO page 20: All department members suggesting revision of the contents of the General Orders shall forward their written suggestions to the Accreditation and Compliance Unit, who will consider the recommendations and forward them to the executive staff as appropriate.

unit1.question: According to the Law Enforcement Code of Ethics, what is the fundamental duty of a law enforcement officer?
unit1.answer: To serve the community.
options: To enforce all laws without exception.
To serve the community.
To obey all supervisory orders.
To protect department property.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: As a law enforcement officer, my fundamental duty is to serve the community; to safeguard lives and property; to protect the innocent against deception, the weak against oppression or intimidation and the peaceful against abuse or disorder; and to respect the constitutional rights of all to liberty, equality and justice.

unit1.question: In the Code of Ethics, confidential information can only be revealed under what circumstance?
unit1.answer: When revelation is necessary in the performance of duty.
options: When requested by the media.
When discussing the case with family.
When revelation is necessary in the performance of duty.
It can never be revealed.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: Whatever I see or hear of a confidential nature or that is confided to me in my official capacity will be kept ever secret unless revelation is necessary in the performance of my duty.

unit1.question: What does the Law Enforcement Code of Ethics say about personal feelings and decisions?
unit1.answer: I will never act officiously or permit personal feelings, prejudices, political beliefs, aspirations, animosities or friendships to influence my decisions.
options: Personal feelings should guide all decisions for community-oriented policing.
I will never act officiously or permit personal feelings, prejudices, political beliefs, aspirations, animosities or friendships to influence my decisions.
Friendships with community members are encouraged to influence decisions positively.
Political beliefs are a primary factor in law enforcement decisions.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I will never act officiously or permit personal feelings, prejudices, political beliefs, aspirations, animosities or friendships to influence my decisions.

unit1.question: The Law Enforcement Code of Ethics states an officer will never employ unnecessary force or abuse and never accept what?
unit1.answer: Gratuities.
options: Overtime pay.
Commendations.
Gratuities.
Public praise.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: With no compromise for crime and with relentless prosecution of criminals, I will enforce the law courteously and appropriately without fear or favor, malice or ill will, never employing unnecessary force or abuse and never accepting gratuities.

unit1.question: What does the badge of office symbolize according to the Law Enforcement Code of Ethics?
unit1.answer: A symbol of public faith.
options: A symbol of absolute authority.
A symbol of personal achievement.
A symbol of public faith.
A symbol of the state's power.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I recognize the badge of my office as a symbol of public faith, and I accept it as a public trust to be held so long as I am true to the ethics of police service.

unit1.question: What commitment do officers make regarding acts of corruption or bribery according to the Code of Ethics?
unit1.answer: I will never engage in acts of corruption or bribery, nor will I condone such acts by other police officers.
options: I will report acts of bribery only if they involve large sums of money.
I will never engage in acts of corruption or bribery, nor will I condone such acts by other police officers.
I will overlook small acts of corruption to maintain team morale.
Engaging in acts of bribery is permissible with a supervisor's approval.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I will never engage in acts of corruption or bribery, nor will I condone such acts by other police officers. I will cooperate with all legally authorized agencies and their representatives in the pursuit of justice.

unit1.question: According to the Code of Ethics, who is solely responsible for an officer's standard of professional performance?
unit1.answer: The officer alone.
options: The Chief of Police.
The officer's direct supervisor.
The Training Division.
The officer alone.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I know that I alone am responsible for my own standard of professional performance and will take every reasonable opportunity to enhance and improve my level of knowledge and competence.

unit1.question: The definition of 'Probable Cause' to arrest is based on reasonably trustworthy information sufficient to warrant a reasonable person to believe what?
unit1.answer: That a particular person has committed or is committing an offense.
options: That a crime has been committed, but not by a particular person.
That a particular person might commit an offense in the future.
That a particular person has committed or is committing an offense.
That a particular person has been accused of a crime by an anonymous source.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Probable cause - Exists to arrest where the police have reasonably trustworthy information, considered as a whole, sufficient to warrant a reasonable person to believe a particular person has committed or is committing an offense.

unit1.question: What is 'Reasonable Suspicion' defined as in the General Orders?
unit1.answer: Specific, articulable facts that would lead an officer to reasonably conclude a person is, has been, or soon will be engaged in criminal activity.
options: A vague feeling or hunch about a person.
The same standard as probable cause.
Specific, articulable facts that would lead an officer to reasonably conclude a person is, has been, or soon will be engaged in criminal activity.
Information from an uncorroborated anonymous tip.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Reasonable suspicion - Specific, articulable facts that, combined with rational inferences from those facts, would lead the officer to reasonably conclude that the person detained is, has been, or soon will be engaged in criminal activity.

unit1.question: Which of the following is NOT included in the definition of a 'Member' of the Denton Police Department?
unit1.answer: Elected City Officials.
options: Full- and part-time employees.
Volunteers.
Reserve, auxiliary officers.
Elected City Officials.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Member - Any person employed or appointed by the Denton Police Department, including: Full- and part-time employees, Sworn peace officers, Reserve, auxiliary officers, Non-sworn employees, Volunteers.

unit1.question: Who is defined as an 'Officer' in the General Orders?
unit1.answer: Those employees, regardless of rank, who are sworn peace officer employees of the Denton Police Department.
options: Only employees with the rank of Sergeant or above.
All employees of the Denton Police Department, including civilians.
Those employees, regardless of rank, who are sworn peace officer employees of the Denton Police Department.
Only patrol division employees.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: Officer - Those employees, regardless of rank, who are sworn peace officer employees of the Denton Police Department.

unit1.question: What is the policy regarding department members conforming to the provisions of the General Orders manual?
unit1.answer: All members are to conform to the provisions of this manual.
options: Only sworn officers must conform.
Conformance is optional.
Only supervisors must conform.
All members are to conform to the provisions of this manual.
unit1.reference: GO 103.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The manual is a statement of the current policies, procedures, rules and guidelines of this department. All members are to conform to the provisions of this manual.

unit1.question: Who is authorized to issue Departmental Directives that modify provisions of the General Orders manual?
unit1.answer: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
options: Any supervisor.
The City Council.
The Training Division.
The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
unit1.reference: GO 103.3 AUTHORITY: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee is authorized to issue Departmental Directives, which shall modify those provisions of the manual to which they pertain.

unit1.question: How long will Departmental Directives remain in effect?
unit1.answer: Until they may be permanently incorporated into the manual.
options: For 30 days only.
Until the end of the fiscal year.
Until they may be permanently incorporated into the manual.
For a maximum of one year.
unit1.reference: GO 103.3 AUTHORITY: Departmental Directives shall remain in effect until they may be permanently incorporated into the manual.

unit1.question: In the Law Enforcement Code of Ethics, an officer commits to keeping their private life in what condition?
unit1.answer: Unsullied as an example to all.
options: Completely separate from their professional life.
Unsullied as an example to all.
Known only to their immediate family.
Shared openly on social media.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I will keep my private life unsullied as an example to all and will behave in a manner that does not bring discredit to me or to my agency.

unit1.question: What characteristics should a law enforcement officer maintain in the face of danger, scorn, or ridicule?
unit1.answer: Courageous calm and self-restraint.
options: Aggression and intimidation.
Courageous calm and self-restraint.
Humor and detachment.
Silence and observation.
unit1.reference: GO 104.1: I will maintain courageous calm in the face of danger, scorn or ridicule; develop self-restraint; and be constantly mindful of the welfare of others.

unit1.question: What is the policy regarding an officer's authority to make arrests outside their jurisdiction but within Texas?
unit1.answer: An officer may make a warrantless arrest for any offense committed in their presence or view, except for most traffic offenses.
options: An officer has no arrest authority outside their jurisdiction.
An officer may only arrest for felonies outside their jurisdiction.
An officer may make a warrantless arrest for any offense committed in their presence or view, except for most traffic offenses.
An officer must have a warrant to make any arrest outside their jurisdiction.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.2(a): Without a warrant for any offense committed within the presence or view of the officer except traffic offenses.

unit1.question: A warrantless arrest for a traffic offense under Subtitle C, Title 7 is permitted outside the officer's jurisdiction under what condition?
unit1.answer: The offense is committed in the same county or counties where the Denton Police Department is located.
options: The offense is a felony.
The driver is from out of state.
The offense is committed in the same county or counties where the Denton Police Department is located.
The officer has supervisory approval.
unit1.reference: GO 100.3.2(a): Officers may make a warrantless arrest for a traffic offense under Subtitle C, Title 7, Texas Transportation Code if the offense is committed in the same county or counties where the Denton Police Department is located.

unit1.question: What does TCOLE stand for?
unit1.answer: The Texas Commission on Law Enforcement.
options: The Texas Coalition of Law Enforcement.
The Training Commission on Law Enforcement.
The Texas Commission on Law Enforcement.
The Texas Council of Law Enforcement.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: TCOLE - The Texas Commission on Law Enforcement.

unit1.question: What does TCIC stand for?
unit1.answer: Texas Crime Information Center.
options: Texas Criminal Investigation Center.
Texas Crime Information Center.
Tactical Crime Information Center.
Texas Crime Investigation Command.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: TCIC - Texas Crime Information Center.

unit1.question: What does TLETS stand for?
unit1.answer: Texas Law Enforcement Telecommunications System.
options: Texas Law Enforcement Training System.
Texas Law Enforcement Telecommunications System.
Texas Legal Enforcement Telemetry System.
Tactical Law Enforcement Team Services.
unit1.reference: GO 103.4 DEFINITIONS: TLETS - Texas Law Enforcement Telecommunications System.

unit1.question: What must all prior and existing manuals, orders, and regulations do to remain in effect?
unit1.answer: They must not conflict with the provisions of the current General Orders manual.
options: They are automatically rescinded.
They take precedence over the new manual.
They must be reviewed and re-approved annually.
They must not conflict with the provisions of the current General Orders manual.

options: The EOC is commanded by a Lieutenant while the DOC is commanded by the Chief.
A DOC handles internal department tactical operations while an EOC handles inter-agency strategic coordination.

unit3.question: What is the stated philosophy of the Denton Police Department regarding the sanctity of human life in relation to resistance?
unit3.answer: The sanctity of human life is the foundation by which DPD serves the community.
options: The sanctity of human life is secondary to officer safety.
The sanctity of human life is considered only in non-violent encounters.
The sanctity of human life is the foundation by which DPD serves the community.
The sanctity of human life is a goal, but not a guiding philosophy.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.1 PHILOSOPHY: The sanctity of human life is the foundation by which DPD serves the community. The response to resistance by law enforcement personnel is a matter of critical concern both to the public and to the law enforcement community.

unit3.question: Which of the following defines 'Active aggression'?
unit3.answer: A physical act or verbal statement threatening assault, coupled with the immediate ability to carry out the threat.
options: Refusing to comply with a lawful order without any physical action.
Tensing muscles to prevent an officer's control.
A physical act or verbal statement threatening assault, coupled with the immediate ability to carry out the threat.
Any application of force other than lethal force.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.2 DEFINITIONS: Active aggression - A physical act threatening assault or a verbal statement threatening assault, coupled with the immediate ability to carry out the threat or assault that would cause a reasonable person to believe bodily injury is imminent to any person.

unit3.question: What is the definition of 'Defensive resistance'?
unit3.answer: Physical actions that attempt to prevent the officer's control, but make no directed attempt to harm the officer.
options: A refusal to comply with a lawful order.
A verbal statement threatening assault.
Physical actions that attempt to prevent the officer's control, but make no directed attempt to harm the officer.
A physical act that threatens assault with an immediate ability to carry it out.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.2 DEFINITIONS: Defensive resistance - Physical actions that attempt to prevent the officer's control, but make no directed attempt to harm the officer. At this level of resistance, the subject tenses their muscles or attempts to push or pull away in a manner that does not allow the officer to establish control.

unit3.question: How is 'Lethal force' defined in the general orders?
unit3.answer: Force reasonably anticipated and intended to create a substantial likelihood of causing death or serious bodily injury.
options: Any use of force that results in any injury.
Force reasonably anticipated and intended to create a substantial likelihood of causing death or serious bodily injury.
Any discharge of a firearm.
The use of a neck restraint.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.2 DEFINITIONS: Lethal force - Force reasonably anticipated and intended to create a substantial likelihood of causing death or serious bodily injury. (Tex. Penal Code § 9.01(3))

unit3.question: What does the term 'Imminent' mean in the context of a threat?
unit3.answer: Ready to take place; impending, but not necessarily immediate or instantaneous.
options: Occurring within the next 24 hours.
Happening at this very moment.
Ready to take place; impending, but not necessarily immediate or instantaneous.
A threat that is only verbal.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.2 DEFINITIONS: Imminent - Ready to take place; impending. Note that imminent does not mean immediate or instantaneous.

unit3.question: The standard for determining the necessity and level of force is viewed from what perspective?
unit3.answer: The perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, without the benefit of 20/20 hindsight.
options: The perspective of the media and public opinion.
The perspective of a legal expert reviewing the case later.
The perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, without the benefit of 20/20 hindsight.
The perspective of the suspect involved in the incident.
unit3.reference: GO 300.2 POLICY: The standard in determining the necessity for force and the appropriate level of force will be viewed from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, without the benefit of 20/20 hindsight, and within the limitations of the totality of the circumstances presented at the time of the incident...

unit3.question: What is the duty of any officer or employee who is present and observes another member using unreasonable force?
unit3.answer: When in a position to do so, intervene to prevent the use of unreasonable force.
options: To report the incident only if asked by a supervisor.
To wait until the situation is over and then report it.
When in a position to do so, intervene to prevent the use of unreasonable force.
To record the incident on their phone for evidence.
unit3.reference: GO 300.2.1 DUTY TO INTERVENE AND REPORT: Any officer or employee present and observing another law enforcement officer or a member using force that is clearly beyond that which is objectively reasonable under the circumstances shall, when in a position to do so, intervene to prevent the use of unreasonable force.

unit3.question: What must a non-sworn employee do if they witness a use of force that is clearly beyond what is objectively reasonable?
unit3.answer: Submit a written report to the appropriate supervisor as soon as practicable.
options: Intervene physically to stop the force.
Ignore the incident as they are not a sworn officer.
Discuss the incident with coworkers to get their opinion.
Submit a written report to the appropriate supervisor as soon as practicable.
unit3.reference: GO 300.2.4 ADDITIONAL ACCREDITATION REQUIREMENTS FOR INTERVENING AND REPORTING: In all cases, the non-sworn employee shall submit a written report to the appropriate supervisor as soon as practicable.

unit3.question: What is the preferred, tactically sound approach in many critical incidents?
unit3.answer: De-escalation.
options: Immediate use of force.
De-escalation.
Waiting for a supervisor to arrive.
Establishing a perimeter and waiting.
unit3.reference: GO 300.3 DE-ESCALATION OF POTENTIAL FORCE ENCOUNTERS: De-escalation is the preferred, tactically sound approach in many critical incidents.

unit3.question: When assessing risks and benefits of de-escalation, which factor should an officer consider?
unit3.answer: Whether the situation requires a supervisor's response.
options: The time of day.
The nearest backup unit's location.
The weather conditions.
Whether the situation requires a supervisor's response.

unit3.question: Which of the following is considered a de-escalation technique?

Using a loud, commanding voice.
Tactical repositioning (e.g. obtaining distance and cover).
Immediately handcuffing the subject.
unit3.reference: GO 300.3.1(a): Use of De-escalation Techniques - Employing de-escalation techniques may involve securing additional resources, tactical repositioning (e.g. obtaining distance and cover), and employing verbal persuasion.

unit3.question: An officer may NOT use a chemical irritant spray or CED on a student enrolled in the fifth grade or less, unless what condition is met?

The student is running away.
The student's parents have given consent.
The student poses a serious risk of harm to the student or another person.

The individual's political affiliation.
The individual's mental state or capacity.
The cost of the property damage involved.

unit3.question: The use of neck restraints is explicitly prohibited, with what single exception?

With supervisor approval.
Lethal force situations.
When controlling a large crowd.
unit3.reference: GO 300.5.4 NECK RESTRAINTS: Pressure to the neck of an individual is explicitly prohibited, with the exception of lethal force situations.

unit3.question: When is an officer justified in using deadly force to stop a fleeing subject?
unit3.answer: When the officer has probable cause to believe the individual has committed a felony involving serious bodily injury or death and poses an imminent risk to others.
options: For any fleeing felony suspect.
Any time a subject flees from a lawful arrest.
When the officer has probable cause to believe the individual has committed a felony involving serious bodily injury or death and poses an imminent risk to others.
To prevent the escape of any individual from custody.
unit3.reference: GO 300.6(b): An officer may use deadly force to stop a fleeing subject when the officer has probable cause to believe that the individual has committed, or intends to commit, a felony involving the infliction or threatened infliction of serious bodily injury or death, and the officer reasonably believes that there is an imminent risk of serious bodily injury or death to any other person if the individual is not immediately apprehended.

unit3.question: When should officers discharge a firearm at a moving vehicle or its occupants?
unit3.answer: Only when there are no other reasonable means available to avert the imminent threat of the vehicle.
options: To disable the vehicle's tires.
Any time a vehicle is used in a pursuit.
Only when there are no other reasonable means available to avert the imminent threat of the vehicle.
As a standard tactic to end all pursuits.

unit3.answer: When the application caused a visible injury.
options: Only if the subject is arrested.
When the application caused a visible injury.
Only if the incident is recorded.
At the end of the shift.

unit3.question: Medical assistance shall be obtained for any person who exhibits signs of physical distress, has a visible injury, or what other condition?

Has committed a felony.

Refuses to be handcuffed.

unit3.question: If a supervisor is unable to respond to the scene of a force application, what is their responsibility?
unit3.answer: They are still expected to complete as many of the required procedural items as circumstances permit.

They must delegate all tasks to the primary officer.
They are still expected to complete as many of the required procedural items as circumstances permit.
They must respond to the scene within one hour.
unit3.reference: GO 300.11: In the event that a supervisor is unable to respond to the scene of an incident involving the reported application of force, the supervisor is still expected to complete as many of the above items as circumstances permit.

unit3.question: What is the purpose of a Response to Resistance Review Board?
unit3.answer: To establish a process for the department to review the response to resistance by its members.
options: To determine criminal guilt or innocence.
To recommend specific disciplinary actions.
To establish a process for the department to review the response to resistance by its members.
To handle all citizen complaints.
unit3.reference: GO 301.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This order establishes a process for the Denton Police Department to review the response to resistance by its members.

unit3.question: Generally, when will a member be placed in a temporary administrative assignment?
unit3.answer: Whenever their actions or response to resistance results in death or serious bodily injury to another.
options: After any use of force.
After any vehicle pursuit.
Whenever their actions or response to resistance results in death or serious bodily injury to another.
Following any citizen complaint.
unit3.reference: GO 301.3 REMOVAL FROM LINE DUTY ASSIGNMENT: Generally, whenever a member's actions or response to resistance in an official capacity, or while using department equipment, results in death or serious bodily injury to another, that member will be placed in a temporary administrative assignment pending an administrative review.

Every vehicle pursuit.
Every response to resistance that is reported.
Every discharge of a firearm, excluding training or recreational use.
unit3.reference: GO 301.4 REVIEW BOARD: The Response to Resistance Review Board will also review the circumstances surrounding every discharge of a firearm, whether the member was on- or off-duty, excluding training or recreational use.

unit3.question: What is the scope of the Response to Resistance Review Board's power?

To conduct criminal investigations.

To subpoena civilian witnesses.

unit3.question: What is the policy on using restraint devices?
unit3.answer: They shall not be used to punish, to display authority, or as a show of force.
options: They can be used to ensure compliance with verbal commands.
They are mandatory for all arrests.
They shall not be used to punish, to display authority, or as a show of force.
They can only be used by supervisors.

unit3.answer: Safety permitting, handcuffing to the front to allow the person to sign or write notes.
options: Restraints should not be used on them.
Only leg restraints should be used.
Safety permitting, handcuffing to the front to allow the person to sign or write notes.
The presence of an interpreter is required before using restraints.
