unit3.question: When should leg restraints NOT be used on a pregnant person?
unit3.answer: They should not be used unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion the person may resist, attempt escape, injure themself or others, or damage property.
options: They can never be used on a pregnant person.
They should not be used unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion the person may resist, attempt escape, injure themself or others, or damage property.
They can be used in all circumstances.
Only if the person is in their third trimester.
unit3.reference: GO 302.3.2 RESTRAINT OF PREGNANT PERSONS: Leg restraints, waist chains, or handcuffs behind the body should not be used unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion that the person may resist, attempt escape, injure themself or others, or damage property.

unit3.question: In what situation should a juvenile under 14 years of age be restrained?
unit3.answer: When they are suspected of a dangerous felony or there is a reasonable suspicion they may resist, escape, or cause injury.
options: For any offense, to set an example.
They should never be restrained.
When they are suspected of a dangerous felony or there is a reasonable suspicion they may resist, escape, or cause injury.
Only if their parents are present.
unit3.reference: GO 302.3.3 RESTRAINT OF JUVENILES: A juvenile under 14 years of age should not be restrained unless they are suspected of a dangerous felony or when the officer has a reasonable suspicion that the juvenile may resist, attempt escape, injure themselves, injure the officer or damage property.

unit3.question: When are spit hoods generally used?
unit3.answer: During application of a physical restraint, while the person is restrained, or during or after transport.
options: As a primary means of control.
On any person who is verbally abusive.
During application of a physical restraint, while the person is restrained, or during or after transport.
Only in the booking area of the jail.
unit3.reference: GO 302.5 APPLICATION OF SPIT HOODS: They are generally used during application of a physical restraint, while the person is restrained, or during or after transport.

unit3.question: When applying leg restraints, who should be notified as soon as practicable after the application?
unit3.answer: A supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The on-duty dispatcher.
A supervisor.
No notification is required.
unit3.reference: GO 302.7.1(a): When applying leg restraints, the following guidelines should be followed: (a) If practicable, officers should notify a supervisor of the intent to apply the leg restraint device. In all cases, a supervisor shall be notified as soon as practicable after the application of the leg restraint device.

unit3.question: What is the policy for using control devices upon a subject?
unit3.answer: It shall only occur when the officer reasonably believes it necessary to gain control of the subject.
options: It is the first option in any encounter.
It is prohibited in all situations.
It shall only occur when the officer reasonably believes it necessary to gain control of the subject.
It can only be used with the Chief's permission.
unit3.reference: GO 303.2.1 PHILOSOPHY: The use of control devices upon a subject by an officer shall only occur when the officer, while in the performance of their lawful duties, reasonably believes it necessary to gain control of the subject.

unit3.question: Which of the following is NOT an approved control device?
unit3.answer: Personal, non-issued impact weapons.
options: Baton and/or impact weapons (long, short, or expandable).
Chemical agents.
Kinetic energy projectiles.
Personal, non-issued impact weapons.
unit3.reference: GO 303.3.2 APPROVED CONTROL DEVICES: Only department issued or approved control devices and munitions shall be carried. Only department approved modifications may be made to any control device. (a) The control devices approved by the department are: 1. Baton and/or impact weapons... 2. Chemical agents; 3. Kinetic energy projectiles...

unit3.question: What is a prohibited use of chemical agents?
unit3.answer: To torture, psychologically torment, elicit statements or inflict undue pain on any individual.
options: To disperse violent crowds or riots.
To subdue a subject who is displaying active aggression.
To torture, psychologically torment, elicit statements or inflict undue pain on any individual.
To repel physical attacks from humans or animals.
unit3.reference: GO 303.8.3 PROHIBITED USES: The following are prohibited uses of chemical agents: (a) To torture, psychologically torment, elicit statements or inflict undue pain on any individual;

unit3.question: What must uniformed patrol officers carry, at a minimum, in terms of control devices?
unit3.answer: Oleoresin Capsicum spray or CS Gel, and a CED.
options: Only a baton.
Only a CED.
Oleoresin Capsicum spray or CS Gel, and a CED.
Kinetic energy projectiles.
unit3.reference: GO 303.4 ISSUING, CARRYING AND USING CONTROL DEVICES: All uniformed patrol officers shall carry, at a minimum, Oleoresin Capsicum spray or CS Gel, and a -CED.

unit3.question: The appropriate use of a Conducted Energy Device (CED) may result in what positive outcome?
unit3.answer: Fewer serious injuries to officers and suspects.
options: Increased departmental revenue.
Fewer serious injuries to officers and suspects.
A reduction in paperwork.
Faster court proceedings.
unit3.reference: GO 304.2 POLICY: The appropriate use of such a device may result in fewer serious injuries to officers and suspects.

unit3.question: How should a CED be carried by a uniformed officer?
unit3.answer: In a holster on the side opposite the duty weapon.
options: In a pants pocket.
On the same side as the duty weapon.
In a holster on the side opposite the duty weapon.
In the glove compartment of the patrol car.
unit3.reference: GO 304.3 ISSUANCE AND CARRYING CEDS: Officers who carry the CED while in uniform shall carry it in a holster on the side opposite the duty weapon.

unit3.question: What should precede the application of a CED, unless it would endanger safety?
unit3.answer: A verbal warning of the intended use.
options: A physical strike.
The use of OC spray.
A verbal warning of the intended use.
A request for a supervisor.
unit3.reference: GO 304.4 VERBAL AND VISUAL WARNINGS: A verbal warning of the intended use of the CED should precede its application, unless it would otherwise endanger the safety of officers or when it is not practicable due to the circumstances.

unit3.question: Mere flight from a pursuing officer is not good cause for the use of a CED without what?
unit3.answer: Additional circumstances or factors.
options: The officer being tired.
The suspect running into a crowded area.
Additional circumstances or factors.
The pursuit lasting more than five minutes.
unit3.reference: GO 304.5.1 APPLICATION OF THE CED: Mere flight from a pursuing officer, without additional circumstances or factors, is not good cause for the use of the CED to apprehend an individual.

unit3.question: What is a preferred target area to avoid when using a CED?
unit3.answer: Head, neck, area of the heart, or genitals.
options: The back.
The upper legs.
The lower center mass.
Head, neck, area of the heart, or genitals.
unit3.reference: GO 304.5.4 TARGETING CONSIDERATIONS: ...when practicable, officers should attempt to target the back, lower center mass, and upper legs of the subject, and avoid intentionally targeting the head, neck, area of the heart, or genitals.

unit3.question: How should an expended CED cartridge be handled if the probes penetrated the subject's skin?
unit3.answer: Submitted into evidence with packaging marked 'Biohazard'.
options: It should be discarded in a regular trash can.
It should be returned to the manufacturer.
Submitted into evidence with packaging marked 'Biohazard'.
It should be kept by the officer for reuse.
unit3.reference: GO 304.5.6 ACTIONS FOLLOWING DEPLOYMENTS: The evidence packaging should be marked 'Biohazard' if the probes penetrated the subject's skin.

unit3.question: For how long must all CED deployment information be maintained by the department?
unit3.answer: For a minimum of three years.
options: One year.
Two years.
For a minimum of three years.
Five years.
unit3.reference: GO 304.10 DEPLOYMENT RECORD RETENTION: All CED deployment information shall be maintained by the department for a minimum of three years.

unit3.question: What defines a 'Patrol rifle'?
unit3.answer: Any magazine-fed repeating rifle with an optical sighting device of 5 power or less.
options: Any rifle carried by a patrol officer.
A rifle with an optical sight greater than 5 power.
Any magazine-fed repeating rifle with an optical sighting device of 5 power or less.
A bolt-action sniper rifle.
unit3.reference: GO 305.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Patrol rifle - Any magazine-fed repeating rifle with iron/open sights or with a frame mounted optical enhancing sighting device of 5 power or less that is carried by an officer in an official capacity.

unit3.question: What is a 'Preventable discharge'?
unit3.answer: An unintentional discharge that constitutes a gross deviation from department training.
options: Any discharge that occurs during training.
A discharge that results in no injury.
An unintentional discharge that constitutes a gross deviation from department training.
A discharge to euthanize an animal.
unit3.reference: GO 305.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Preventable discharge - An unintentional discharge that constitutes a gross deviation from department training received prior to the incident or a discharge which exhibits a failure to exercise the care that a reasonably prudent employee would have exercised in similar circumstances.

unit3.question: What is one of the general guidelines for deploying a patrol rifle?
unit3.answer: When a member reasonably believes that a suspect may be wearing body armor.
options: For any traffic stop.
When a suspect is verbally non-compliant.
When a member reasonably believes that a suspect may be wearing body armor.
To perform a building search for a misdemeanor suspect.
unit3.reference: GO 305.3.3(e): Examples of some general guidelines for deploying the patrol rifle may include, but are not limited to: ... (e) When a member reasonably believes that a suspect may be wearing body armor.

unit3.question: When an officer is armed, whether on or off-duty, what must they carry?
unit3.answer: Their badge and Denton Police Department identification card.
options: A copy of the General Orders manual.
Their badge and Denton Police Department identification card.
A concealed handgun license.
A business card.
unit3.reference: GO 305.3.4(a): When armed, whether off-duty or in plain clothes, officers shall carry their badges and Denton Police Department identification cards under circumstances requiring possession of such identification.

unit3.question: What is the policy regarding carrying firearms when an officer's ability is impaired by alcohol or drugs?
unit3.answer: Firearms shall not be carried.
options: It is left to the officer's discretion.
Firearms shall not be carried.
Only a backup weapon may be carried.
The firearm must be unloaded.
unit3.reference: GO 305.5.3 ALCOHOL AND DRUGS: Firearms shall not be carried by any member, either on- or off-duty, who has consumed an amount of an alcoholic beverage, taken any drugs or medication, or taken any combination thereof that would tend to adversely affect the member's senses or judgment.

unit3.question: What is a 'Blocking or vehicle intercept'?
unit3.answer: A slow-speed coordinated maneuver to contain and prevent a pursuit.
options: Using a vehicle to create a stationary roadblock.
Intentionally ramming a suspect vehicle.
A slow-speed coordinated maneuver to contain and prevent a pursuit.
Following a suspect vehicle at a safe distance.
unit3.reference: GO 306.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Blocking or vehicle intercept - A slow-speed coordinated maneuver where two or more pursuing vehicles simultaneously intercept and block the movement of a suspect vehicle... The goal is containment and preventing a pursuit.

unit3.question: What is the definition of a 'Vehicle pursuit'?
unit3.answer: An event where an officer attempts to apprehend a suspect who is using high-speed driving or other evasive tactics to avoid arrest.
options: Following any vehicle that fails to immediately pull over.
An event where an officer attempts to apprehend a suspect who is using high-speed driving or other evasive tactics to avoid arrest.
Any time an officer exceeds the speed limit.
A vehicle that fails to yield to an emergency vehicle.
unit3.reference: GO 306.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Vehicle pursuit - An event involving one or more law enforcement officers attempting to apprehend a suspect, who is attempting to avoid arrest while operating a vehicle by using high-speed driving or other evasive tactics...

unit3.question: When deciding to initiate or continue a pursuit, what is a primary factor to consider?
unit3.answer: The seriousness of the known or reasonably suspected crime and its relationship to community safety.
options: The time of day and traffic conditions.
The performance capabilities of the police vehicle.
The seriousness of the known or reasonably suspected crime and its relationship to community safety.
The officer's familiarity with the area.
unit3.reference: GO 306.3.1(a): Factors that shall be considered, both individually and collectively, when deciding to initiate or continue a pursuit include, but are not limited to: (a) The seriousness of the known or reasonably suspected crime and its relationship to community safety;

unit3.question: When should vehicle pursuits be terminated?
unit3.answer: Whenever the present risks of continuing reasonably appear to outweigh the risks from the suspect's escape.
options: After 10 minutes, regardless of the circumstances.
Only when the suspect vehicle is out of sight.
Whenever the present risks of continuing reasonably appear to outweigh the risks from the suspect's escape.
Only upon order from the Chief of Police.
unit3.reference: GO 306.3.2 WHEN TO TERMINATE A PURSUIT: Pursuits should be terminated whenever the totality of objective circumstances known or which reasonably ought to be known to the officer or supervisor during the pursuit indicates that the present risks of continuing the pursuit reasonably appear to outweigh the risks resulting from the suspect's escape.

unit3.question: Pursuits for what type of offenses are generally discouraged?
unit3.answer: Offenses not involving violence or weapons (except for DWI).
options: All felony offenses.
Offenses not involving violence or weapons (except for DWI).
Property crimes.
Any misdemeanor.
unit3.reference: GO 306.3.2(h): Pursuits of violators for offenses not involving violence or weapons (independent of the pursuit), except for Driving While Intoxicated, are generally discouraged.

unit3.question: What is the maximum number of police vehicles that should generally be involved in a pursuit?
unit3.answer: Three.
options: Two.
Three.
Four.
There is no limit.
unit3.reference: GO 306.4 PURSUIT VEHICLES: Vehicle pursuits should be limited to three police department emergency vehicles.

unit3.question: What is the primary consideration when determining whether to initiate or continue a foot pursuit?
unit3.answer: The safety of department members and the public.
options: The likelihood of catching the suspect.
The physical fitness of the officer.
The safety of department members and the public.
The time of day.
unit3.reference: GO 307.3 DECISION TO PURSUE: The safety of department members and the public should be the primary consideration when determining whether a foot pursuit should be initiated or continued.

unit3.question: What is one condition under which an officer should consider alternatives to continuing a foot pursuit?
unit3.answer: The officer loses radio contact with the communications dispatcher.
options: The suspect runs into a residential area.
The officer loses radio contact with the communications dispatcher.
The pursuit has lasted longer than two minutes.
The suspect is faster than the officer.
unit3.reference: GO 307.4(g): When reasonably practicable, officers should consider alternatives to engaging in or continuing a foot pursuit when: ... (g) The officer loses radio contact with the communications dispatcher or with assisting or backup officers.

unit3.question: What is a Code 3 response?
unit3.answer: Operation of a vehicle while the emergency lights and siren are activated.
options: A routine, non-emergency response.
A response with lights activated but no siren.
Operation of a vehicle while the emergency lights and siren are activated.
A response for administrative purposes only.
unit3.reference: GO 308.3.2 CODE 3 (EMERGENCY CALLS): Code 3 is used to describe the operation of a vehicle while the emergency lights and siren are activated.

unit3.question: When can an officer operate a vehicle Code 2 (lights only)?
unit3.answer: As a patrol technique with the approval of a lieutenant or higher.
options: For any call for service.
During normal patrol, at the officer's discretion.
As a patrol technique with the approval of a lieutenant or higher.
Never, Code 2 is not an authorized response.
unit3.reference: GO 308.3.3(c): Officers may be allowed to drive Code 2 as a patrol technique with the approval of a lieutenant or higher (high visibility directed patrols).

unit3.question: Who appoints the Canine Coordinator?
unit3.answer: The canine coordinator... shall be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or the authorized designee.
options: The lead canine handler.
A vote of the canine unit members.
The Training Supervisor.
The canine coordinator... shall be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or the authorized designee.
unit3.reference: GO 309.4 CANINE COORDINATOR: The canine coordinator, or designated canine handler, shall be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or the authorized designee.

unit3.question: When can a canine be used to locate and apprehend a suspect?
unit3.answer: When there is a reasonable belief the suspect poses an imminent threat of violence or serious harm.
options: For any person who runs from the police.
For any misdemeanor offense.
When there is a reasonable belief the suspect poses an imminent threat of violence or serious harm.
To apprehend a person for a traffic violation.
unit3.reference: GO 309.6(a): A canine may be used to locate and apprehend a suspect if the canine handler reasonably believes that the individual has either committed, is committing, or is threatening to commit any serious offense and if any of the following conditions exist: (a) There is a reasonable belief the suspect poses an imminent threat of violence or serious harm to the public, any officer or the handler;

unit3.question: What is a minimum qualification for an officer to be selected as a canine handler?
unit3.answer: Agreeing to be assigned to the position for a minimum of three years.
options: Having prior military experience.
Living outside the city limits.
Agreeing to be assigned to the position for a minimum of three years.
Being under the age of 30.
unit3.reference: GO 309.8(d): The minimum qualifications for the assignment of canine handler include: ... (d) Agreeing to be assigned to the position for a minimum of three years.

unit3.question: What is the policy regarding a canine being left unattended in a public area?
unit3.answer: A canine shall not be left unattended in any area to which the public may have access.
options: It is allowed for short periods.
It is permissible if the vehicle is running.
A canine shall not be left unattended in any area to which the public may have access.
It is allowed if the handler is within sight of the canine.
unit3.reference: GO 309.9.1(a): CANINE IN PUBLIC AREAS... (a) A canine shall not be left unattended in any area to which the public may have access.

unit3.question: What should an officer do before initiating medical aid to a person?
unit3.answer: Contact Public Safety Communications and request a response by EMS.
options: Wait for a supervisor to arrive.
Contact Public Safety Communications and request a response by EMS.
Get a signed waiver from the person.
Take photographs of the scene.
unit3.reference: GO 300.8 and 518.3: Before initiating medical aid, the member should contact Public Safety Communications and request a response by Emergency Medical Services (EMS) as the member deems appropriate (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 2B.0301).

unit3.question: When may a Review Board's review be delayed?
unit3.answer: Until after completion of any criminal investigation or review by a prosecutorial body.
options: If the board members are on vacation.
Until after completion of any criminal investigation or review by a prosecutorial body.
If the incident occurred on a holiday.
The review can never be delayed.
unit3.reference: GO 301.4.2 RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE BOARD: The Chief of Police will determine whether the board should delay its review until after completion of any criminal investigation, review by any prosecutorial body, filing of criminal charges, the decision not to file criminal charges or any other action.

unit3.question: What is the policy for restraining persons known to be pregnant?
unit3.answer: They should be restrained in the least restrictive manner that is effective for officer safety.
options: They should not be restrained under any circumstances.
They should be restrained in the same manner as any other person.
They should be restrained in the least restrictive manner that is effective for officer safety.
They must be transported by ambulance if restraints are used.
unit3.reference: GO 302.3.2 RESTRAINT OF PREGNANT PERSONS: Persons who are known to be pregnant should be restrained in the least restrictive manner that is effective for officer safety.

unit3.question: How often must control devices be inspected?
unit3.answer: Periodically by the employee's supervisor or the designated instructor.
options: Annually.
Before each shift.
Periodically by the employee's supervisor or the designated instructor.
Only when a malfunction is suspected.
unit3.reference: GO 303.3.2(b): Every control device shall be periodically inspected by the employee's supervisor or the designated instructor for a particular control device.

unit3.question: When using a baton, which area should NOT be intentionally targeted except in cases of imminent threat of serious bodily injury or death?
unit3.answer: The head, neck, throat, spine, heart, kidneys and groin.
options: The arms and legs.
The torso.
The hands and feet.
The head, neck, throat, spine, heart, kidneys and groin.
unit3.reference: GO 303.6 BATON GUIDELINES: The head, neck, throat, spine, heart, kidneys and groin should not be intentionally targeted except when the officer reasonably believes the suspect poses an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or death to the officer or others.

unit3.question: What is the primary purpose of the verbal warning before using a CED?
unit3.answer: To provide the individual with a reasonable opportunity to voluntarily comply.
options: To escalate the situation.
To alert the media.
To provide the individual with a reasonable opportunity to voluntarily comply.
To test the functionality of the CED's speaker.
unit3.reference: GO 304.4(a): The purpose of the warning is to: (a) Provide the individual with a reasonable opportunity to voluntarily comply.

unit3.question: Who is responsible for the maintenance and repair of authorized personally owned firearms?
unit3.answer: The individual member.
options: The Department Armorer.
The Quartermaster.
The individual member.
The City of Denton.
unit3.reference: GO 305.4 EQUIPMENT: Maintenance and repair of authorized personally owned firearms are the responsibility of the individual member.

unit3.question: When flying armed, what is the officer's responsibility regarding notification to the air carrier?
unit3.answer: To notify the air carrier in advance of the intended armed travel.
options: No notification is required.
To notify the air carrier upon boarding.
To notify the air carrier in advance of the intended armed travel.
To notify the flight crew after takeoff.
unit3.reference: GO 305.9(f): It is the officer's responsibility to notify the air carrier in advance of the intended armed travel. This notification should be accomplished by early check-in at the carrier's check-in counter.

unit3.question: What is the definition of 'Ramming'?
unit3.answer: The deliberate act of contacting a suspect's vehicle with a law enforcement vehicle to functionally damage or force the suspect's vehicle to stop.
options: An accidental collision during a pursuit.
The deliberate act of contacting a suspect's vehicle with a law enforcement vehicle to functionally damage or force the suspect's vehicle to stop.
Using a patrol car to create a roadblock.
A maneuver to cause the suspect vehicle to spin out.
unit3.reference: GO 306.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Ramming - The deliberate act of contacting a suspect's vehicle with a law enforcement vehicle to functionally damage or otherwise force the suspect's vehicle to stop.

unit3.question: What must an officer do if their emergency equipment fails during an emergency response?
unit3.answer: The officer must terminate the emergency response and continue accordingly.
options: Continue the response without lights or siren.
The officer must terminate the emergency response and continue accordingly.
Return to the station immediately.
Request another unit to take over the response.
unit3.reference: GO 308.6 EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT: If the emergency equipment on the vehicle should fail to operate, the officer must terminate the emergency response and continue accordingly.

unit3.question: What is the primary role of the Canine Coordinator?
unit3.answer: To be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or authorized designee.
options: To handle all canine deployments.
To train all new canines.
To be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or authorized designee.
To act as the primary handler for all canines.
unit3.reference: GO 309.4 CANINE COORDINATOR: The canine coordinator, or designated canine handler, shall be appointed by and directly responsible to the Support Operations Bureau Chief or the authorized designee.

unit3.question: What is the policy regarding a canine handler declining a request for a specific assignment?
unit3.answer: The canine handler shall have the authority to decline a request for any specific assignment that they deem unsuitable.
options: The handler must accept all assignments.
The handler can only decline with a supervisor's approval.
The canine handler shall have the authority to decline a request for any specific assignment that they deem unsuitable.
The handler can only decline assignments outside the city.
unit3.reference: GO 309.5.1(b): All requests for canine assistance from outside agencies must be approved by the canine coordinator or designated canine handler and are subject to the following: ... (b) The canine handler shall have the authority to decline a request for any specific assignment that they deem unsuitable.

unit3.question: An officer should recognize that their conduct prior to the response to resistance may be what?
unit3.answer: A factor which can influence the level of force necessary in a situation.
options: Irrelevant to the level of force used.
A factor which can influence the level of force necessary in a situation.
Only important if it is recorded.
A private matter not subject to review.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.1 PHILOSOPHY: Officers should recognize that their conduct prior to the response to resistance may be a factor which can influence the level of force necessary in a situation.

unit3.question: A 'Totality of the circumstances' includes the conduct of the officer and what other party?
unit3.answer: The subject leading up to the use of force.
options: Any witnesses present.
The subject leading up to the use of force.
The communications dispatcher.
The officer's supervisor.
unit3.reference: GO 300.1.2 DEFINITIONS: Totality of the circumstances - All facts and circumstances known to the officer at the time, taken as a whole, including the conduct of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of force.

unit3.question: An officer who observes another officer use force that is potentially beyond what is objectively reasonable must do what?
unit3.answer: Report these observations to a supervisor as soon as feasible.
options: Discuss it with the other officer first.
Report these observations to a supervisor as soon as feasible.
Write a memo to the Chief of Police within 30 days.
Only report it if an injury occurred.
unit3.reference: GO 300.2.1 DUTY TO INTERVENE AND REPORT: An officer or employee who observes another law enforcement officer or employee use force that is potentially beyond that which is objectively reasonable under the circumstances shall report these observations to a supervisor as soon as feasible (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 2B.0251).

unit3.question: What is one example of a verbal persuasion technique listed under de-escalation?
unit3.answer: Listen to the subject's side of the story and permit them to express frustration.
options: Threaten the subject with immediate arrest.
Shout commands to establish authority.
Listen to the subject's side of the story and permit them to express frustration.
Refuse to speak with the subject.
unit3.reference: GO 300.3.1(a)3.(a): Verbal Persuasion -- ... (a) Listen to the subject's side of the story and permit them to express frustration;

unit3.question: The use of an improvised device or method must be reasonable and utilized only to what degree?
unit3.answer: To the degree that reasonably appears necessary to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement purpose.
options: As much as the officer desires.
To the degree that reasonably appears necessary to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement purpose.
To the point of causing injury.
It is never authorized.
unit3.reference: GO 300.5: In such circumstances, the use of any improvised device or method must nonetheless be reasonable and utilized only to the degree that reasonably appears necessary to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement purpose.

unit3.question: If it is not reasonably apparent to a person that they are to be arrested, what should an officer do before using force?
unit3.answer: Make clear their intent to arrest or search, and identify themselves as peace officers.
options: Use force immediately to gain compliance.
Wait for the person to ask if they are under arrest.
Make clear their intent to arrest or search, and identify themselves as peace officers.
Call for a supervisor before proceeding.
unit3.reference: GO 300.5.1 RESPONSE TO EFFECT AN ARREST: If it is not reasonably apparent to the person to be arrested, or it is not reasonably impracticable to do so, officers should make clear their intent to arrest or search, and identify themselves as peace officers, before using force (Tex. Penal Code § 9.51).

unit3.question: The review by the Response to Resistance Review Board shall be based upon what?
unit3.answer: Those facts which were reasonably believed or known by the officer at the time of the incident.
options: Information discovered after the incident was over.
The opinion of the media.
Those facts which were reasonably believed or known by the officer at the time of the incident.
The suspect's criminal history.
unit3.reference: GO 301.4.2 RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE BOARD: The review shall be based upon those facts which were reasonably believed or known by the officer at the time of the incident, applying any legal requirements, department policies, procedures and approved training to those facts.

unit3.question: What is the policy for using the WRAP device?
unit3.answer: It will not be used on a subject who only displays passive resistance.
options: It can be used as a means of punishment.
It can be used by any officer, trained or not.
It will not be used on a subject who only displays passive resistance.
It can be used to transport any arrested person.
unit3.reference: GO 302.8.1 GUIDELINES FOR USE OF WRAP DEVICE: The WRAP device will not be used: ... On a subject who only displays passive resistance, other than to facilitate safe transportation to a police vehicle and/or the jail;

unit3.question: Who is responsible for the normal maintenance of control devices?
unit3.answer: Personnel using the various devices.
options: The Quartermaster.
The Training Supervisor.
Personnel using the various devices.
The Logistics Section Lieutenant.
unit3.reference: GO 303.5.3 USER RESPONSIBILITIES: All normal maintenance, charging or cleaning shall remain the responsibility of personnel using the various devices.

unit3.question: What is the policy on using OC spray on individuals who merely fail to disperse?
unit3.answer: OC spray should not be used against individuals or groups who merely fail to disperse.
options: It is the preferred method for crowd dispersal.
OC spray should not be used against individuals or groups who merely fail to disperse.
It can be used if a verbal warning is given first.
It is authorized for any unlawful assembly.
unit3.reference: GO 303.8 OLEORESIN CAPSICUM (OC) PRESIDIA GEL (CS) GUIDELINES: OC spray should not, however, be used against individuals or groups who merely fail to disperse or do not reasonably appear to present a risk to the safety of department members or the public.

unit3.question: Can an officer hold a firearm and a CED at the same time?
unit3.answer: No, officers should not hold a firearm and the CED at the same time.
options: Yes, it is a recommended tactical procedure.
No, officers should not hold a firearm and the CED at the same time.
Yes, but only in emergency situations.
Only if they are left-handed.
unit3.reference: GO 304.3(c): Officers should not hold a firearm and the CED at the same time.

unit3.question: A person holding a driver's license issued by the DOS who is stopped for a traffic violation may be prevented from doing what if they have diplomatic immunity?
unit3.answer: Being compelled to sign the citation.
options: Receiving a citation.
Being asked for their license.
Being compelled to sign the citation.
Having their vehicle searched.
unit3.reference: GO 522.5.1 and 522.4(a): Generally, all persons with diplomatic and consular privileges and immunities may be issued a citation or notice to appear. However, the person may not be compelled to sign the citation.

unit3.question: What is the primary policy for vehicle pursuits?
unit3.answer: To weigh the importance of apprehending suspects against the risks associated with the pursuit.
options: To pursue all fleeing vehicles regardless of the offense.
To terminate all pursuits once they leave the city limits.
To weigh the importance of apprehending suspects against the risks associated with the pursuit.
To use any means necessary to stop a fleeing vehicle.
unit3.reference: GO 306.2 POLICY: It is the policy of this department to weigh the importance of apprehending suspects who unlawfully flee from law enforcement against the risks associated with vehicle pursuits.

unit3.question: When is an officer prohibited from pursuing a vehicle?
unit3.answer: For traffic offenses alone.
options: If the suspect is a juvenile.
During nighttime hours.
For traffic offenses alone.
If the officer is working alone.
unit3.reference: GO 306.3.2(i): Officers are prohibited from pursuing vehicles for traffic offenses alone.

unit3.question: In a foot pursuit, when should an initiating officer NOT attempt to overtake and confront a suspect?
unit3.answer: When acting alone and when practicable.
options: If the suspect is unarmed.
If the officer is physically fit.
When acting alone and when practicable.
If other officers are nearby.
unit3.reference: GO 307.5.1 INITIATING OFFICER RESPONSIBILITIES: When acting alone and when practicable, the initiating officer should not attempt to overtake and confront the suspect but should attempt to keep the suspect in sight until sufficient officers are present to safely apprehend the suspect.

unit3.question: When can an officer operate an emergency vehicle without audible or visual signals?
unit3.answer: When responding to an emergency call with probable cause to believe the signals will cause the suspect to destroy evidence.
options: At any time, at the officer's discretion.
Only during undercover operations.
When responding to an emergency call with probable cause to believe the signals will cause the suspect to destroy evidence.
Never, signals must always be used in an emergency.
unit3.reference: GO 308.3.2(a)1: Officers may operate an authorized emergency vehicle for a law enforcement purpose without using the audible or visual signals if the officer is responding to an emergency call or pursuing a suspected violator of the law with probable cause to believe that: (a) Knowledge of the presence of the officer will cause the suspect to: 1. Destroy or lose evidence of a suspected felony;

unit3.question: What is the policy for using canines in public demonstrations?
unit3.answer: Canine handlers shall not demonstrate any apprehension work unless authorized by the canine coordinator.
options: Apprehension work is a required part of all public demonstrations.
Canine handlers shall not demonstrate any apprehension work unless authorized by the canine coordinator.
Any handler can decide to demonstrate apprehension work.
Apprehension demonstrations are prohibited entirely.
unit3.reference: GO 309.5.2 PUBLIC DEMONSTRATION: Canine handlers shall not demonstrate any apprehension work unless authorized to do so by the canine coordinator.

unit3.question: When may a canine be used against a person known to be armed or violent?
unit3.answer: If they have evaded lawful detention or arrest for any crime.
options: Only if they have committed a felony.
If they have evaded lawful detention or arrest for any crime.
Only with a supervisor's direct order.
It is not permitted.
unit3.reference: GO 309.6(d): A canine may be used to locate and apprehend a suspect if... (d) Against any person who has evaded lawful detention or arrest for any crime and the person is known to be armed or violent; and/or

unit3.question: What is a canine handler's responsibility for the health and welfare of their canine?
unit3.answer: The handler shall ultimately be responsible.
options: The department veterinarian is solely responsible.
The Canine Coordinator is solely responsible.
The handler shall ultimately be responsible.
The City is responsible, but not the handler.
unit3.reference: GO 309.9 HANDLER RESPONSIBILITIES: The canine handler shall ultimately be responsible for the health and welfare of the canine and shall ensure that the canine receives proper nutrition, grooming, training, medical care, affection and living conditions.

unit3.question: What happens if a canine team fails to graduate or obtain certification?
unit3.answer: The team shall not be deployed in the field for tasks it is not certified for.
options: The team is given one more chance to pass.
The team shall not be deployed in the field for tasks it is not certified for.
The handler is reassigned to patrol.
The canine is retired from service.
unit3.reference: GO 309.12.2 FAILURE TO SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE TRAINING: Any canine team failing to graduate or obtain certification shall not be deployed in the field for tasks the team is not certified to perform until graduation or certification is achieved.

unit3.question: How often should an officer's job related training certificates be forwarded to the Training Division?
unit3.answer: As they are received.
options: Annually.
Only upon promotion.
As they are received.
Never, they are for personal records only.
unit3.reference: GO 203.8 TRAINING RECORDS: All department members, sworn and non-sworn, should forward a copy of their job related training certificates and certifications received from outside agencies and organizations to the Training Division.

unit4.question: What is the purpose of General Order 400, Major Incident Notification?
unit4.answer: To provide guidance on when, how, and to whom notification of major incidents should be made.
options: To establish the criteria for promoting officers.
To detail the procedures for evidence collection.
To provide guidance on when, how, and to whom notification of major incidents should be made.
To outline the department's media relations policy.
unit4.reference: GO 400.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The purpose of this order is to provide guidance to members of the Denton Police Department in determining when, how and to whom notification of major incidents should be made.

unit4.question: Which of the following is listed as a criterion for a major incident notification?
unit4.answer: An officer-involved shooting, whether on- or off-duty.
options: A minor traffic accident with no injuries.
A routine arrest for a Class C misdemeanor.
An officer-involved shooting, whether on- or off-duty.
A citizen complaint regarding a parking ticket.
unit4.reference: GO 400.3 CRITERIA FOR NOTIFICATION: The following list of incident types is provided as a guide for notification and is not intended to be all-inclusive: Officer-involved shooting, whether on- or off-duty (see the Officer-Involved Shootings and In-Custody Deaths General Order for special notification);

unit4.question: According to GO 400.3, which incident involving a department member requires a major incident notification?
unit4.answer: Significant injury or death to a member of the Department, whether on- or off-duty.
options: A member receiving a commendation.
A member being transferred to a new assignment.
Significant injury or death to a member of the Department, whether on- or off-duty.
A member taking a scheduled vacation.
unit4.reference: GO 400.3 CRITERIA FOR NOTIFICATION: Significant injury or death to a member of the Department, whether on- or off-duty;

unit4.question: Who is responsible for making the appropriate notifications for a major incident?
unit4.answer: The on-duty patrol Lieutenant.
options: The responding officer.
The on-duty dispatcher.
The Chief of Police.
The on-duty patrol Lieutenant.
unit4.reference: GO 400.4 LIEUTENANT RESPONSIBILITIES: The on-duty patrol Lieutenant is responsible for making the appropriate notifications.

unit4.question: In the event of a major incident, who must the Chief of Police be notified along with?
unit4.answer: The Assistant Chief of Police and the affected Bureau Chief.
options: The Mayor and the City Manager.
The on-duty patrol Sergeant.
The Assistant Chief of Police and the affected Bureau Chief.
The Public Information Officer only.
unit4.reference: GO 400.4.1 COMMAND STAFF NOTIFICATION: In the event an incident occurs as identified in the Criteria for Notification section above, the Chief of Police shall be notified along with the Assistant Chief of Police and the affected Bureau Chief.

unit4.question: When should the Public Information Officer be called after a major incident?
unit4.answer: If it appears the media may have a significant interest in the incident.
options: For every major incident, regardless of media interest.
If it appears the media may have a significant interest in the incident.
Only if the Chief of Police is unavailable.
After a press release has been drafted.
unit4.reference: GO 400.4.4 PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICER: After members of the command staff have been notified, the Public Information Officer shall be called if it appears the media may have a significant interest in the incident.

unit4.question: The Peer Support Team Coordinator or Mental Health Consultant should be notified to provide assistance for which of the following incidents?
unit4.answer: A vehicle pursuit that results in death or serious bodily injury to any person.
options: A routine arrest.
A minor traffic collision with no injuries.
A vehicle pursuit that results in death or serious bodily injury to any person.
A public speaking engagement by an officer.
unit4.reference: GO 400.4.6 PEER SUPPORT TEAM NOTIFICATION: Critical incidents or traumatic life events can include, but are not limited to, incidents which involve the following: ... (c) Vehicle pursuits that result in death or serious bodily injury to any person;

unit4.question: What is the purpose of General Order 401 concerning Officer-Involved Shootings and In-Custody Deaths?
unit4.answer: To establish policy and procedures for the investigation of such incidents.
options: To guarantee that no officer will be disciplined for such an incident.
To outline the process for media notification only.
To establish policy and procedures for the investigation of such incidents.
To detail the types of firearms officers can use.
unit4.reference: GO 401.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The purpose of this general order is to establish policy and procedures for the investigation of an incident in which a person is injured or dies as the result of an officer-involved shooting, dies as a result of another action of an officer, or while in police custody.

unit4.question: What types of investigations do officer-involved shootings and in-custody deaths involve?
unit4.answer: A criminal investigation of the suspect's actions and the officer's actions, an administrative investigation, and a civil investigation.
options: Only a criminal investigation of the officer's actions.
Only an administrative investigation.
A criminal investigation of the suspect's actions and the officer's actions, an administrative investigation, and a civil investigation.
Only a civil investigation to determine liability.
unit4.reference: GO 401.3 TYPES OF INVESTIGATIONS: Officer-involved shootings and in-custody deaths involve several separate investigations. The investigations may include: A criminal investigation of the suspect's actions; A criminal investigation of the involved officer's actions; An administrative investigation as to general order compliance by involved officers.; or A civil investigation to determine potential liability.

unit4.question: What determines the jurisdiction for the investigation of an officer-involved shooting or in-custody death?
unit4.answer: The location of the shooting or in-custody death and the agency employing the involved officer.
options: The rank of the involved officer.
The severity of the injury.
The location of the shooting or in-custody death and the agency employing the involved officer.
The time of day the incident occurred.
unit4.reference: GO 401.4 CONTROL OF INVESTIGATIONS: Jurisdiction is determined by the location of the shooting or in-custody death and the agency employing the involved officer.

unit4.question: Upon arrival at the scene of an officer-involved shooting, who is the initial officer-in-charge?
unit4.answer: The first uninvolved DPD officer.
options: The most senior officer on scene, regardless of involvement.
The first uninvolved DPD officer.
The officer who discharged their weapon.
The on-duty shift supervisor, who must respond first.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.1 UNINVOLVED OFFICER RESPONSIBILITIES: Upon arrival at the scene of an officer-involved shooting or in-custody death, the first uninvolved DPD officer will be the officer-in-charge and will assume the responsibilities of a supervisor until properly relieved.

unit4.question: What is one of the first responsibilities of a supervisor arriving at an officer-involved shooting scene?
unit4.answer: Attempt to obtain a brief overview of the situation from any uninvolved officers.
options: Conduct a detailed interview with the involved officer.
Secure all firearms from involved officers.
Attempt to obtain a brief overview of the situation from any uninvolved officers.
Make a statement to the media.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.2 SUPERVISOR RESPONSIBILITIES: Upon arrival at the scene, the first uninvolved DPD supervisor should ensure completion of the duties as outlined above, plus: (a) Attempt to obtain a brief overview of the situation from any uninvolved officers.

unit4.question: Who is responsible for coordinating all aspects of an officer-involved shooting or in-custody death until relieved by the Chief or a Bureau Chief?
unit4.answer: The Lieutenant.
options: The first responding officer.
The on-scene supervisor.
The Lieutenant.
The Public Information Officer.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.3 LIEUTENANT RESPONSIBILITIES: Upon learning of an officer-involved shooting or in-custody death, the Lieutenant shall be responsible for coordinating all aspects of the incident until they are relieved by the Chief of Police or a Bureau Chief.

unit4.question: What consideration is given to an involved officer's request for legal representation?
unit4.answer: Any request for legal or association representation will be accommodated.
options: It will be denied until a statement is given.
The officer must wait 24 hours before contacting an attorney.
Any request for legal or association representation will be accommodated.
Legal representation is only for criminal investigations.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.5(a): The following shall be considered for the involved officer: (a) Any request for legal or association representation will be accommodated.

unit4.question: What is the policy regarding involved DPD officers meeting before providing a formal interview or report?
unit4.answer: They shall not be permitted to meet collectively or in a group.
options: They are encouraged to meet to ensure their stories are consistent.
They shall not be permitted to meet collectively or in a group.
They may meet only if their attorneys are present.
They can meet after a 24-hour waiting period.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.5(a)1.: Involved DPD officers shall not be permitted to meet collectively or in a group prior to providing a formal interview or report.

unit4.question: To whom should requests from involved non-DPD officers be referred?
unit4.answer: To their employing agency.
options: To the Denton Police Chief.
To the on-scene supervisor.
To their employing agency.
To the Denton City Attorney.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.5(a)2.: Requests from involved non-DPD officers should be referred to their employing agency.

unit4.question: What assistance shall be provided by the Department to each involved DPD officer following a critical incident?
unit4.answer: A licensed psychotherapist shall be provided.
options: A mandatory 3-day suspension.
A bonus for their actions.
A licensed psychotherapist shall be provided.
A transfer to a different assignment.
unit4.reference: GO 401.5.5(d): A licensed psychotherapist shall be provided by the Department to each involved DPD officer.

unit4.question: What is the purpose of the Tactical Operations Unit (TOU)?
unit4.answer: To handle critical field operations where special tactical deployment or intense negotiations are beyond the capacity of field officers.
options: To handle all traffic enforcement.
To conduct all initial criminal investigations.
To handle critical field operations where special tactical deployment or intense negotiations are beyond the capacity of field officers.
To manage the department's public relations.
unit4.reference: GO 402.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This general order provides guidelines for the specialized support of the Tactical Operations Unit (TOU) in handling critical field operations where special tactical deployment methods or intense negotiations are beyond the capacity of field officers.

unit4.question: What does CNT stand for in the context of the Tactical Operations Unit?
unit4.answer: Crisis negotiation team.
options: Critical Neutralization Tactics.
Community Networking Team.
Crisis negotiation team.
Command and Notification Team.
unit4.reference: GO 402.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Crisis negotiation team (CNT) - Designated officers... who are specifically trained and equipped to provide skilled verbal communications to de-escalate or effect surrender...

unit4.question: What are the three basic operational functions the TOU should develop resources to perform?
unit4.answer: Command and control, Containment, and Entry/apprehension/rescue.
options: Investigation, Reporting, and Prosecution.
Command and control, Containment, and Entry/apprehension/rescue.
Public relations, Media management, and Community outreach.
Traffic control, Crowd management, and Perimeter security.
unit4.reference: GO 402.2 POLICY: The TOU should develop sufficient resources to perform three basic operational functions: (a) Command and control (b) Containment (c) Entry/apprehension/rescue

unit4.question: Who manages the Tactical Operations Unit (TOU)?
unit4.answer: The appointed TOU Commander.
options: The Patrol Bureau Chief.
The Chief of Police.
The appointed TOU Commander.
A committee of team members.
unit4.reference: GO 402.4 MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION: Under the direction of the Chief of Police, through the Patrol Bureau Chief, the TOU shall be managed by the appointed TOU Commander.

unit4.question: Which of the following is a minimum requirement for the TOU's organizational procedures?
unit4.answer: Member selection, retention and termination criteria.
options: A detailed budget for all equipment.
A published schedule of all training exercises.
Member selection, retention and termination criteria.
A list of all past members of the unit.
unit4.reference: GO 402.6.1 ORGANIZATIONAL PROCEDURES: The Department shall develop a separate written set of organizational procedures that should address, at a minimum: ... (c) Member selection, retention and termination criteria.

unit4.question: Which situation is listed as an appropriate use for the activation of the TOU?
unit4.answer: Incidents where hostages are taken.
options: Routine traffic stops.
Responding to a noise complaint.
Incidents where hostages are taken.
Serving a civil citation.
unit4.reference: GO 402.7.1 APPROPRIATE USE: Incidents that may result in the activation of the TOU include: ... (b) Incidents where hostages are taken;

unit4.question: Who will be the Incident Commander at the scene of an event until relieved by the responding TOU?
unit4.answer: The supervisor-in-charge at the scene.
options: The first officer to arrive.
The TOU Commander, via radio.
The supervisor-in-charge at the scene.
The highest-ranking officer in the city.
unit4.reference: GO 402.7.2 ON-SCENE DETERMINATION AND NOTIFICATION: The supervisor-in-charge at the scene of a particular event will be designated as the Incident Commander and will assess whether the TOU is to be requested to respond to the scene. The Incident Commander shall maintain overall command of the scene until relieved by the responding TOU.

unit4.question: The testing process for selection of SWAT members consists of an oral interview, physical agility test, and what else?
unit4.answer: Firearm qualification and team evaluation.
options: A written essay and a polygraph exam.
A psychological evaluation and a medical exam.
Firearm qualification and team evaluation.
A driving course and a public speaking test.
unit4.reference: GO 402.8.1 SELECTION OF SWAT MEMBERS: The testing process will consist of an oral interview, physical agility test, firearm qualification and team evaluation.

unit4.question: How often must each SWAT team member perform a physical fitness test?
unit4.answer: Twice each year.
options: Once a month.
Once a year.
Twice each year.
Only upon joining the team.
unit4.reference: GO 402.8.2(a): Each SWAT team member shall perform a physical fitness test twice each year.

unit4.question: What is the minimum requirement for training for the Crisis Negotiation Team (CNT)?
unit4.answer: A minimum of one training day per quarter.
options: A minimum of one training day per year.
A minimum of one training day per month.
A minimum of one training day per quarter.
Training is on an as-needed basis only.
unit4.reference: GO 402.9.2 NEGOTIATION TRAINING: A minimum of one training day per quarter will be required to provide the opportunity for role playing and situational training necessary to maintain proper skills.

unit4.question: What is a 'Barricade situation'?
unit4.answer: An incident where a person maintains a position of cover or concealment and ignores or resists law enforcement personnel, and it is reasonable to believe the subject is armed.
options: Any situation where a person refuses to exit a building.
An incident where a person is unlawfully held as security.
An incident where a person maintains a position of cover or concealment and ignores or resists law enforcement personnel, and it is reasonable to believe the subject is armed.
A peaceful protest that blocks a roadway.
unit4.reference: GO 403.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Barricade situation - An incident where a person maintains a position of cover or concealment and ignores or resists law enforcement personnel, and it is reasonable to believe the subject is armed with a dangerous or deadly weapon.

unit4.question: What is the policy for addressing hostage and barricade situations?
unit4.answer: To have due regard for the preservation of life and balancing the risk of injury.
options: To use maximum force to resolve the situation quickly.
To prioritize the apprehension of the offender above all else.
To have due regard for the preservation of life and balancing the risk of injury.
To wait for the suspect to surrender without intervention.
unit4.reference: GO 403.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to address hostage and barricade situations with due regard for the preservation of life and balancing the risk of injury, while obtaining the safe release of hostages, apprehending offenders and securing available evidence.

unit4.question: Who may order the disconnection of telephone lines to prevent an armed and barricaded suspect from communicating with others?
unit4.answer: The Tactical Operations Unit Commander.
options: Any officer on scene.
The on-duty shift supervisor.
The Tactical Operations Unit Commander.
The telephone company, on their own initiative.
unit4.reference: GO 403.3.1 EMERGENCY COMMUNICATIONS: The Tactical Operations Unit Commander may order the telephone company to disconnect or control telephone lines in order to prevent an armed and barricaded suspect or person holding a hostage from communicating with anyone other than designated personnel...

unit4.question: What is a primary consideration for first responders at a potential hostage or barricade situation?
unit4.answer: To evaluate all available information to determine the nature of the incident.
options: To immediately enter the location and confront the suspect.
To set up a media staging area.
To evaluate all available information to determine the nature of the incident.
To begin negotiations with the suspect immediately.
unit4.reference: GO 403.4 FIRST RESPONDER CONSIDERATIONS: First responding officers should promptly and carefully evaluate all available information to determine whether an incident involves, or may later develop into, a hostage or barricade situation.

unit4.question: What is one of the recommended options for officers handling a barricade situation while awaiting specialized personnel?
unit4.answer: Establish an inner and outer perimeter.
options: Attempt a dynamic entry.
Use loudspeakers to order the suspect out.
Establish an inner and outer perimeter.
Turn off power to the building.
unit4.reference: GO 403.4.1(g): In the interim, the following options, while not all-inclusive or in any particular order, should be considered: ... (g) Establish an inner and outer perimeter as circumstances require and resources permit to prevent unauthorized access.

unit4.question: What should personnel on scene NOT do when responding to a bomb threat?
unit4.answer: Transmit on any equipment capable of producing radio frequency energy.
options: Evacuate the immediate area.
Establish a perimeter.
Transmit on any equipment capable of producing radio frequency energy.
Request assistance from the fire department.
unit4.reference: GO 404.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: Once on scene, personnel should not transmit on any equipment that is capable of producing radio frequency energy within the evacuation area around the suspected device.

unit4.question: What is the department's policy priority in response to bomb calls?
unit4.answer: To place a higher priority on the safety of persons and the public over damage or destruction to property.
options: To prioritize the preservation of property.
To apprehend the suspect at all costs.
To place a higher priority on the safety of persons and the public over damage or destruction to property.
To minimize the financial impact on the city.
unit4.reference: GO 404.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to place a higher priority on the safety of persons and the public over damage or destruction to public or private property.

unit4.question: If a bomb threat is received against a federal building, who should be immediately notified?
unit4.answer: The Federal Protective Service.
options: The Denton Fire Department.
The FBI.
The Federal Protective Service.
The Secret Service.
unit4.reference: GO 404.4.3 FEDERAL BUILDING OR PROPERTY: If the bomb threat is against a federal building or property, the Federal Protective Service should be immediately notified.

unit4.question: What should be done with a suspected explosive device when it is found?
unit4.answer: It should not be touched or moved except by the bomb squad.
options: It should be immediately placed in a bucket of water.
It should not be touched or moved except by the bomb squad.
The finding officer should attempt to disarm it.
It should be transported to an open field.
unit4.reference: GO 404.6(b): When handling an incident involving a suspected explosive device, the following guidelines... should be followed: ... (b) The device should not be touched or moved except by the bomb squad or military explosive ordnance disposal team.

unit4.question: After an explosion has occurred, who should be notified?
unit4.answer: The Fire department, Fire marshal, and Bomb squad, among others.
options: Only the Chief of Police.
Only the media.
The Fire department, Fire marshal, and Bomb squad, among others.
The City Council.
unit4.reference: GO 404.7.2 NOTIFICATIONS: When an explosion has occurred, the following people should be notified as appropriate: Fire department, Fire marshal, Bomb squad...

unit4.question: What is a key consideration for first responders if they believe a suspect's acts or threats are placing lives in imminent danger?
unit4.answer: To consider reasonable options to reduce, prevent or eliminate the threat.
options: To wait for the arrival of the SWAT team.
To immediately use lethal force.
To consider reasonable options to reduce, prevent or eliminate the threat.
To establish a negotiation dialogue.
unit4.reference: GO 405.4 FIRST RESPONSE: If there is a reasonable belief that acts or threats by a suspect are placing lives in imminent danger, first responding officers should consider reasonable options to reduce, prevent or eliminate the threat.

unit4.question: What is one of the factors an officer should consider when deciding on a course of action in a crisis situation?
unit4.answer: Whether the suspect can be contained or denied access to victims.
options: The officer's personal feelings about the suspect.
The time remaining on the officer's shift.
Whether the suspect can be contained or denied access to victims.
The potential for media coverage.
unit4.reference: GO 405.4: When deciding on a course of action officers should consider: ... (d) Whether the suspect can be contained or denied access to victims.

unit4.question: Who is responsible for coordinating critical incident planning?
unit4.answer: The Patrol Bureau Chief.
options: The TOU Commander.
The Emergency Management Coordinator.
The Patrol Bureau Chief.
The Chief of Police.
unit4.reference: GO 405.5 PLANNING: The Patrol Bureau Chief should coordinate critical incident planning.

unit4.question: What is one of the topics that rapid response training should address?
unit4.answer: First aid, including gunshot trauma.
options: Report writing.
Public speaking.
Vehicle maintenance.
First aid, including gunshot trauma.
unit4.reference: GO 405.6 TRAINING: The Training Supervisor should include rapid response to critical incidents in the training plan. This training should address: ... (d) First aid, including gunshot trauma.

unit4.question: What is the purpose of General Order 406, Hazardous Material Response?
unit4.answer: To outline the responsibilities of members who respond to these events.
options: To provide a list of all hazardous materials.
To outline the responsibilities of members who respond to these events.
To detail the cleaning procedures for department facilities.
To establish the department's hazmat team.
unit4.reference: GO 406.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This general order outlines the responsibilities of members who respond to these events and the factors that should be considered while on-scene...

unit4.question: What is the primary policy regarding response to hazardous material emergencies?
unit4.answer: To respond with due regard for the safety of the public and those members responding.
options: To prioritize evidence collection over safety.
To delegate all responses to the fire department.
To respond with due regard for the safety of the public and those members responding.
To respond only during daylight hours.
unit4.reference: GO 406.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to respond to hazardous material emergencies with due regard for the safety of the public and those members responding to such incidents.

unit4.question: What is a key consideration for officers at a scene involving suspected hazardous materials?
unit4.answer: Remain upwind, uphill and at a safe distance.
options: Approach the scene as quickly as possible.
Remain upwind, uphill and at a safe distance.
Touch the material to identify it.
Use radio communication as close to the material as possible.
unit4.reference: GO 406.4(d): The following steps should be considered at any scene involving suspected hazardous materials: ... (d) Remain upwind, uphill and at a safe distance...

unit4.question: What should a member who believes they have been exposed to a hazardous material do?
unit4.answer: Immediately report the exposure to a supervisor.
options: Wait until the end of the shift to report it.
Complete a report before seeking medical attention.
Immediately report the exposure to a supervisor.
Wash their uniform at home.
unit4.reference: GO 406.5 REPORTING EXPOSURE: Department members who believe they have been exposed to a hazardous material shall immediately report the exposure to a supervisor.

unit4.question: The Field Force Operations (FFO) concept is used to handle what type of situations?
unit4.answer: Civil disorder situations.
options: Routine traffic control.
Active shooter incidents.
Civil disorder situations.
Hostage negotiations.
unit4.reference: GO 407.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This order covers the activation and mobilization of on-duty personnel to handle civil disorder situations when it has been determined to use the Field Force Operations (FFO) concept.

unit4.question: Which of the following personnel have the authority to activate a Field Force Operations (FFO) response?
unit4.answer: Lieutenants.
options: Any patrol officer.
Communications dispatchers.
Lieutenants.
The Mayor.
unit4.reference: GO 407.2(b): The following personnel have the authority to activate a FFO response: (a) Lieutenants; (b) Deputy Chiefs; (c) Assistant Chief; and (d) Chief of Police.

unit4.question: What is the primary objective of Field Force Operations (FFO)?
unit4.answer: Life/safety.
options: Making mass arrests.
Protecting property.
Life/safety.
Restoring traffic flow.
unit4.reference: GO 407.3 FIELD FORCE OPERATIONS CONCEPT: The objectives of the FFO are: (a) Life/safety;

unit4.question: Who commands the Field Force Operations (FFO)?
unit4.answer: The on-scene Incident Commander (IC) and/or designated supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The first arriving officer.
The on-scene Incident Commander (IC) and/or designated supervisor.
A Lieutenant from the Support Bureau.
unit4.reference: GO 407.3.1(a): The FFO is commanded by the on-scene Incident Commander (IC) and/or designated supervisor in charge of the event per ICS protocol.

unit4.question: What is the 'linear strategy' in containment operations?
unit4.answer: Deploying officers as a blocking force along a roadway or geographic barrier.
options: Surrounding a problem area on all sides.
Dividing an area into smaller units.
Deploying officers as a blocking force along a roadway or geographic barrier.
Making random arrests throughout the crowd.
unit4.reference: GO 407.5.1(a): Linear strategy - Deploys officers as a blocking force along a roadway or geographic barrier perpendicular to access routes into the impacted area.

unit4.question: Who has the authority to issue local emergency orders, such as a curfew, during a civil disorder?
unit4.answer: The Mayor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The Incident Commander.
The Mayor.
The City Council.
unit4.reference: GO 407.5.3 LOCAL EMERGENCY ORDERS: The Mayor has the authority to issue and enforce rules, regulations, orders, and directions necessary to maintain life safety, incident stabilization, property protection, and societal restoration (e.g., establish a curfew).

unit4.question: Who is responsible for ensuring that personnel under their command are proficiently trained in FFO tactics?
unit4.answer: Lieutenants.
options: Sergeants.
Lieutenants.
The Training Supervisor.
Bureau Chiefs.
unit4.reference: GO 407.6(b): Lieutenants are responsible for: 1. Ensuring that personnel under their command are proficiently trained in FFO tactics, procedures, and commands; and

unit4.question: What is the policy for securing crime or disaster scenes?
unit4.answer: To secure scenes so that evidence is preserved, and to identify and mitigate dangers.
options: To allow public access for transparency.
To prioritize officer safety over evidence preservation.
To secure scenes so that evidence is preserved, and to identify and mitigate dangers.
To clean the scene as quickly as possible.
unit4.reference: GO 408.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to secure crime or disaster scenes so that evidence is preserved, and to identify and mitigate the dangers associated with a major crime or disaster scene for the safety of the community and those required to enter or work near the scene.

unit4.question: Who is generally responsible for the immediate safety of the public and preservation of a crime scene?
unit4.answer: The first officer at the scene.
options: The property owner.
The first officer at the scene.
The first supervisor to arrive.
The fire department.
unit4.reference: GO 408.3 SCENE RESPONSIBILITY: The first officer at the scene of a crime or major incident is generally responsible for the immediate safety of the public and preservation of the scene.

unit4.question: What is one of the first considerations for a first responder at a crime or disaster scene?
unit4.answer: Broadcast emergency information, including requests for additional assistance.
options: Interview all witnesses.
Collect all evidence.
Broadcast emergency information, including requests for additional assistance.
Make a statement to the media.
unit4.reference: GO 408.4(a): The following list generally describes the first responder's function at a crime or disaster scene... (a) Broadcast emergency information, including requests for additional assistance and resources.

unit4.question: When may officers have authority to secure a group of individuals who have been exposed to a communicable disease?
unit4.answer: When the Department of Health or a health authority has ordered it.
options: At any time based on their own discretion.
Only if the individuals are committing a crime.
When the Department of Health or a health authority has ordered it.
Never, as it is a violation of rights.
unit4.reference: GO 408.6 ENFORCING HEALTH ORDERS: When the Department of Health or a health authority has ordered a group of five or more individuals who have been exposed to or infected with a communicable disease to implement control measures to prevent the spread of the disease, officers have authority to secure the members of the group...

unit4.question: What is the purpose of General Order 409, Utility Service Emergencies?

To provide guidelines for addressing City utility service emergencies.
To establish a new utility service.
To outline the billing process for utilities.

unit4.question: If a water line break occurs on the City side of the water meter, who should be notified?
unit4.answer: Public works personnel.

The property owner.
Public works personnel.
The police department's records division.

unit4.question: Who should be referred reports of a possible natural gas leak?

The public works department.
The fire department and the local gas entity.
The Environmental Protection Agency.

unit4.question: What does the definition of 'Aircraft' include?
unit4.answer: Any fixed wing aircraft, rotorcraft, balloon, blimp/dirigible or glider.
options: Only commercial airplanes.
Only police department drones.
Any fixed wing aircraft, rotorcraft, balloon, blimp/dirigible or glider.
Only military aircraft.
unit4.reference: GO 410.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Aircraft - Any fixed wing aircraft, rotorcraft, balloon, blimp/dirigible or glider that is capable of carrying a person or any unmanned aerial vehicle other than those intended for non-commercial recreational use.

unit4.question: Upon arrival at an aircraft accident, what is a primary responsibility of officers?
unit4.answer: Protect persons and property.
options: Collect all personal belongings.
Interview the pilot immediately.
Protect persons and property.
Take photos for the media.
unit4.reference: GO 410.3(a): Officers or other authorized members tasked with initial scene management should establish an inner and outer perimeter to: (a) Protect persons and property.

unit4.question: Who should be notified once an aircraft accident has been reported?
unit4.answer: The FAA FSDO (Flight Services District Office).
options: The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) directly.
The local airport manager.
The FAA FSDO (Flight Services District Office).
The Department of Homeland Security.
unit4.reference: GO 410.5 NOTIFICATIONS: When an aircraft accident is reported to this department, the responding supervisor shall ensure notification is or has been made to the FAA FSDO.

unit4.question: Prior to FAA arrival at an aircraft crash scene, who has access to the scene?
unit4.answer: Limited to authorized personnel such as fire department, EMS, or Medical Examiner.
options: The general public.
The media.
Limited to authorized personnel such as fire department, EMS, or Medical Examiner.
Only federal investigators.

unit4.question: What should be done with military aircraft wreckage at an accident scene?
unit4.answer: It shall not be photographed unless authorized by a military commanding officer.
options: It should be photographed immediately for evidence.
It shall not be photographed unless authorized by a military commanding officer.
It should be moved to a secure location by police.
It should be covered to hide it from view.

unit4.question: Who coordinates the media response for an aircraft accident?
unit4.answer: The Public Information Officer (PIO).
options: The FAA.
The NTSB.
The Public Information Officer (PIO).
The on-scene supervisor.

unit4.question: What is a 'Level I' tactical team capable of?
unit4.answer: Providing containment and intervention in critical incidents that exceed the training and resources available to line-level officers.
options: Only handling high-risk warrant service.
Operating on a full-time basis with advanced equipment.
Providing containment and intervention in critical incidents that exceed the training and resources available to line-level officers.
Conducting all hostage negotiations.

unit4.question: How often must TOU equipment be inspected?

Annually.
At least monthly.
Every six months.

unit4.question: What is the policy for a SWAT team member who fails a physical fitness test?

They are placed on administrative leave.

They are exempt from the physical fitness requirement for one year.

Within 30 days of the previous physical fitness test date, the member required to qualify shall report to a team supervisor and complete the entire physical fitness test.

unit4.question: If a person is unlawfully held as security so that specified terms or conditions will be met, what is the situation called?

options: Barricade situation.
Abduction.
Hostage situation.
Kidnapping.

unit4.question: When a bomb threat is received on a recorded line, what should be done?
unit4.answer: Reasonable steps should be taken to ensure the recording is preserved.

Reasonable steps should be taken to ensure the recording is preserved.
The recording should be transcribed and then deleted.
Only the dispatcher should listen to the recording.

unit4.answer: Emergency services and private security providers at likely target sites.

The city council.
Emergency services and private security providers at likely target sites.
The Texas Rangers.

unit4.question: What is the policy for responding to a possible leak of natural gas?
unit4.answer: It shall be promptly referred to the fire department and the local gas entity.

It shall be promptly referred to the fire department and the local gas entity.
The public works department handles all gas leaks.
It is not a police matter.

unit4.question: At an aircraft accident scene, who provides guidance on scene integrity and the movement of human remains?
unit4.answer: FAA investigators.

FAA investigators.

unit4.question: What is the policy on retaliation against a person who reports sexual abuse in a DPD facility?
unit4.answer: The Department will not tolerate retaliation.

The Department will not tolerate retaliation.
Retaliation is handled by the City's HR department.
Retaliation is a matter for civil court.

unit5.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding patrol services?
unit5.answer: To provide patrol services 24 hours a day, seven days a week and prioritize responses to requests for emergency services.
options: To provide patrol services only during business hours.
To respond only to calls that are reported online.
To provide patrol services 24 hours a day, seven days a week and prioritize responses to requests for emergency services.
To prioritize property crime responses over emergency services.
unit5.reference: GO 500.2 POLICY: The Denton Police Department provides patrol services 24 hours a day, seven days a week and will prioritize responses to requests for emergency services using available resources to enhance the safety of the public and department members.

unit5.question: Which of the following is a function of patrol services?
unit5.answer: Carrying out community-oriented policing and problem-solving activities.

Prosecuting cases in court.
Carrying out community-oriented policing and problem-solving activities.
Managing the department's budget.
unit5.reference: GO 500.3(i): Patrol services include, but are not limited to: ... (i) Carrying out community-oriented policing and problem-solving activities, including the application of resources to improve or resolve specific problems or situations and contacting or assisting members of the public in a positive way.
