unit6.question: What is the Denton Police Department's Mission Statement?
unit6.answer: To make Denton a safe, sustainable, and livable city for everyone, by keeping victims safe and holding offenders accountable.
options: To enforce all laws and ordinances of the City of Denton.
To serve the community with courage, integrity, and respect.
To reduce crime and the fear of crime through community policing.
To make Denton a safe, sustainable, and livable city for everyone, by keeping victims safe and holding offenders accountable.
unit6.reference: Mission Statement: To make Denton a safe, sustainable, and livable city for everyone, by keeping victims safe and holding offenders accountable.

unit7.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding traffic services?
unit7.answer: To provide traffic services including, but not limited to, enforcement, education and engineering.
options: To focus exclusively on traffic enforcement.
To delegate all traffic services to the state highway patrol.
To provide traffic services including, but not not limited to, enforcement, education and engineering.
To prioritize traffic education over enforcement.

unit7.question: Who is responsible for developing a comprehensive traffic safety plan for the department?
unit7.answer: The Traffic Supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The on-duty Patrol Lieutenant.
The Traffic Supervisor.
The City Traffic Engineer.
unit7.reference: GO 700.3(a): A designated Traffic Supervisor shall be responsible for: (a) Developing a comprehensive traffic safety plan for this department.

unit7.question: What is 'selective enforcement' in the context of traffic operations?
unit7.answer: The use of statistical data to identify high-accident locations and peak times for enforcement.
options: Enforcing only certain types of traffic laws.
Targeting only specific types of vehicles for enforcement.
The use of statistical data to identify high-accident locations and peak times for enforcement.
Allowing officers to select which laws they want to enforce.
unit7.reference: GO 700.4 SELECTIVE ENFORCEMENT: Patrol operations should include the use of statistical data to identify high-accident locations, days and peak times.

unit7.question: How often should the department's traffic safety plan be reviewed?
unit7.answer: At least annually.
options: Monthly.
Every two years.
At least annually.
Only when a major traffic incident occurs.
unit7.reference: GO 700.5.1 TRAFFIC SAFETY PLAN: A written traffic safety plan should be developed and reviewed at least annually.

unit7.question: What is the primary responsibility of officers upon arrival at a traffic collision scene?
unit7.answer: The safety of persons.
options: Issuing citations.
The safety of persons.
Clearing the roadway for traffic flow.
Preserving physical evidence.
unit7.reference: GO 701.3.1 INITIAL RESPONSIBILITIES: The primary responsibility of officers upon arrival at a traffic collision scene is the safety of persons. Officers should immediately ensure that appropriate actions are taken to provide for the safety of persons at the scene...

unit7.question: What must an officer provide to the victim of a hit-and-run collision?
unit7.answer: A written statement outlining their duties as an operator of a vehicle involved in a collision.
options: A copy of the full police report.
The officer's personal contact information.
A written statement outlining their duties as an operator of a vehicle involved in a collision.
A voucher for vehicle repairs.
unit7.reference: GO 701.4 HIT-AND-RUN COLLISIONS: The assigned officer will also provide the victim a written statement outlining their duties as an operator of a vehicle involved in a collision.

unit7.question: Under what circumstances is a driver required to complete a Driver's Crash Report (Form CR-2)?
unit7.answer: When a collision is not investigated by a peace officer and results in injury, death, or damage of $1,000 or more.
options: For every traffic collision, regardless of damage.
Only when the collision is investigated by an officer.
When a collision is not investigated by a peace officer and results in injury, death, or damage of $1,000 or more.
Only for collisions involving commercial vehicles.
unit7.reference: GO 701.5.1 DRIVER'S CRASH REPORT (FORM CR-2): A person who operates a motor vehicle that is involved in a collision not investigated by a peace officer... is required to make a written report of the collision... if the collision resulted in injury or death to a person or damage to the property of any one person to the apparent extent of $1,000 or more...

unit7.question: Which of the following is a circumstance that authorizes towing a vehicle?
unit7.answer: The vehicle is abandoned.
options: The vehicle has an expired registration sticker.
The driver received a verbal warning.
The vehicle is abandoned.
The vehicle is parked legally but is considered unsightly.
unit7.reference: GO 702.3.1(g): Circumstances that authorize towing: ... (g) The vehicle is abandoned...

unit7.question: What must be done before a stolen vehicle is released to its owner?
unit7.answer: It must be removed from TCIC/NCIC.
options: It must be held for 30 days.
The owner must pay a recovery fee.
It must be removed from TCIC/NCIC.
It must be inspected by a supervisor.
unit7.reference: GO 702.3.4 STOLEN VEHICLES: Before the stolen vehicle is released, it must be removed from the Texas Crime Information Center (TCIC) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC).

unit7.question: What is the purpose of a vehicle inventory?
unit7.answer: To protect the owner's property, protect the department from claims of theft, and for officer safety.
options: To search for evidence of a crime.
To determine the vehicle's market value.
To protect the owner's property, protect the department from claims of theft, and for officer safety.
To prepare the vehicle for auction.
unit7.reference: GO 702.5.1 VEHICLE INVENTORY: The purpose of the inventory is to protect the owner's property, protect the department against claims of lost or stolen property, and to protect department members and others from any danger associated with the vehicle.

unit7.question: When can a hold be placed on a towed vehicle?
unit7.answer: When the vehicle is evidence of a crime.
options: If the owner has outstanding parking tickets.
If the vehicle is over 10 years old.
When the vehicle is evidence of a crime.
If the driver was uncooperative.
unit7.reference: GO 702.6 HOLDS ON TOWED VEHICLES: A hold may be placed on a towed vehicle in any of the following circumstances: ... (a) The vehicle is evidence of a crime.

unit7.question: What is a Drug Recognition Expert (DRE)?
unit7.answer: A person certified to recognize impairment in drivers under the influence of drugs other than, or in addition to, alcohol.
options: Any officer who has made a DWI arrest.
A forensic scientist from a crime lab.
A person certified to recognize impairment in drivers under the influence of drugs other than, or in addition to, alcohol.
A medical doctor specializing in toxicology.
unit7.reference: GO 703.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) - A person who is certified by the International Association of Chiefs of Police as having met all requirements of the Drug Evaluation and Classification Program.

unit7.question: When can an officer require a person to submit to a Standardized Field Sobriety Test (SFST)?
unit7.answer: When the officer has reasonable suspicion that the person is driving while impaired.
options: For any traffic stop.
Only after an arrest has been made.
When the officer has reasonable suspicion that the person is driving while impaired.
Only if the person appears to be under 21.
unit7.reference: GO 703.4 FIELD SOBRIETY TESTS: When an officer has reasonable suspicion that a person is driving while impaired, the officer can require the person to submit to one or all of the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFST).

unit7.question: Are the results of a Preliminary Breath Test (PBT) admissible in court?
unit7.answer: No, they are not admissible in court.
options: Yes, they are the primary evidence in a DWI case.
No, they are not admissible in court.
Yes, but only if the suspect consents in writing.
Only if the reading is over .08.
unit7.reference: GO 703.4.1 PRELIMINARY BREATH TEST: The results of a PBT are not admissible in court; therefore, they are only used to assist an officer in determining whether there is probable cause to arrest.

unit7.question: What is the 'implied consent' law?
unit7.answer: Any person arrested for an offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated is deemed to have consented to a breath or blood test.
options: Drivers must consent to a vehicle search during a traffic stop.
Drivers imply consent to follow all traffic laws by getting a license.
Any person arrested for an offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated is deemed to have consented to a breath or blood test.
A person implies consent to be video recorded during a stop.
unit7.reference: GO 703.5 IMPLIED CONSENT: Any person who is arrested for an offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while operating a motor vehicle in a public place, or a watercraft, while intoxicated is deemed to have consented to the taking of one or more specimens of breath or blood for analysis...

unit7.question: Under which circumstance is a blood draw MANDATORY for a DWI suspect?
unit7.answer: When the suspect was involved in a collision where a person has died or suffers serious bodily injury.
options: For all DWI arrests.
If the suspect refuses a breath test.
When the suspect was involved in a collision where a person has died or suffers serious bodily injury.
If the suspect has a prior traffic citation.
unit7.reference: GO 703.5.2 MANDATORY BLOOD DRAW: If a person is arrested for DWI and refuses to submit to a breath or blood test, the officer shall require the taking of a blood specimen if the officer reasonably believes that a collision occurred as a direct result of the offense and a person has died or suffers serious bodily injury (Tex. Transp. Code § 724.012).

unit7.question: What is the required observation period before administering an evidentiary breath test?
unit7.answer: At least 15 minutes.
options: 5 minutes.
10 minutes.
At least 15 minutes.
30 minutes.
unit7.reference: GO 703.6.1 OBSERVATION PERIOD: The certified operator shall observe the suspect for a period of at least 15 minutes before administering an evidentiary breath test.

unit7.question: What is the policy for video recording DWI stops?
unit7.answer: All DWI stops, from the time of the vehicle stop until the arrest is complete, should be video recorded.
options: Only the field sobriety tests need to be recorded.
Recording is at the officer's discretion.
All DWI stops, from the time of the vehicle stop until the arrest is complete, should be video recorded.
Recording is only required if the suspect consents.
unit7.reference: GO 703.7 DWI VIDEO RECORDING: All DWI stops, from the time of the vehicle stop until the arrest is complete, should be video recorded.

unit7.question: When can an officer make a custody arrest for a traffic violation?
unit7.answer: When the violator refuses to sign the citation.
options: For any moving violation.
If the officer feels disrespected.
When the violator refuses to sign the citation.
If the violation occurs in a school zone.
unit7.reference: GO 704.3.1 GROUNDS FOR ARREST: State law permits a custody arrest for any traffic violation except speeding or open container. An officer may make a custody arrest of a person who has committed a traffic violation under the following circumstances: ... (b) The violator refuses to sign the citation.

unit7.question: Who must approve the voiding of a traffic citation?

options: The issuing officer.
The records clerk.
A supervisor.
The Chief of Police.

unit7.question: What is the primary responsibility of an officer encountering a disabled vehicle?
unit7.answer: To render aid and protect the occupants and other motorists.

To call for a tow truck immediately.
To render aid and protect the occupants and other motorists.
To complete a full incident report.
unit7.reference: GO 705.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to render aid and protect the occupants of disabled vehicles and other motorists.

unit7.question: When directing traffic, what must an officer wear to enhance visibility?

High-visibility clothing, such as a reflective vest.

Yes, for a scheduled break.
Not until properly relieved.
Yes, if their shift is over.
unit7.reference: GO 706.4 UNATTENDED TRAFFIC POSTS: Officers assigned to traffic posts should not leave their posts unattended until properly relieved.

unit7.question: What is a legitimate reason for a non-disabled person to be parked in a disabled parking space?
unit7.answer: There are no legitimate reasons.

If they are waiting to pick up a disabled person.
There are no legitimate reasons.
If other parking spaces are full.
unit7.reference: GO 707.3.2 PARKING PLACARDS FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES: Any vehicle displaying an expired placard, a placard not issued to the operator or passenger, or no placard at all is subject to citation. There are no legitimate reasons (e.g., waiting for a disabled person) for a person who is not disabled to be parked in a disabled space.

unit7.question: What is the purpose of the Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) system?
unit7.answer: To apprehend criminals, recover stolen property, and gather evidence for investigations.

To issue automated parking tickets.
To apprehend criminals, recover stolen property, and gather evidence for investigations.
To track the movements of all citizens.
unit7.reference: GO 708.2 POLICY: The ALPR system is intended to be used by the Denton Police Department in a manner that will assist in the apprehension of criminals, the recovery of stolen property and the gathering of evidence for criminal investigations.

options: 24 hours.
One week.
One year.

Only unlocked containers can be opened.

Counting Backwards, Walk-and-Turn, and Finger Count.

unit7.question: When can a mandatory blood draw be performed on a DWI suspect?

unit7.question: During the 15-minute observation period before a breath test, what must the operator ensure?

unit7.question: What must be issued to a violator along with a traffic citation?

unit7.question: When an officer stops to assist a disabled motorist, where should the patrol car be positioned?

On the opposite side of the road.
A safe distance behind the disabled vehicle, with emergency lights activated.
Perpendicular to the disabled vehicle to block traffic.

unit7.question: What is one purpose of the ALPR system?

To monitor employee movements.
To enhance officer safety.
To enforce immigration laws.

Civilian volunteers.
Only members of this department who have been authorized and trained in its use.

unit7.question: What is the primary reason an officer would place a hold on a towed vehicle?

The vehicle has excessive damage.
The vehicle contains evidence of a crime or is itself evidence.
The vehicle is a classic or high-value car.

unit7.question: What is a key difference between a PBT and an evidentiary breath test?
unit7.answer: The PBT result is not admissible in court, while the evidentiary test is.

The PBT does not require an observation period.

unit7.question: When can an officer make a lawful custodial arrest for a traffic violation?

When the violator is unable to offer satisfactory evidence of identification.
If the vehicle is dirty.

unit7.question: What is the policy for using traffic citations to evaluate officer performance?

unit7.question: The Traffic Collision Investigation Team (TCIT) may be activated for what type of incident?

Any collision where a driver is suspected of being impaired.

unit7.question: A vehicle may be towed if its registration is expired for more than how long?

One week.

Only a promise to appear and not an admission of guilt.
Consent to a vehicle search.
unit7.reference: GO 704.3.2 CITATION ISSUANCE: The officer should be prepared to explain that the violator's signature is only a promise to appear and not an admission of guilt.

unit7.question: When can a citizen direct traffic?
unit7.answer: Only when requested and supervised by a law enforcement officer.
options: At any time during a power outage.
Only when requested and supervised by a law enforcement officer.
If they are a member of a certified community patrol.
Never, under any circumstances.
unit7.reference: GO 706.5 CITIZEN DIRECTING TRAFFIC: Citizens should not be permitted to direct traffic except when requested and supervised by a law enforcement officer.

unit7.question: An ALPR 'hit' on a license plate is not, by itself, probable cause for what?
unit7.answer: To stop or arrest the driver.
options: To run the license plate in a database.
To follow the vehicle.
To stop or arrest the driver.
To alert other officers of the vehicle's location.
unit7.reference: GO 708.3 ALPR USE: An alert or 'hit' on a license plate from the ALPR system is not, by itself, probable cause to stop or arrest the driver or occupants of the vehicle.

unit7.question: Who does the Traffic Supervisor coordinate with to identify and correct traffic hazards?
unit7.answer: The Traffic Engineer.
options: The City Council.
The Texas Department of Transportation.
The Traffic Engineer.
The Patrol Bureau Chief.
unit7.reference: GO 700.8 TRAFFIC ENGINEERING: The Traffic Supervisor will coordinate with the Traffic Engineer to assist in identifying and correcting traffic hazards.

unit7.question: What is the policy for using physical force to remove a CR-2 report from a driver?
unit7.answer: It shall not be used.
options: It is authorized if the driver is uncooperative.
It shall not be used.
It requires supervisor approval.
It is a recommended tactic.
unit7.reference: GO 701.5.1 DRIVER'S CRASH REPORT (FORM CR-2): Physical force shall not be used to take possession of a CR-2 from a driver.

unit7.question: A vehicle inventory should be conducted whenever a vehicle is lawfully impounded by a member of the department, except when what condition applies?
unit7.answer: The vehicle is being preserved as a crime scene.
options: The owner objects.
The vehicle is being preserved as a crime scene.
It is raining.
The inventory would take too long.
unit7.reference: GO 702.5.1 VEHICLE INVENTORY: An inventory of the contents of a vehicle should be conducted whenever a vehicle is lawfully impounded by a member of this department, unless the vehicle is being preserved as a crime scene.

unit7.question: What should a certified breath test operator do if they have reasonable suspicion a DWI suspect has a foreign substance in their mouth?
unit7.answer: Request the suspect to remove it.
options: Immediately terminate the test.
Proceed with the test anyway.
Request the suspect to remove it.
Use force to remove the substance.
unit7.reference: GO 703.6.1 OBSERVATION PERIOD: If the certified operator has reasonable suspicion that the suspect has a foreign substance in their mouth, the operator should request the suspect to remove it.

unit7.question: When can a juvenile be arrested for a traffic offense?
unit7.answer: Only for offenses where a court appearance is required, or upon order of the court.
options: For any traffic offense.
Only for offenses where a court appearance is required, or upon order of the court.
Never, they can only be issued a citation.
Only if their parent or guardian is present.
unit7.reference: GO 704.6 JUVENILES: A juvenile may only be arrested for a traffic offense for which a court appearance is required (Tex. Fam. Code § 52.01) or upon order of the court.

unit7.question: When an officer uses hand signals to direct traffic, they should be what?
unit7.answer: Clear, uniform and deliberate.
options: Rapid and energetic.
Accompanied by shouting.
Clear, uniform and deliberate.
Subtle to avoid confusing drivers.
unit7.reference: GO 706.3(e): The following guidelines should be followed whenever an officer is assigned to direct traffic: ... (e) Hand signals should be clear, uniform and deliberate.

unit7.question: What is the policy for using ALPR data to monitor individuals engaged in First Amendment-protected speech?
unit7.answer: It is prohibited.
options: It is allowed with a supervisor's approval.
It is a primary use of the system.
It is prohibited.
It is only allowed for large protests.
unit7.reference: GO 708.3 ALPR USE: ALPR data shall not be used to monitor individuals engaged in First Amendment-protected speech, association or religion.

unit7.question: What is the purpose of the Traffic Collision Investigation Team (TCIT)?
unit7.answer: To investigate traffic collisions involving fatalities or serious bodily injuries.
options: To investigate all traffic collisions.
To direct traffic at collision scenes.
To investigate traffic collisions involving fatalities or serious bodily injuries.
To educate the public on traffic safety.
unit7.reference: GO 701.7 TRAFFIC COLLISION INVESTIGATION TEAM: This department has established a Traffic Collision Investigation Team (TCIT) to respond to and investigate traffic collisions involving fatalities or serious bodily injuries.

unit7.question: If a vehicle is towed because the driver was arrested, where should it be towed?
unit7.answer: To the designated tow company's storage facility.
options: To the police station.
To the driver's home.
To the designated tow company's storage facility.
To the nearest public parking lot.
unit7.reference: GO 702.3.1(c): Circumstances that authorize towing: ... (c) The driver of the vehicle has been arrested.

unit7.question: If a DWI suspect requests to contact an attorney before taking a breath or blood test, what is the policy?
unit7.answer: The suspect has no right to consult with an attorney before deciding whether to submit to a test.
options: The officer must provide a phone for the suspect to call an attorney.
The test must be delayed until the attorney arrives.
The suspect has no right to consult with an attorney before deciding whether to submit to a test.
The request must be granted, but the suspect has a 15-minute time limit.
unit7.reference: GO 703.5.4 CONTACTING AN ATTORNEY: A person arrested for DWI has no right to consult with an attorney, either in person or by telephone, before deciding whether to submit to a breath or blood test (Tex. Transp. Code § 724.016).

unit7.question: Who must be issued a traffic citation?
unit7.answer: The person to whom the citation was issued.
options: The registered owner of the vehicle.
The person to whom the citation was issued.
Any passenger in the vehicle.
The driver's parent or guardian if they are a juvenile.
unit7.reference: GO 704.3.2 CITATION ISSUANCE: A copy of the citation shall be issued to the person to whom it was issued (Tex. Transp. Code § 543.006).

unit7.question: When can an officer authorize a 'roadblock'?
unit7.answer: When it is reasonable to believe it will be effective and with due regard for safety.
options: For any fleeing vehicle.
Only for pursuits involving violent felonies.
When it is reasonable to believe it will be effective and with due regard for safety.
Never, roadblocks are prohibited.
unit7.reference: GO 306.8 ROADBLOCKS: A supervisor may authorize the use of a roadblock when it is reasonable to believe that the roadblock will be effective, and with due regard for the safety of the public and involved members.

unit7.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the traffic function?
unit7.answer: The Traffic Supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The Traffic Supervisor.
The on-duty Lieutenant.
The City Manager.
unit7.reference: GO 700.3 TRAFFIC SUPERVISOR: The Traffic Supervisor, under the direction of the Support Bureau Chief, is responsible for the overall supervision of the traffic function.

unit7.question: What information should be given to a hit-and-run victim regarding their duties?
unit7.answer: Information regarding their duty to report the collision.
options: Advice on which body shop to use.
Information regarding their duty to report the collision.
The personal phone number of the investigating officer.
An estimated cost of repairs.
unit7.reference: GO 701.4 HIT-AND-RUN COLLISIONS: The assigned officer will also provide the victim a written statement outlining their duties as an operator of a vehicle involved in a collision.

unit7.question: When an owner requests a tow but cannot pay, what is the procedure?
unit7.answer: The vehicle will be towed at the owner's expense by the designated tow company.
options: The officer pays for the tow.
The city pays for the tow.
The vehicle cannot be towed.
The vehicle will be towed at the owner's expense by the designated tow company.
unit7.reference: GO 702.4 OWNER CONSENT TOWS: An officer may encounter situations where the owner or operator of a vehicle requests that the vehicle be towed. If the operator is unable to pay for such services, the vehicle will be towed at the owner's expense by the designated tow company.

unit7.question: What is the primary role of a Drug Recognition Expert (DRE)?
unit7.answer: To conduct an evaluation on a subject believed to be impaired by drugs.
options: To make all DWI arrests.
To conduct an evaluation on a subject believed to be impaired by drugs.
To testify in all traffic court cases.
To administer all breath tests.
unit7.reference: GO 703.9 DRUG RECOGNITION EXPERT: When available, a DRE may be requested to conduct an evaluation on a subject who is believed to be impaired by drugs other than, or in addition to, alcohol.

unit7.question: How should an officer handle multiple traffic violations by one driver?
unit7.answer: Multiple violations may be listed on a single citation form.
options: A separate citation must be issued for each violation.
The officer should only cite the most serious violation.
Multiple violations may be listed on a single citation form.
The officer should arrest the driver.
unit7.reference: GO 704.3.2 CITATION ISSUANCE: Multiple violations may be listed on a single citation form.

unit7.question: When can an officer direct traffic in a manner contrary to posted signs?
unit7.answer: Whenever it is reasonably necessary.
options: Never, signs must always be obeyed.
Whenever it is reasonably necessary.
Only during a major disaster.
Only with a supervisor's approval.
unit7.reference: GO 706.3(a): The following guidelines should be followed whenever an officer is assigned to direct traffic: (a) Officers may direct traffic in a manner contrary to posted signs whenever it is reasonably necessary.

unit7.question: How are vehicles marked for timed parking enforcement?
unit7.answer: As designated by the Traffic Supervisor.
options: With a chalk mark on the tire.
With a sticker on the window.
As designated by the Traffic Supervisor.
They are not marked, only timed visually.
unit7.reference: GO 707.3.1 TIMED PARKING: Officers assigned to parking enforcement may mark vehicles parked in timed spaces as designated by the Traffic Supervisor.

unit7.question: An ALPR system may automatically compare license plates against what?
unit7.answer: Hot lists.
options: Social media databases.
The city census.
Hot lists.
Voter registration records.
unit7.reference: GO 708.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) system - A system of one or more mobile or fixed high-speed cameras combined with optical character recognition software which automatically compares license plates against hot lists.

unit7.question: What should an officer do after a vehicle inventory is complete?
unit7.answer: Complete the appropriate inventory form.
options: Give the keys to the tow truck driver.
Complete the appropriate inventory form.
Call the owner to notify them of the inventory.
Lock the vehicle and leave it for towing.
unit7.reference: GO 702.5.1(c): The following guidelines apply to vehicle inventories: ... (c) Upon completion of the inventory, the officer should complete the appropriate inventory form.

unit7.question: If a person arrested for DWI is unconscious or otherwise incapable of refusal, what is the policy?
unit7.answer: The person is considered not to have withdrawn consent.
options: A blood sample cannot be taken.
A warrant is required to take a sample.
The person is considered not to have withdrawn consent.
Only a breath sample can be taken.
unit7.reference: GO 703.5.1(a): A person who is dead, unconscious or otherwise incapable of refusal is considered not to have withdrawn consent provided by law.

unit7.question: Can an officer issue a citation for a parking violation if the vehicle is occupied?
unit7.answer: Yes, to the operator.
options: No, the vehicle must be unoccupied.
Yes, to the operator.
No, a warning must be given first.
Yes, but only if the owner is also the operator.
unit7.reference: GO 707.3.3 CITATIONS FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS: The officer should issue a parking citation to the operator if the vehicle is occupied, or attach it to the vehicle if it is unoccupied.

unit8.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding the investigation of crimes?
unit8.answer: To investigate crimes that occur within its jurisdiction in a timely and thorough manner.
options: To investigate only felony-level crimes.
To delegate all investigations to other agencies.
To investigate crimes that occur within its jurisdiction in a timely and thorough manner.
To prioritize investigations based on media interest.
unit8.reference: GO 800.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to investigate crimes that occur within its jurisdiction in a timely and thorough manner.

unit8.question: Who is responsible for developing procedures for case management and assignment?
unit8.answer: The Investigations Bureau Chief.
options: The Chief of Police.
The on-duty Patrol Lieutenant.
The Investigations Bureau Chief.
The District Attorney.
unit8.reference: GO 800.3 CASE MANAGEMENT: The Investigations Bureau Chief is responsible for developing procedures for case management and assignment.

unit8.question: Which of the following is a key solvability factor to be considered during case screening?
unit8.answer: Whether there is a named suspect or suspect description.
options: The time of day the crime occurred.
Whether the victim has insurance.
Whether there is a named suspect or suspect description.
The monetary value of the stolen property, regardless of other factors.
unit8.reference: GO 800.4.1(b): Case screening shall include consideration of the following solvability factors: ... (b) Whether there is a named suspect or suspect description.

unit8.question: Under what circumstances may a case be closed?
unit8.answer: When all available leads have been exhausted but the case has not been cleared by other means.
options: After 30 days, regardless of the status.
If the victim becomes uncooperative.
When all available leads have been exhausted but the case has not been cleared by other means.
Only upon the conviction of a suspect.
unit8.reference: GO 800.4.3 CASE CLOSURE: A case may be closed under the following circumstances: ... (c) All available leads have been exhausted but the case has not been cleared by other means.

unit8.question: What is the policy regarding the confidentiality of case information?
unit8.answer: It is considered confidential and should not be discussed with any unauthorized person.
options: It can be shared with family members.
It is public record and can be shared freely.
It is considered confidential and should not be discussed with any unauthorized person.
It can only be discussed with other members of the same shift.
unit8.reference: GO 800.6 CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION: Information related to any case is considered confidential and should not be discussed with any unauthorized person.

unit8.question: What is a primary responsibility of the initial officer investigating a sexual assault?
unit8.answer: To secure the scene and address the immediate medical needs of the victim.
options: To obtain a full, detailed statement from the victim immediately.
To interview the suspect before speaking with the victim.
To secure the scene and address the immediate medical needs of the victim.
To notify the media about the incident.
unit8.reference: GO 801.3(a): The initial investigating officer at the scene of a reported sexual assault should, as applicable: (a) Secure the scene and address the immediate medical needs of the victim.

unit8.question: Who are sexual assault cases generally assigned to for follow-up investigation?
unit8.answer: An investigator who has received specialized training in sexual assault investigation.
options: The initial responding officer.
Any available detective.
An investigator who has received specialized training in sexual assault investigation.
A supervisor in the patrol division.
unit8.reference: GO 801.4 CASE ASSIGNMENT AND FOLLOW-UP: Sexual assault cases will generally be assigned to an investigator who has received specialized training in sexual assault investigation and interviewing techniques.

unit8.question: What is a Sexual Assault Response Team (SART)?
unit8.answer: A multidisciplinary team that collaboratively responds to sexual assault cases.
options: A team of patrol officers who respond to initial calls.
A team composed solely of medical professionals.
A multidisciplinary team that collaboratively responds to sexual assault cases.
A citizen volunteer group that supports victims.
unit8.reference: GO 801.5 SEXUAL ASSAULT RESPONSE TEAM: The Denton Police Department should participate in a Sexual Assault Response Team (SART) to ensure a multidisciplinary response to sexual assault cases.

unit8.question: Can a sexual assault victim be required to submit to a polygraph exam as a condition for proceeding with an investigation?
unit8.answer: No, this is not permitted.
options: Yes, it is a mandatory step.
Yes, but only with the victim's consent.
No, this is not permitted.
Only if the suspect passes a polygraph exam first.
unit8.reference: GO 801.7 FILING A REPORT: A victim of a sexual assault cannot be required to submit to a polygraph examination as a condition for proceeding with an investigation (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 56A.302).

unit8.question: Who is prohibited from acting as the administrator of a lineup?
unit8.answer: An investigator assigned to the case.
options: Any supervisor.
A blinded administrator.
An investigator assigned to the case.
Any officer who has not seen the suspect.
unit8.reference: GO 802.4 ADMINISTRATOR: An investigator assigned to the case shall not act as the lineup administrator.

unit8.question: What instruction must be given to an eyewitness before a lineup?
unit8.answer: That the person who committed the crime may or may not be in the lineup.
options: To pick the person who most closely resembles the suspect.
That the suspect is definitely in the lineup.
That the person who committed the crime may or may not be in the lineup.
To discuss their choice with other witnesses.
unit8.reference: GO 802.5.1(a): The following are general procedures for photo lineups and live lineups: (a) The eyewitness should be instructed that the person who committed the crime may or may not be in the lineup.

unit8.question: A photo lineup should be comprised of how many photos?
unit8.answer: At least six, including one suspect and a minimum of five fillers.
options: Exactly five photos.
At least six, including one suspect and a minimum of five fillers.
No more than four photos to avoid confusion.
As many photos as are available.
unit8.reference: GO 802.5.3 FOLDERS: The photo lineup should be comprised of at least six photos, which includes one photo of the suspect and a minimum of five fillers.

unit8.question: When is a 'showup' or field identification authorized?
unit8.answer: When a suspect matching the description is detained in close proximity in time and location to the crime.
options: At any time during an investigation.
Only after a suspect has been arrested.
When a suspect matching the description is detained in close proximity in time and location to the crime.
As a standard replacement for a photo lineup.
unit8.reference: GO 802.6 SHOWUPS: A showup is authorized when a suspect matching the description of the person who committed the crime is detained in close proximity in time and location to the crime.

unit8.question: What should be documented immediately after a showup?
unit8.answer: A verbatim statement of the witness's confidence in their identification.
options: The officer's opinion of the identification.
A verbatim statement of the witness's confidence in their identification.
Only a positive identification, not a non-identification.
The weather conditions at the time of the showup.
unit8.reference: GO 802.7 DOCUMENTATION: Immediately following the showup, the officer shall document a verbatim statement of the witness' confidence in their identification.

unit8.question: Is there a required waiting period before a person can be reported as missing?
unit8.answer: No, a report of a missing person shall be accepted without a waiting period.
options: Yes, 24 hours.
Yes, 48 hours.
No, a report of a missing person shall be accepted without a waiting period.
Yes, 72 hours, unless foul play is suspected.
unit8.reference: GO 803.3 INITIAL RESPONSE: A report of a missing person shall be accepted without a waiting period.

unit8.question: A missing person is considered 'at-risk' if what condition is met?
unit8.answer: The person is 13 years of age or younger.
options: The person is over 65.
The person is an adult who voluntarily left.
The person is 13 years of age or younger.
The person has been missing for more than 24 hours.
unit8.reference: GO 803.4.0 RISK ASSESSMENT: The responding officer should determine if the person is an at-risk missing person. At-risk includes, but is not limited to: ... (d) The person is 13 years of age or younger.

unit8.question: For an at-risk missing person, information must be entered into TCIC/NCIC within what time frame?
unit8.answer: Within two hours of receiving the report.
options: Within 12 hours.
Within 24 hours.
Within two hours of receiving the report.
By the end of the shift.
unit8.reference: GO 803.5.1 TCIC/NCIC ENTRY: Information regarding an at-risk missing person shall be entered into the Texas Crime Information Center (TCIC) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) within two hours of receiving the report (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 63.009).

unit8.question: What is the criterion for activating an Amber Alert?
unit8.answer: A law enforcement agency believes a child 17 years of age or younger has been abducted.
options: Any child reported missing by a parent.
A law enforcement agency believes a child 17 years of age or younger has been abducted.
A child who has run away from home.
Any missing person under the age of 21.
unit8.reference: GO 803.6.1 AMBER ALERT: An Amber Alert may be activated when a law enforcement agency believes a child 17 years of age or younger has been abducted.

unit8.question: A 'Silver Alert' is for a missing senior citizen who has what condition?
unit8.answer: A diagnosed impaired mental condition.
options: A physical disability.
A communicable disease.
A diagnosed impaired mental condition.
A terminal illness.
unit8.reference: GO 803.6.2 SILVER ALERT: A Silver Alert may be activated for a missing senior citizen, 65 years of age or older, who has a diagnosed impaired mental condition.

unit8.question: What is the policy for investigating vice, drugs, and organized crime?
unit8.answer: To identify and investigate these activities and enforce all applicable laws.
options: To focus only on large-scale drug trafficking.
To refer all such cases to federal agencies.
To identify and investigate these activities and enforce all applicable laws.
To conduct undercover operations only.
unit8.reference: GO 805.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to identify and investigate vice, drug and organized crime activities and to enforce all applicable laws.

unit8.question: Who must approve any undercover operation?
unit8.answer: A supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The District Attorney.
A supervisor.
The undercover officer's partner.
unit8.reference: GO 805.5 UNDERCOVER OPERATIONS: All undercover operations shall require supervisor approval.

unit8.question: A written operational plan for a 'reverse sting' operation must be approved by whom?
unit8.answer: The commander assigned to oversee the investigation.
options: The on-duty patrol sergeant.
The lead investigator.
The commander assigned to oversee the investigation.
A judge.
unit8.reference: GO 805.7 REVERSE STINGS: Any reverse sting operation shall require a written operational plan approved by the commander assigned to oversee the investigation.

unit8.question: What is 'volatile data' in the context of digital evidence?
unit8.answer: Data that is subject to being lost, changed or destroyed when power is removed from a computer or device.
options: Encrypted data.
Data stored in the cloud.
Data that is subject to being lost, changed or destroyed when power is removed from a computer or device.
Data that has been corrupted.
unit8.reference: GO 806.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Volatile data - Data that is subject to being lost, changed or destroyed when power is removed from a computer or device.

unit8.question: What should a responding officer do if they encounter a computer that is running at a crime scene?
unit8.answer: They should not turn it off, touch the keyboard, or click the mouse.
options: Immediately turn it off to preserve evidence.
Log in to see what the user was doing.
They should not turn it off, touch the keyboard, or click the mouse.
Disconnect it from the power source.
unit8.reference: GO 806.3 RESPONDING OFFICER GUIDELINES: If a computer is found to be running, officers should not turn it off, touch the keyboard or click the mouse. These actions may destroy or alter evidence.

unit8.question: How should a seized cellular phone be handled to isolate it from the network?
unit8.answer: It should be placed in airplane mode or stored in a signal-blocking container (Faraday bag).
options: The battery should be removed.
It should be turned off immediately.
It should be placed in airplane mode or stored in a signal-blocking container (Faraday bag).
It should be wrapped in aluminum foil.
unit8.reference: GO 806.4(b): When seizing cellular phones, officers should attempt to isolate the device from the network by: ... Placing the device in airplane mode... Storing it in a signal-blocking container (Faraday bag)...

unit8.question: Digital evidence should be protected from what environmental factors?
unit8.answer: Magnets, extreme temperatures, and moisture.
options: Sunlight, dust, and loud noises.
Magnets, extreme temperatures, and moisture.
Vibrations, bright lights, and airflow.
Static electricity only.
unit8.reference: GO 806.5 TRANSPORTATION AND STORAGE: To minimize the potential for loss of evidence, digital evidence should be protected from magnets, extreme temperatures and moisture.

unit8.question: When is the seizure of assets authorized?
unit8.answer: When there is probable cause to believe that the property is contraband and subject to forfeiture.
options: During any felony arrest.
Any time a large amount of cash is found.
When there is probable cause to believe that the property is contraband and subject to forfeiture.
Only with a court order.
unit8.reference: GO 807.3 SEIZURE OF ASSETS: The seizure of assets is authorized when there is probable cause to believe that the property is contraband and is subject to forfeiture.

unit8.question: Who is responsible for providing the legal notice of seizure and intended forfeiture to the owner of the property?
unit8.answer: The District Attorney's office.
options: The seizing officer.
The property custodian.
The District Attorney's office.
The Chief of Police.
unit8.reference: GO 807.4 NOTICE OF SEIZURE AND INTENDED FORFEITURE: The District Attorney's office is responsible for providing the legal notice of seizure and intended forfeiture to the owner of the property.

unit8.question: What is 'Brady Material'?
unit8.answer: Evidence that is favorable to the defendant in a criminal case, including evidence that is exculpatory or impeachment evidence.
options: Evidence that proves the defendant's guilt.
Any physical evidence collected at a crime scene.
Evidence that is favorable to the defendant in a criminal case, including evidence that is exculpatory or impeachment evidence.
Confidential informant information.
unit8.reference: GO 808.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Brady material - Evidence that is favorable to the defendant in a criminal case, including evidence that is exculpatory or impeachment evidence. This evidence is material to guilt or punishment.

unit8.question: What is the department's policy regarding the disclosure of Brady and Giglio material?
unit8.answer: To fully comply with all applicable legal and ethical obligations.
options: To disclose only what is explicitly requested by the defense.
To protect officers by withholding potentially damaging information.
To fully comply with all applicable legal and ethical obligations.
To leave the decision to the individual officer.
unit8.reference: GO 808.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to fully comply with all applicable legal and ethical obligations to provide any and all exculpatory and impeachment evidence to the prosecutor's office.

unit8.question: What is an employee's responsibility if they become aware of potential Brady/Giglio material about themself or another member?
unit8.answer: To promptly report the information to a supervisor.
options: To keep the information confidential.
To report it directly to the District Attorney.
To discuss it with the affected member first.
To promptly report the information to a supervisor.
unit8.reference: GO 808.3 EMPLOYEE RESPONSIBILITIES: Every member of this department has a duty to promptly report to a supervisor any and all potential exculpatory or impeachment information about themself or about another member of the department.

unit8.question: Who comprises the Brady/Giglio Committee?
unit8.answer: The Assistant Chief of Police, the Professional Standards Lieutenant, and the Investigations Bureau Chief.
options: The Chief of Police and two patrol sergeants.
A representative from the DA's office and two investigators.
The Assistant Chief of Police, the Professional Standards Lieutenant, and the Investigations Bureau Chief.
The City Attorney and two lieutenants.
unit8.reference: GO 808.5 BRADY/GIGLIO COMMITTEE: The Chief of Police should appoint a Brady/Giglio Committee to review allegations of potential Brady/Giglio material. The Committee should be comprised of the Assistant Chief of Police, the Professional Standards Lieutenant and the Investigations Bureau Chief.

unit8.question: If an investigator determines a case lacks sufficient solvability factors, what is the next step?
unit8.answer: The case should be documented and placed in an inactive status.
options: The case should be immediately closed and destroyed.
The case should be assigned to a new investigator.
The case should be documented and placed in an inactive status.
The case is referred to a federal agency.
unit8.reference: GO 800.4.1(c): Based upon the initial report and any preliminary investigation, if the investigator determines that a case lacks sufficient solvability factors, the case should be documented and placed in an inactive status.

unit8.question: When can a closed case be reopened?
unit8.answer: If new or additional information is received.
options: Never, once a case is closed it is permanent.
Only with a court order.
If new or additional information is received.
If the victim requests it, regardless of new information.
unit8.reference: GO 800.4.3 CASE CLOSURE: Cases that have been closed may be reopened if new or additional information is received.

unit8.question: During a sexual assault investigation, what is the policy on 'good faith' reports?
unit8.answer: All reports of sexual assault made in good faith will be thoroughly investigated.
options: Only reports with physical evidence will be investigated.
Good faith reports are investigated only if the victim is willing to testify.
All reports of sexual assault made in good faith will be thoroughly investigated.
Good faith reports are handled by a different unit.
unit8.reference: GO 801.4 CASE ASSIGNMENT AND FOLLOW-UP: All reports of sexual assault made in good faith will be thoroughly investigated.

unit8.question: What is the policy regarding using a 'blind administrator' for a lineup?
unit8.answer: A blind administrator shall be utilized whenever practicable.
options: It is prohibited.
It is optional at the administrator's discretion.
A blind administrator shall be utilized whenever practicable.
It is only required for live lineups.
unit8.reference: GO 802.4 ADMINISTRATOR: Whenever practicable, a blind administrator shall be utilized.

unit8.question: What is the purpose of using fillers in a lineup?
unit8.answer: To ensure the lineup is not unduly suggestive.
options: To confuse the witness.
To test the witness's memory.
To ensure the lineup is not unduly suggestive.
To meet a minimum number requirement only.

Wrapped in a plastic bag.

unit9.question: What should an officer do when seizing currency believed to be evidence?
unit9.answer: Request a supervisor to respond to the scene to verify the amount of currency seized.
options: Count the money alone and then seal it in an envelope.
Deposit the currency into the department's bank account.
Request a supervisor to respond to the scene to verify the amount of currency seized.
Allow the suspect to hold the currency until it can be processed.
unit9.reference: GO 904.4.1(c): When seizing currency that is believed to be evidence, the officer should request a supervisor respond to the scene to verify the amount of currency seized.

unit9.question: What must be maintained for all property and evidence?
unit9.answer: A clear and complete chain of custody.
options: A photograph of each item.
A monetary appraisal.
A clear and complete chain of custody.
A written description by the property owner.
unit9.reference: GO 904.5 CHAIN OF CUSTODY: A clear and complete chain of custody shall be maintained for all property and evidence.

unit9.question: How often should the property and evidence function be audited?
unit9.answer: At least annually by an outside agency.
options: Monthly by a department supervisor.
Every five years.
At least annually by an outside agency.
Only when a discrepancy is found.
unit9.reference: GO 904.6.2 AUDITS: The property and evidence function shall be audited at least annually by an outside agency.

unit9.question: When can property being held as evidence be disposed of?
unit9.answer: Upon written authorization from the appropriate prosecutor's office.
options: After 90 days, automatically.
Upon the verbal order of the investigating officer.
Upon written authorization from the appropriate prosecutor's office.
Once the property owner requests its return.
unit9.reference: GO 904.8 DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY: Evidence shall not be disposed of without the written authorization of the appropriate prosecutor's office.

unit9.question: What must an officer do before executing a warrant?
unit9.answer: Confirm that the warrant is valid and still active.
options: Notify the media.
Confirm that the warrant is valid and still active.
Obtain permission from a supervisor.
Wait until after midnight.
unit9.reference: GO 905.3 WARRANT CONFIRMATION: Officers must confirm that the warrant is valid and still active prior to taking any action on the warrant.

unit9.question: What is the 'knock-and-announce' requirement for warrant service?
unit9.answer: Officers must knock and announce their identity and purpose before making a forced entry.
options: It is an optional courtesy.
It only applies to misdemeanor warrants.
Officers must knock and announce their identity and purpose before making a forced entry.
It is only required during daytime hours.
unit9.reference: GO 905.4.1 KNOCK AND ANNOUNCE: In order to safely execute a search warrant where entry must be forced, officers are generally required to first knock and announce their identity and purpose.

unit9.question: Is it permissible to use a personal communication device (PCD) while driving Code 3?
unit9.answer: No, it is prohibited unless the device is operating in a hands-free manner.
options: Yes, for any reason.
No, it is prohibited unless the device is operating in a hands-free manner.
Yes, but only for official department business.
Only if the officer is a passenger.
unit9.reference: GO 906.3 PROHIBITED USE: An employee shall not use a PCD, whether department-issued or personal, while operating a motor vehicle during a pursuit, a Code-3 response or when engaged in crowd control unless the device is operating in a hands-free manner...

unit9.question: Can an officer use a personal cell phone to photograph a crime scene?
unit9.answer: No, unless exigent circumstances exist and a department device is not available.
options: Yes, it is the preferred method.
No, under any circumstances.
No, unless exigent circumstances exist and a department device is not available.
Yes, but only for minor crime scenes.
unit9.reference: GO 906.4 PHOTOGRAPHY AND RECORDING: An employee shall not use a personal communication device to photograph or record any scene, person or event in an official capacity unless exigent circumstances exist and a department-issued device is not readily available.

unit9.question: What is the policy for sex offenders who work or attend school in Denton but live elsewhere?
unit9.answer: They are required to register with the Denton Police Department.
options: They only need to register where they live.
They are exempt from registering in Denton.
They are required to register with the Denton Police Department.
They must report to the department on a weekly basis.
unit9.reference: GO 907.3 REGISTRATION: Any person who is required by law to register as a sex offender and who resides in, is employed in, or attends school in the City of Denton, is required to register with the Denton Police Department.

unit9.question: How often must the address of a registered sex offender be verified?
unit9.answer: Annually for most offenders, and every 90 days for sexually violent predators.
options: Monthly for all offenders.
Only when they first register.
Annually for most offenders, and every 90 days for sexually violent predators.
Every five years.
unit9.reference: GO 907.4 VERIFICATION: The Denton Police Department will verify the address of each registered sex offender annually... The address of a person determined to be a sexually violent predator shall be verified every 90 days.

unit9.question: What is required before a person can be used as an informant?
unit9.answer: Approval from a supervisor.
options: A full background check.
A signed contract.
Approval from a supervisor.
A polygraph examination.
unit9.reference: GO 911.3 USE OF INFORMANTS: When considering the use of an informant, officers and supervisors should consider the following: ...(e) Supervisor approval has been obtained.

unit9.question: The use of a juvenile between 15 and 17 years of age as an informant requires written consent from whom?
unit9.answer: Their parents/guardians, their attorney, the court, and the Chief of Police.
options: Only their parents or legal guardians.
Only the juvenile and their attorney.
Their parents/guardians, their attorney, the court, and the Chief of Police.
Only the Chief of Police.
unit9.reference: GO 911.3.2 JUVENILE INFORMANTS: In all cases, a juvenile 15 to 17 years of age may only be used as an informant with the written consent of each of the following: (a) The juvenile's parents or legal guardians (b) The juvenile's attorney, if any (c) The court in which the juvenile's case is being handled, if applicable (d) The Chief of Police or the authorized designee

unit9.question: What is the role of a School Resource Officer (SRO) regarding school disciplinary matters?
unit9.answer: SROs should not become involved in routine school disciplinary matters that should be handled by school officials.
options: They are the primary enforcers of all school rules.
SROs should not become involved in routine school disciplinary matters that should be handled by school officials.
They must be present for all student detentions.
They are required to make arrests for any rule violation.
unit9.reference: GO 912.4.2 LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS: SROs should not become involved in routine school disciplinary matters that should otherwise be handled by school officials.

unit9.question: Who must approve the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the police department and the school district?
unit9.answer: The Chief of Police and the superintendent of schools.
options: The Mayor and the school board president.
The City Council and the school board.
The Chief of Police and the superintendent of schools.
The SRO supervisor and the school principal.
unit9.reference: GO 912.5 MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING: The Chief of Police and the superintendent of schools shall approve and sign the MOU on behalf of the Department and the District.

unit9.question: When can a child be fingerprinted or photographed by a law enforcement officer?
unit9.answer: Only with the consent of the juvenile court or for certain violent felony offenses.
options: For any offense.
Only with the consent of the juvenile court or for certain violent felony offenses.
Any time they are taken into custody.
Only with parental consent.
unit9.reference: GO 900.6.1 FINGERPRINTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS: A child may not be fingerprinted or photographed without the consent of the juvenile court unless the child is taken into custody or referred to the juvenile court for conduct that constitutes a felony or a misdemeanor punishable by confinement in jail (Tex. Fam. Code § 58.002).

unit9.question: If two or more parties in a family violence incident have injuries, what should the officer attempt to identify?
unit9.answer: The primary physical aggressor.
options: Who started the verbal argument.
The primary physical aggressor.
Who owns the residence.
The person with the least severe injuries.
unit9.reference: GO 901.9.1 MUTUAL COMBATANTS: When two or more parties have injuries, the officer should attempt to identify the primary physical aggressor.

unit9.question: When must an officer report suspected child abuse to CPS or another agency?
unit9.answer: Within 24 hours of receiving information that a child has been or may be abused or neglected.
options: Within one week.
By the end of their shift.
Within 24 hours of receiving information that a child has been or may be abused or neglected.
After the criminal investigation is complete.
unit9.reference: GO 902.5 REPORTING TO CHILD PROTECTIVE SERVICES: An officer who receives information that a child has been or may be abused or neglected shall make a report to CPS or another appropriate agency within 24 hours (Tex. Fam. Code § 261.401).

unit9.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the property and evidence function?
unit9.answer: The Property Officer.
options: The Support Bureau Chief.
The Property Officer.
The Investigations Lieutenant.
The on-duty patrol supervisor.
unit9.reference: GO 904.3 PROPERTY OFFICER: The Property Officer is responsible for the overall supervision of the property and evidence function.

unit9.question: What is the policy for executing warrants in another Texas jurisdiction?
unit9.answer: The warrant provides the same authority to arrest as it does in the issuing jurisdiction.
options: It is not permitted.
It requires a local judge to co-sign the warrant.
The warrant provides the same authority to arrest as it does in the issuing jurisdiction.
The officer must be accompanied by an officer from the local jurisdiction.
unit9.reference: GO 905.5 EXECUTION IN OTHER JURISDICTIONS: An arrest warrant issued by any Texas magistrate may be executed anywhere in the State of Texas and provides the officer with the same authority to arrest as the warrant provides in the jurisdiction from which it was issued.

unit9.question: An employee has no expectation of privacy regarding what type of information on a personal device?
unit9.answer: Any information or communication related to department business.
options: Personal photos and text messages.
Any information or communication related to department business.
Their web Browse history.
Their contact list.
unit9.reference: GO 906.6 NO EXPECTATION OF PRIVACY: An employee has no expectation of privacy with regard to any information or communication on any personal communication device that is related to department business.

unit9.question: When may a sexual assault case be closed?
unit9.answer: Only after all leads have been exhausted and with the approval of a supervisor.
options: If the victim refuses a forensic exam.
After 30 days of inactivity.
Only after all leads have been exhausted and with the approval of a supervisor.
If the victim moves out of state.
unit9.reference: GO 801.4 CASE ASSIGNMENT AND FOLLOW-UP: A case should only be closed after all leads have been exhausted and with the approval of a supervisor.

unit9.question: What must an officer do if they learn of an outstanding warrant for a person they have detained?
unit9.answer: Confirm the warrant is active and valid before making an arrest.
options: Arrest the person immediately without confirmation.
Confirm the warrant is active and valid before making an arrest.
Issue a citation for the new offense and release them.
Let the person go and notify the issuing agency.
unit9.reference: GO 905.3 WARRANT CONFIRMATION: Officers must confirm that the warrant is valid and still active prior to taking any action on the warrant.

unit9.question: What is a 'child' defined as in the juvenile operations order?
unit9.answer: A person who is 10 years of age or older and under 17 years of age.
options: Anyone under the age of 18.
Anyone who has not yet graduated from high school.
A person who is 10 years of age or older and under 17 years of age.
A person under the age of 16.
unit9.reference: GO 900.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Child - A person who is 10 years of age or older and under 17 years of age (Tex. Fam. Code § 51.02).

unit9.question: Can an officer take temporary custody of a child without a court order?
unit9.answer: Yes, if there is probable cause that the child's life or health is in immediate danger.
options: No, a court order is always required.
Yes, for any reason if the officer feels it is necessary.
Yes, if there is probable cause that the child's life or health is in immediate danger.
Only if the child is committing a crime.
unit9.reference: GO 902.6 EMERGENCY CUSTODY: An officer may take temporary custody of a child without a court order if, upon the facts and circumstances, there is probable cause to believe that the child's life or health is in immediate danger (Tex. Fam. Code § 262.104).

unit9.question: Who must approve the release of a copy of an offense report?
unit9.answer: The Records Custodian.
options: The investigating officer.
The on-duty shift supervisor.
The Records Custodian.
The City Attorney.
unit9.reference: GO 903.4.2 RELEASE OF INFORMATION: The Records Custodian must approve the release of any information. When a request is made for a copy of an offense report or other information, the following considerations should apply...

unit9.question: How should drugs and narcotics be packaged for evidence?
unit9.answer: In a manner that prevents the contents from escaping.
options: In a paper bag.
In a manner that prevents the contents from escaping.
In the original packaging it was found in.
In a clear plastic Ziploc bag.
unit9.reference: GO 904.4.1(b): All drugs and narcotics should be packaged in a manner that will prevent the contents from escaping. Items should be double-bagged when practicable.

unit9.question: An officer may use a personal communication device while driving a department vehicle for what purpose?
unit9.answer: For brief communications necessary for a law enforcement purpose.
options: To make personal phone calls.
To check social media.
To watch videos.
For brief communications necessary for a law enforcement purpose.
unit9.reference: GO 906.3 PROHIBITED USE: This does not prohibit an employee from using a PCD for brief communications necessary for a law enforcement purpose, including receiving information related to a call for service or initiating a call for service.

unit9.question: What is the primary role of an SRO?
unit9.answer: To provide law enforcement and security services to the school, staff and students.
options: To teach regular academic classes.
To act as a guidance counselor.
To provide law enforcement and security services to the school, staff and students.
To handle all after-school event security.
unit9.reference: GO 912.4.1 SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICER RESPONSIBILITIES: The primary role of an SRO is to provide law enforcement and security services to the school, staff and students.

unit9.question: The use of an informant to make a controlled buy of narcotics requires what?
unit9.answer: A written plan and supervisor approval.
options: The presence of two officers.
A search warrant for the location.
A written plan and supervisor approval.
The informant to be a registered sex offender.
unit9.reference: GO 805.5 UNDERCOVER OPERATIONS: All undercover operations shall require supervisor approval. (This is implied for a controlled buy as a type of undercover operation).

unit9.question: Can a person be arrested for dating violence even if they are not married to or living with the victim?
unit9.answer: Yes, if the relationship is of a romantic or intimate nature.
options: No, it only applies to married couples.
Yes, if the relationship is of a romantic or intimate nature.
No, it only applies to people who live together.
Only if they have a child together.
unit9.reference: GO 901.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Dating violence - An act by an individual that is against another individual with whom that person has or has had a dating relationship... 'Dating relationship' means a relationship between individuals who have or have had a continuing relationship of a romantic or intimate nature.

unit9.question: Who must be notified immediately upon taking a juvenile into custody?
unit9.answer: The juvenile's parent, guardian, or custodian.
options: The school principal.
The juvenile's lawyer.
The juvenile's parent, guardian, or custodian.
The District Attorney's office.
unit9.reference: GO 900.4.1 NOTIFICATION OF PARENTS: When an officer takes a juvenile into custody, the officer shall promptly notify a parent, guardian or custodian of the juvenile (Tex. Fam. Code § 52.02).

unit9.question: When can an officer seize property believed to be abandoned?
unit9.answer: When the person in control has voluntarily discarded, left behind, or otherwise relinquished their interest in the property.
options: If it has been left unattended for more than one hour.
If it is found in a public place.
When the person in control has voluntarily discarded, left behind, or otherwise relinquished their interest in the property.
Any time property is found without an owner present.
unit9.reference: GO 904.4.2 FOUND PROPERTY: Property may be seized by an officer when it has been determined that the property is lost, mislaid or abandoned. Abandoned property is property over which the person in control has voluntarily discarded, left behind or otherwise relinquished their interest in the property...

unit9.question: What information does a 'pseudonym form' protect for a victim?
unit9.answer: The victim's name, address, and phone number from being made public.
options: The victim's age and gender.
The details of the offense.
The victim's name, address, and phone number from being made public.
The identity of the suspect.
unit9.reference: GO 808.1: A victim of a sex offense may elect to use a pseudonym to be used in all public files and records concerning the offense (Tex. Code of Crim. Pro. art. 57.02).

unit9.question: An arrest warrant for a felony remains in effect for how long?
unit9.answer: Until it is served or withdrawn by a magistrate.
options: One year.
Seven years.
Until it is served or withdrawn by a magistrate.
90 days.
unit9.reference: GO 905.3 WARRANT CONFIRMATION: Officers must confirm that the warrant is valid and still active prior to taking any action on the warrant.

unit9.question: If an officer's personal device containing department business is lost or stolen, what must they do?
unit9.answer: Immediately report it to their supervisor.
options: Attempt to locate it themselves first.
Report it to their cell phone provider.
Immediately report it to their supervisor.
Wait 24 hours to see if it turns up.
unit9.reference: GO 906.7 LOST, STOLEN OR COMPROMISED DEVICE: If an employee's personal communication device containing information related to department business is lost, stolen or otherwise compromised, the employee shall immediately report the incident to their supervisor.

unit9.question: What is required before an officer can conduct a 'strip search'?
unit9.answer: Reasonable suspicion that the person is concealing a weapon, contraband or evidence and written authorization from a Lieutenant.
options: Probable cause and a search warrant.
Reasonable suspicion that the person is concealing a weapon, contraband or evidence and written authorization from a Lieutenant.
The person's verbal consent.
It can be done for any felony arrest.
unit9.reference: GO 1202.4.1(a): A strip search may be conducted only upon reasonable suspicion that the person in custody is concealing a weapon, contraband or other evidence. ... Written authorization from the on-duty Lieutenant shall be obtained prior to the strip search.

unit9.question: In a family violence case, when might an officer make a report to Adult Protective Services?
unit9.answer: When there is reason to believe an elderly or disabled person has been abused, neglected or exploited.
options: For all family violence cases.
Only if the victim requests it.
When there is reason to believe an elderly or disabled person has been abused, neglected or exploited.
Only if the incident occurs in a nursing home.
unit9.reference: GO 901.10(d): An officer who has reason to believe that an elderly or disabled person has been abused, neglected or exploited shall make an immediate report to Adult Protective Services...

unit9.question: How should a preliminary child abuse investigation be conducted?
unit9.answer: In a sensitive and professional manner.
options: By interviewing the child in front of their parents.
Using an accusatory tone with the parents.
In a sensitive and professional manner.
By promising the child rewards for information.
unit9.reference: GO 902.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to investigate all reports of child abuse or neglect in a thorough and professional manner...

unit9.question: How long must records related to traffic citations be retained?
unit9.answer: Five years.
options: One year.
Three years.
Five years.
Ten years.
unit9.reference: GO 903.8 RECORDS RETENTION SCHEDULE: Traffic citations... RETENTION: 5 YEARS

unit9.question: When can property that is no longer needed as evidence be converted for department use?
unit9.answer: When it is unclaimed and authorized by a court order.
options: Any time the department needs it.
Only if it is a vehicle.
When it is unclaimed and authorized by a court order.
Never, it must be destroyed or sold.
unit9.reference: GO 904.8 DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY: (e) Lawfully seized property that is not evidence in a criminal investigation and is unclaimed may be converted for department use upon court order.

unit9.question: What does a 'no-knock' warrant allow officers to do?
unit9.answer: Forgo the knock-and-announce requirement due to specific exigent circumstances.
options: Enter any house without a warrant.
Forgo the knock-and-announce requirement due to specific exigent circumstances.
Use explosives to breach a door.
Conduct a search at any time of day or night.
unit9.reference: GO 905.4.1 KNOCK AND ANNOUNCE: An officer may forgo the knock-and-announce requirement if, at the time of the entry, they have a reasonable suspicion that knocking and announcing their presence... would be dangerous or futile...

unit9.question: When must an SRO read Miranda rights to a student?
unit9.answer: When the student is in custody and being interrogated about criminal activity.
options: Any time they speak to a student.
Only for school rule violations.
When the student is in custody and being interrogated about criminal activity.
Only if the student's parents are present.
unit9.reference: GO 912.4.2 LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS: An SRO shall read Miranda rights to a student when the student is in custody and is being interrogated about criminal activity.

unit9.question: What is the policy regarding audio recording interviews with suspects?
unit9.answer: It is required for all custodial interrogations conducted at a department facility.
options: It is optional.
It is only required for felony suspects.
It is required for all custodial interrogations conducted at a department facility.
It is only required if the suspect consents.
unit9.reference: GO 800.7 INTERVIEWS AND INTERROGATIONS: An audio and video recording shall be made of any custodial interrogation of a suspect that occurs at a department facility.

unit9.question: If an officer takes custody of a child, what is the required procedure?
unit9.answer: The officer must promptly take the child to a designated juvenile processing office.
options: Take the child to the adult jail for processing.
Transport the child in a marked patrol car with lights and siren.
The officer must promptly take the child to a designated juvenile processing office.
Have the child wait in the patrol car while the officer completes the investigation.
unit9.reference: GO 900.4.2 TRANSPORTATION AND PROCESSING: An officer who takes a child into custody shall promptly take the child to the juvenile processing office designated by the juvenile board...

unit9.question: When should an officer make an arrest in a family violence case where both parties claim to be victims?
unit9.answer: The officer should attempt to identify and arrest only the primary physical aggressor.
options: Arrest both parties.
Arrest neither party and refer them to counseling.
Arrest the male party.
The officer should attempt to identify and arrest only the primary physical aggressor.
unit9.reference: GO 901.9.1 MUTUAL COMBATANTS: When two or more parties have injuries, the officer should attempt to identify the primary physical aggressor. Officers should not arrest both parties unless it is determined that both have committed a crime.

unit9.question: What is the policy for processing biological evidence?
unit9.answer: It should be submitted to the property room as soon as practicable to ensure proper storage.
options: It should be stored in the officer's vehicle until the end of shift.
It can be air-dried in the report writing room.
It should be submitted to the property room as soon as practicable to ensure proper storage.
It should be placed in a plastic bag immediately to prevent contamination.
unit9.reference: GO 904.4.1(d): Biological evidence should be properly packaged and submitted into the property room as soon as practicable to ensure proper storage.

unit9.question: An officer seeking to execute a search warrant should provide a copy to whom?
unit9.answer: The person in control of the premises.
options: The property owner, even if they are not present.
The person in control of the premises.
The officer's supervisor only.
The media.
unit9.reference: GO 905.4.3 SERVICE OF WARRANT: An officer seeking to execute a search warrant should provide a copy of the warrant and an inventory of any seized property to the person in control of the premises.

unit10.question: Who directs the overall supervision of the support services function?
unit10.answer: The Support Bureau Chief.
options: The Chief of Police.
The Patrol Bureau Chief.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The on-duty Lieutenant.
unit10.reference: GO 1000.2 POLICY: The Chief of Police, through the Support Bureau Chief, will direct the overall supervision of the support services function.

unit10.question: Which of the following is listed as a function of Support Services?
unit10.answer: Detention services.
options: SWAT team operations.
Homicide investigations.
Detention services.
Undercover narcotics buys.
unit10.reference: GO 1000.3 FUNCTIONS: The support services function provides many services that are integral to the effective operation of this department. Such services include, but are not limited to: ... (g) Detention services.

unit10.question: What is a primary purpose of the Mobile Audio/Video (MAV) system?
unit10.answer: To enhance officer safety.
options: To monitor off-duty officer activity.
To provide live video feeds for the media.
To enhance officer safety.
To replace the need for written reports.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department that mobile audio/video (MAV) systems may be used to enhance officer safety, document events, statements and evidence, and to assist with the investigation and prosecution of criminal offenses.

unit10.question: Who is responsible for the overall management of the MAV system and data?
unit10.answer: The MAV Coordinator.
options: Each individual officer.
The IT Department.
The MAV Coordinator.
The on-duty shift supervisor.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.3.1 MAV COORDINATOR: The Support Bureau Chief should designate an MAV Coordinator who is responsible for the overall management of the MAV system and data.

unit10.question: When SHALL an officer activate the MAV system?
unit10.answer: For all traffic stops.
options: Only when they anticipate a use of force.
At their own discretion.
For all traffic stops.
Only for felony-level events.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.4 ACTIVATION OF THE MAV RECORDER: Officers shall activate the MAV system for all calls for service and during any self-initiated activity. This includes, but is not limited to: (a) All traffic stops, regardless of the reason for the stop.

unit10.question: When can an officer deactivate an MAV recording of a personal conversation with other employees?
unit10.answer: When the conversation is of a personal nature and unrelated to an official incident.
options: Never, all conversations in a patrol car must be recorded.
Any time two officers are speaking.
When the conversation is of a personal nature and unrelated to an official incident.
Only with the Chief's permission.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.5 DEACTIVATION OF THE MAV RECORDER: The MAV system may be deactivated under any of the following circumstances: ... (b) The conversation is of a personal nature with other employees and is unrelated to the official incident.

unit10.question: What must an officer do at the beginning of each shift regarding the MAV system?
unit10.answer: Conduct a pre-operational inspection of the system.
options: Format the system's memory card.
Log out all other users.
Conduct a pre-operational inspection of the system.
Record a test video and delete it.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.6.1 PRE-OPERATIONAL INSPECTION: At the beginning of each shift, each officer shall conduct a pre-operational inspection of the MAV system.
