unit10.question: Who has the authority to review MAV recordings?
unit10.answer: Supervisors to ensure compliance with department policy.
options: Any member of the public, upon request.
Only the officer who made the recording.
Supervisors to ensure compliance with department policy.
The media, for news reporting purposes.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.7.2 REVIEW OF RECORDINGS: MAV recordings may be reviewed by: ... (b) A supervisor investigating a specific incident or to ensure compliance with department policy.

unit10.question: How long are MAV recordings that are not flagged as evidence retained?
unit10.answer: A minimum of 90 days.
options: 30 days.
6 months.
A minimum of 90 days.
One year.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.10 RETENTION AND RELEASE OF AUDIO AND VIDEO DATA: All MAV recordings shall be retained for a minimum of 90 days.

unit10.question: What is the policy regarding the use of Body-Worn Cameras (BWC)?
unit10.answer: To enhance transparency, accountability, and the collection of evidence.
options: They are optional for officers to wear.
They replace the need for MAV systems.
To enhance transparency, accountability, and the collection of evidence.
They are only used for training purposes.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department that body-worn cameras (BWC) may be used to enhance transparency and accountability, and to assist with the collection of evidence.

unit10.question: When should an officer activate their BWC?
unit10.answer: During any enforcement or investigative encounter between an officer and a member of the public.
options: Only when a use of force occurs.
Only when the officer feels it is necessary.
During any enforcement or investigative encounter between an officer and a member of the public.
Only after an arrest has been made.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.4 ACTIVATION OF THE BWC: Officers shall activate their BWC to record any enforcement or investigative encounter between an officer and a member of the public.

unit10.question: What should an officer do regarding BWC recording when entering a private residence?
unit10.answer: Advise the occupant that they are being recorded, and if asked, the officer may stop recording unless it is an enforcement or investigative encounter.
options: Continue recording without notifying the occupant.
Turn off the camera before entering.
Advise the occupant that they are being recorded, and if asked, the officer may stop recording unless it is an enforcement or investigative encounter.
Record only the audio in a private residence.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.5.1 PRIVATE RESIDENCE: When entering a private residence... officers should advise the occupant(s) that they are being recorded. Upon request of an adult occupant, the officer may stop recording unless the contact is an enforcement or investigative encounter...

unit10.question: How should the BWC be worn by a uniformed officer?
unit10.answer: In a conspicuous manner, typically on the upper torso area.
options: Concealed under the uniform shirt.
On the duty belt.
In a conspicuous manner, typically on the upper torso area.
On the officer's hat.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.6.2 WEARING OF THE BWC: When in uniform, the BWC should be worn in a conspicuous manner, typically on the upper torso area.

unit10.question: What should an officer do if their BWC is lost, stolen, or damaged?
unit10.answer: Immediately report it to their supervisor.
options: Attempt to repair it themselves.
Wait until the end of the shift to report it.
Immediately report it to their supervisor.
Purchase a replacement out of pocket.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.6.1 PRE-OPERATIONAL INSPECTION: Any BWC that is lost, stolen, damaged or not working properly shall be immediately reported to the officer's supervisor.

unit10.question: What is a prohibited use of the Mobile Data Computer (MDC) system?
unit10.answer: Accessing personal social networking sites.
options: Running license plates.
Communicating with dispatch.
Accessing personal social networking sites.
Viewing call information.
unit10.reference: GO 1003.3.1 PROHIBITED USES: The MDC system shall not be used to: ... (d) Access personal social networking sites, unless authorized for an investigative purpose.

unit10.question: Are members permitted to play games on the MDC?
unit10.answer: No, it is strictly prohibited.
options: Yes, during breaks.
Yes, if it does not interfere with their duties.
No, it is strictly prohibited.
Only educational games are permitted.
unit10.reference: GO 1003.3.1 PROHIBITED USES: The MDC system shall not be used to: ... (g) Play any type of electronic game.

unit10.question: What must an officer do with their MDC at the end of their shift?
unit10.answer: Log off the system.
options: Leave it logged on for the next officer.
Take it home with them.
Log off the system.
Turn the vehicle off, which automatically logs it off.
unit10.reference: GO 1003.4.1 SECURITY OF THE MDC: Members shall not provide their individual passwords to any other person or permit any other person to operate the MDC under their log-on... At the conclusion of their shift, members shall log off the system.

unit10.question: Access to TLETS/Nlets and TCIC/NCIC information is restricted for what purpose?
unit10.answer: Official criminal justice purposes only.
options: Personal curiosity.
Checking on friends or family.
Official criminal justice purposes only.
Any purpose approved by a supervisor.
unit10.reference: GO 1004.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department that access to the Texas Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (TLETS)/National Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (Nlets) and the Texas Crime Information Center (TCIC)/National Crime Information Center (NCIC) information is restricted to authorized personnel for official criminal justice purposes only.

unit10.question: Who is responsible for the overall inventory and control of department property?
unit10.answer: The Quartermaster.
options: Each individual officer.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The Quartermaster.
The Chief of Police.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.3 QUARTERMASTER: The Quartermaster is responsible for the overall inventory and control of department property.

unit10.question: What is the policy for using department property?
unit10.answer: It shall be used for department purposes only.
options: It can be used for personal reasons with supervisor approval.
It can be loaned to family members.
It shall be used for department purposes only.
It can be used for secondary employment.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.4.1 GENERAL USE OF PROPERTY: All department property and equipment is intended to be used for department purposes only.

unit10.question: When is the wearing of department-issued body armor mandatory?
unit10.answer: For all uniformed officers during their tour of duty.
options: It is always optional.
Only for SWAT team members.
For all uniformed officers during their tour of duty.
Only when responding to high-risk calls.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.5.1 BODY ARMOR: The wearing of department-issued body armor is mandatory for all uniformed officers during their tour of duty.

unit10.question: Who is authorized to transport non-department members in a department vehicle?
unit10.answer: Only when it serves a law enforcement purpose, such as transporting victims, witnesses, or arrestees.
options: Officers can give rides to friends and family.
Only when it serves a law enforcement purpose, such as transporting victims, witnesses, or arrestees.
Any time, at the officer's discretion.
Only supervisors can authorize non-department member transport.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.6.3 TRANSPORTING NON-DEPARTMENT MEMBERS: Officers should not transport non-department members in a department vehicle unless such transport serves a law enforcement purpose (e.g., victims, witnesses, arrestees, ride-alongs).

unit10.question: What is the purpose of departmental inspections?
unit10.answer: To ensure compliance with department policy and the readiness of personnel and equipment.
options: To find reasons to discipline employees.
To prepare for a parade.
To ensure compliance with department policy and the readiness of personnel and equipment.
To give supervisors something to do.
unit10.reference: GO 1006.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to conduct periodic inspections to ensure compliance with department policy and to ensure the readiness of department personnel and equipment.

unit10.question: How often is a formal inspection of all personnel and functions conducted?
unit10.answer: Annually.
options: Monthly.
Quarterly.
Annually.
Every two years.
unit10.reference: GO 1006.3 ANNUAL INSPECTION: A formal inspection of all department personnel and functions shall be conducted annually under the direction of the Office of the Chief of Police.

unit10.question: What is the responsibility of a supervisor regarding inspections?
unit10.answer: To conduct continual inspections of all subordinates, equipment, and facilities under their command.
options: To inspect only their own equipment.
To delegate all inspection duties.
To conduct continual inspections of all subordinates, equipment, and facilities under their command.
To inspect only during the formal annual inspection.
unit10.reference: GO 1006.4 SUPERVISOR RESPONSIBILITY: Every supervisor is responsible for conducting continual inspections of all subordinates, equipment and facilities under their command.

unit10.question: What is a primary responsibility of the designated motor vehicle theft investigator?
unit10.answer: To serve as a liaison and resource to other members and agencies on auto theft matters.
options: To investigate all traffic accidents.
To manage the department's vehicle fleet.
To serve as a liaison and resource to other members and agencies on auto theft matters.
To conduct all vehicle pursuits.
unit10.reference: GO 1007.4 MOTOR VEHICLE THEFT INVESTIGATOR: The designated motor vehicle theft investigator will serve as a liaison and resource to other members of this department and other agencies on matters related to motor vehicle theft.

unit10.question: What should an officer who discovers a potential 'chop shop' do?
unit10.answer: Contact a supervisor and the designated motor vehicle theft investigator.
options: Enter the location and make immediate arrests.
Begin surveillance on their own.
Contact a supervisor and the designated motor vehicle theft investigator.
Ignore it unless they see an active crime.
unit10.reference: GO 1007.6 CHOP SHOPS: If an officer discovers what appears to be a chop shop, the officer should contact a supervisor and the designated motor vehicle theft investigator, if available.

unit10.question: What are volunteers prohibited from doing?
unit10.answer: Taking any action that would normally require a peace officer.
options: Answering phones.
Filing paperwork.
Taking any action that would normally require a peace officer.
Interacting with the public.
unit10.reference: GO 1009.4 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES: Volunteers shall not be permitted to perform any task or take any action that would normally require a peace officer. Volunteers shall not take any enforcement action or carry any weapon while on duty.

unit10.question: What must all applicants for the volunteer program undergo?
unit10.answer: A background check.
options: A physical fitness test.
A polygraph examination.
A background check.
A psychological evaluation.
unit10.reference: GO 1009.5 BACKGROUND CHECKS: All applicants for the volunteer program shall undergo a background check.

unit10.question: What is the policy for investigating all deaths that occur within the city?
unit10.answer: To investigate them in a thorough, complete, and sensitive manner.
options: To refer all death investigations to the Medical Examiner.
To investigate only deaths that appear to be homicides.
To investigate them in a thorough, complete, and sensitive manner.
To prioritize property crimes over death investigations.
unit10.reference: GO 1010.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to investigate all deaths that occur within its jurisdiction in a thorough, complete and sensitive manner.

unit10.question: Who must be immediately notified upon the discovery of any apparent human remains?
unit10.answer: A supervisor and the Medical Examiner's Office.
options: The Chief of Police.
The local media.
A supervisor and the Medical Examiner's Office.
The Public Works department.
unit10.reference: GO 1010.3 HUMAN REMAINS: Upon the discovery of any apparent human remains, a supervisor and the Medical Examiner's Office shall be immediately notified.

unit10.question: When can human remains be moved from a death scene?
unit10.answer: Only with the permission of the Medical Examiner, unless necessary to save a life.
options: At any time by the responding officer.
After photographs have been taken.
Only with the permission of the Medical Examiner, unless necessary to save a life.
After the next of kin have been notified.
unit10.reference: GO 1010.3(a): Human remains shall not be moved without the permission of the Medical Examiner unless it is necessary to determine if the person can be saved or to save the life of another.

unit10.question: What is the department's role in a fire investigation?
unit10.answer: To cooperate with the fire department and conduct the criminal investigation if arson is suspected.
options: To determine the cause and origin of all fires.
To lead all fire investigations.
To cooperate with the fire department and conduct the criminal investigation if arson is suspected.
To provide traffic control only.
unit10.reference: GO 1011.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to cooperate with the fire department in the investigation of fires.

unit10.question: Who is responsible for determining the cause and origin of a fire?
unit10.answer: The Fire Marshal's office.
options: The first responding police officer.
The police detective assigned to the case.
The Fire Marshal's office.
An independent insurance investigator.
unit10.reference: GO 1011.3 ARSON INVESTIGATIONS: In such cases, the Fire Marshal's office should be contacted to determine the cause and origin of the fire. The Denton Police Department will conduct the criminal investigation related to any suspected arson.

unit10.question: A recording from a BWC must be retained for at least 90 days, but longer if what event occurs?
unit10.answer: A complaint is filed against an officer.
options: The officer requests it.
The recording is of a routine traffic stop.
A complaint is filed against an officer.
The supervisor finds the video interesting.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.10 RETENTION AND RELEASE OF AUDIO AND VIDEO DATA: ... a recording must be retained for a longer period if: ... (b) A complaint has been filed against an officer related to the incident.

unit10.question: If a member loses or damages their ID card, what must they do?
unit10.answer: Immediately report the loss or damage to their supervisor and submit a report.
options: Wait until their annual review to request a new one.
Attempt to repair it themselves.
Immediately report the loss or damage to their supervisor and submit a report.
Continue working without it until a new one is issued.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.5.5 IDENTIFICATION CARDS: Any member who loses or damages their identification card shall immediately report the loss or damage to their supervisor and shall submit a report detailing the circumstances.

unit10.question: Who must approve a request from an outside agency to borrow department equipment?
unit10.answer: The Support Bureau Chief.
options: Any officer.
The Quartermaster.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The Chief of Police.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.4.3 LOANING EQUIPMENT: The Support Bureau Chief must approve the request from the outside agency.

unit10.question: Who may authorize the establishment of a vehicle checkpoint for DWI enforcement?
unit10.answer: The department is not authorized to conduct DWI checkpoints.
options: Any supervisor.
The Chief of Police.
The department is not authorized to conduct DWI checkpoints.
The City Council.
unit10.reference: GO 703.10 VEHICLE CHECKPOINTS: This department is not authorized to conduct DWI vehicle checkpoints.

unit10.question: What is the policy for transporting prisoners of the opposite sex?
unit10.answer: The officer should notify the dispatcher of the starting time, location, destination, and starting mileage.
options: It is prohibited.
A second officer must be present.
The officer should notify the dispatcher of the starting time, location, destination, and starting mileage.
The transport must be recorded on video.
unit10.reference: GO 1206.5 TRANSPORTING PRISONERS OF THE OPPOSITE SEX: When an officer must transport a prisoner of the opposite sex, the officer should notify the dispatcher of the starting time and location of the transport, the destination, and the starting vehicle mileage.

unit10.question: Can a person arrested for Public Intoxication be released to a responsible adult?
unit10.answer: Yes, if the person can be released into the care of an adult who agrees to assume responsibility.
options: No, they must be taken to jail.
Yes, if the person can be released into the care of an adult who agrees to assume responsibility.
Only if the responsible adult is a family member.
Only after they have been sober for four hours.
unit10.reference: GO 1201.3.1 RELEASE: A person arrested for public intoxication may be released into the care of an adult who agrees to assume responsibility for the person.

unit10.question: What is the purpose of the Chaplain Program?
unit10.answer: To provide spiritual guidance and counseling services to members of the department and their families.
options: To conduct religious services for the public.
To provide law enforcement services at religious institutions.
To provide spiritual guidance and counseling services to members of the department and their families.
To investigate crimes with a religious motivation.
unit10.reference: GO 1207.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to provide for the spiritual guidance and counseling of its members and their families through the services of a department chaplain or chaplains.

unit10.question: How often should an operational readiness inspection of TOU equipment be performed?
unit10.answer: At least monthly.
options: Weekly.
Quarterly.
At least monthly.
Annually.
unit10.reference: GO 402.5.1 EQUIPMENT INSPECTIONS: The TOU Commander shall appoint a team supervisor to perform operational readiness inspections of all TOU equipment at least monthly.

unit10.question: What is required before using a 'reverse sting' operation?
unit10.answer: A written operational plan approved by a commander.
options: Verbal approval from a supervisor.
Approval from the District Attorney.
A written operational plan approved by a commander.
A search warrant.
unit10.reference: GO 805.7 REVERSE STINGS: Any reverse sting operation shall require a written operational plan approved by the commander assigned to oversee the investigation.

unit10.question: In a death investigation, what should be done with any prescription medications found at the scene?
unit10.answer: They should be collected and listed on the property report.
options: They should be left at the scene.
They should be destroyed immediately.
They should be collected and listed on the property report.
They should be given to the next of kin.
unit10.reference: GO 1010.4(c): In all death investigations, the following should be considered: ... (c) Any prescription medications at the scene should be collected and listed on the property report.

unit10.question: The use of a volunteer requires the approval of whom?
unit10.answer: The Volunteer Coordinator and a supervisor in the area where the volunteer will be assigned.
options: The Chief of Police.
The City Manager.
The Volunteer Coordinator and a supervisor in the area where the volunteer will be assigned.
The Human Resources department.
unit10.reference: GO 1009.6 ASSIGNMENTS: The use of any volunteer requires the approval of the Volunteer Coordinator and a supervisor in the area where the volunteer will be assigned.

unit10.question: What is one example of a 'special population' addressed in the General Orders?
unit10.answer: Persons with physical and intellectual disabilities.
options: College students.
Tourists.
Persons with physical and intellectual disabilities.
City employees.
unit10.reference: Chapter 6 Title: Special Populations; GO 601: Communications with Persons with Physical and Intellectual Disabilities

unit10.question: What is the policy for releasing recordings from MAV or BWC systems?
unit10.answer: They will not be released without approval from the Chief of Police or authorized designee.
options: They are automatically released to the public after 90 days.
They can be released by any supervisor.
They will not be released without approval from the Chief of Police or authorized designee.
They are only released with a court order.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.10.1: No audio or video data from the MAV system will be released, duplicated or converted without the express approval of the Chief of Police or the authorized designee.

unit10.question: When can an officer stop recording on their BWC during an encounter?
unit10.answer: When the encounter has concluded.
options: Once an arrest is made.
When the officer feels the situation is no longer interesting.
When the encounter has concluded.
After the primary suspect has been identified.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.5 DEACTIVATION OF THE BWC: Once activated, the BWC should remain on and continue to record until the event has fully concluded.

unit10.question: Can an officer use the MDC to transmit information about a celebrity sighting?
unit10.answer: No, transmitting criminal history information for curiosity or personal reasons is prohibited.
options: Yes, if it is for officer safety.
No, transmitting criminal history information for curiosity or personal reasons is prohibited.
Yes, but only if no last name is used.
Only if the celebrity is a known felon.
unit10.reference: GO 1004.3 MISUSE OF INFORMATION: This includes, but is not limited to... Transmission of information for curiosity or personal reasons.

unit10.question: What should an officer do if they discover lost, stolen, or damaged department property?
unit10.answer: Promptly report it to their supervisor.
options: Attempt to find or fix it themselves.
Wait until the annual inspection.
Promptly report it to their supervisor.
Note it in their activity log.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.4.2 REPORTING LOSS OR DAMAGE: An employee who discovers any lost, stolen or damaged department property shall promptly report the circumstances to their supervisor.

unit10.question: Can an officer smoke in a department vehicle?
unit10.answer: No, smoking is prohibited in any department vehicle.
options: Yes, at any time.
No, smoking is prohibited in any department vehicle.
Yes, but only if no one else is in the vehicle.
Only if the vehicle is assigned to them personally.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.6.2(a): Officers shall not smoke in any department vehicle.

unit10.question: What is one purpose of a 'showup'?
unit10.answer: To promptly release innocent persons.
options: To increase the number of arrests.
To test a witness's memory under pressure.
To promptly release innocent persons.
To create probable cause for a search.
unit10.reference: GO 802.6 SHOWUPS: A showup... can be an effective tool to promptly release innocent persons.

unit10.question: What is required before property can be disposed of by destruction?
unit10.answer: Approval from the Support Bureau Chief and a court order if necessary.
options: The presence of two officers.
A video recording of the destruction.
Approval from the Support Bureau Chief and a court order if necessary.
A public notice of the intended destruction.
unit10.reference: GO 904.8.1 DESTRUCTION: The Property Officer may authorize the destruction of property that is no longer needed... With the approval of the Support Bureau Chief and court order, if necessary...

unit10.question: When can an officer make an arrest based on a warrant from another state?
unit10.answer: When the warrant has been confirmed and entered into TCIC/NCIC.
options: At any time based on a phone call from the other agency.
When the warrant has been confirmed and entered into TCIC/NCIC.
Never, the officer must wait for extradition.
Only if the person is also a Texas resident.
unit10.reference: GO 905.5 EXECUTION IN OTHER JURISDICTIONS: Officers should take appropriate enforcement action on any out-of-state warrant that has been confirmed and entered into the Texas Crime Information Center (TCIC) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC).

unit10.question: What must be done with recordings made on a personal device under exigent circumstances?
unit10.answer: They must be promptly transferred to department evidence systems.
options: They can be kept on the personal device indefinitely.
They must be promptly transferred to department evidence systems.
They should be uploaded to a personal cloud storage account.
They must be deleted after a report is written.
unit10.reference: GO 906.4 PHOTOGRAPHY AND RECORDING: Any recordings or photographs made with a personal communication device under this section shall be promptly transferred to department evidence systems and deleted from the personal device.

unit10.question: What should an officer do upon discovering a stolen vehicle?
unit10.answer: Notify a supervisor and request a check of TCIC/NCIC.
options: Immediately begin a high-speed pursuit.
Attempt to stop the vehicle without backup.
Notify a supervisor and request a check of TCIC/NCIC.
Place a tracking device on the vehicle.
unit10.reference: GO 1007.3 STOLEN VEHICLE DISCOVERY AND RECOVERY: Upon discovering a stolen vehicle, the officer should notify a supervisor and request a check of the Texas Crime Information Center (TCIC) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) to confirm the status of the vehicle.

unit10.question: Who must approve the disposition of found property?
unit10.answer: The Support Bureau Chief.
options: The finding officer.
The Property Officer.
The Support Bureau Chief.
A judge.
unit10.reference: GO 904.8.2 FOUND PROPERTY: If the owner of any found property cannot be located after a reasonable time, the Property Officer may request approval from the Support Bureau Chief to dispose of the property...

unit10.question: What is the policy for securing firearms in a department vehicle when the officer is not present?
unit10.answer: They shall be secured in a locked trunk, a locked firearms rack, or another locked container.
options: They can be left on the front seat if the doors are locked.
They must be taken with the officer.
They shall be secured in a locked trunk, a locked firearms rack, or another locked container.
They can be stored in the glove compartment.
unit10.reference: GO 1005.6.2(c): When an officer is not in the immediate presence of a department vehicle, all firearms shall be secured in a locked trunk, a locked firearms rack or another locked container.

unit10.question: During an inspection, a supervisor notes a policy violation. What should they do?
unit10.answer: Take corrective action.
options: Ignore it unless it's a safety issue.
Report it to Internal Affairs.
Take corrective action.
Wait for the annual inspection.
unit10.reference: GO 1006.4 SUPERVISOR RESPONSIBILITY: When a supervisor notes a policy violation or a deficiency, the supervisor is expected to take corrective action.

unit10.question: How are volunteers identified while on duty?
unit10.answer: They shall wear a department-issued identification card and approved vest or shirt.
options: They do not require special identification.
They wear the same uniform as sworn officers.
They shall wear a department-issued identification card and approved vest or shirt.
They wear a name tag with 'Volunteer' written on it.
unit10.reference: GO 1009.7 IDENTIFICATION: All volunteers shall wear a department-issued identification card that clearly identifies the person as a volunteer. Additionally, volunteers shall wear a department-approved vest or shirt.

unit10.question: In a death investigation where the identity of the deceased is unknown, what should be done?
unit10.answer: The Medical Examiner should be requested to assist with identification.
options: A photo of the deceased should be released to the media.
The case is closed until someone reports a missing person.
The Medical Examiner should be requested to assist with identification.
The remains are held indefinitely at the police department.
unit10.reference: GO 1010.5 IDENTIFICATION OF THE DECEASED: When the identity of the deceased is unknown... the Medical Examiner should be requested to assist with the identification.

unit10.question: What is the primary concern when investigating a fire scene?
unit10.answer: Life safety and scene security.
options: Determining the financial loss.
Interviewing the property owner.
Life safety and scene security.
Locating the source of ignition.
unit10.reference: GO 1011.4 SCENE SECURITY: The primary concern when investigating a fire is life safety. Once it has been determined that there is no immediate threat to life, the scene of the fire should be secured to prevent unauthorized access.

unit10.question: What must an officer do if their MAV system malfunctions during a shift?
unit10.answer: Promptly report the malfunction to a supervisor.
options: Continue working without a functioning system.
Attempt to fix it using the manual.
Promptly report the malfunction to a supervisor.
Swap vehicles with another officer.
unit10.reference: GO 1001.6.1 PRE-OPERATIONAL INSPECTION: Any system that is not functioning properly shall be promptly reported to a supervisor.

unit10.question: When can an officer review their BWC recording?
unit10.answer: Prior to making a statement about the recorded event.
options: Only after giving a statement.
Never, to ensure an untainted recollection.
Prior to making a statement about the recorded event.
Only with permission from the Chief of Police.
unit10.reference: GO 1002.7.2 REVIEW OF RECORDINGS: Officers may review their own BWC recordings prior to making a statement about the recorded event.

unit10.question: What type of messages are prohibited from being transmitted via the MDC?
unit10.answer: Messages that are derogatory, harassing, or obscene.
options: Messages related to officer safety.
Messages containing case information.
Messages that are derogatory, harassing, or obscene.
Messages requesting backup.
unit10.reference: GO 1003.3.1 PROHIBITED USES: The MDC system shall not be used to: (a) Transmit any message that is derogatory, defamatory, obscene, harassing or is otherwise inappropriate.

unit10.question: When can a hold on a towed vehicle be released?
unit10.answer: When a supervisor determines the hold is no longer necessary.
options: After 30 days.
Once the owner pays all fees.
When a supervisor determines the hold is no longer necessary.
Automatically upon case closure.
unit10.reference: GO 702.6.2 REMOVING A HOLD: Upon determining that a hold is no longer necessary, a supervisor shall ensure that the appropriate paperwork is forwarded through the proper channels to authorize the release of the hold.

unit10.question: What is one reason an officer might request a Drug Recognition Expert (DRE)?
unit10.answer: To conduct an evaluation on a subject believed to be impaired by drugs other than alcohol.
options: To administer a breath test.
To transport a prisoner to jail.
To conduct an evaluation on a subject believed to be impaired by drugs other than alcohol.
To assist with a traffic collision investigation.
unit10.reference: GO 703.9 DRUG RECOGNITION EXPERT: When available, a DRE may be requested to conduct an evaluation on a subject who is believed to be impaired by drugs other than, or in addition to, alcohol.

unit10.question: An officer assigned to direct traffic at a fixed post should not leave until when?
unit10.answer: Until properly relieved.
options: Their shift ends.
Traffic subsides.
Until properly relieved.
They feel tired.
unit10.reference: GO 706.4 UNATTENDED TRAFFIC POSTS: Officers assigned to traffic posts should not leave their posts unattended until properly relieved.

unit10.question: What is required for a vehicle to be legally parked in a disabled parking space?
unit10.answer: A valid, non-expired placard or license plate displayed on the vehicle.
options: A note on the dashboard.
The driver having a disabled passenger.
A valid, non-expired placard or license plate displayed on the vehicle.
Verbal confirmation of a disability.
unit10.reference: GO 707.3.2 PARKING PLACARDS FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES: Any vehicle displaying an expired placard, a placard not issued to the operator or passenger, or no placard at all is subject to citation.

unit11.question: What is the purpose of General Order 1100, Information Technology?
unit11.answer: To establish guidelines for the use and management of department information technology resources.
options: To outline the department's social media strategy.
To provide instructions for hardware repair.
To establish guidelines for the use and management of department information technology resources.
To list all approved software for department use.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The purpose of this general order is to establish guidelines for the use and management of department information technology resources.

unit11.question: Who is responsible for the overall management and security of the department's computer system?
unit11.answer: The IT Administrator.
options: The Chief of Police.
Each individual user.
The IT Administrator.
The Support Bureau Chief.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.3.1 IT ADMINISTRATOR: The IT Administrator is responsible for the overall management and security of the department's computer system.

unit11.question: What is one of the responsibilities of the IT Administrator?
unit11.answer: Ensuring department computer systems are protected by anti-virus and anti-malware software.
options: Approving all departmental purchases.
Conducting all new employee background checks.
Ensuring department computer systems are protected by anti-virus and anti-malware software.
Writing all department press releases.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.3.1(b): Responsibilities include, but are not limited to: ... (b) Ensuring department computer systems are protected by anti-virus and anti-malware software.

unit11.question: What is the responsibility of supervisors regarding their subordinates' use of IT resources?
unit11.answer: To ensure their subordinates are aware of and conform to department policies.
options: To monitor all of their subordinates' emails.
To know their subordinates' passwords.
To ensure their subordinates are aware of and conform to department policies.
To personally repair their subordinates' computer issues.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.3.2 SUPERVISORS: Supervisors are responsible for ensuring that their subordinates are aware of and conform to department policies for the use of information technology resources.

unit11.question: What must all system users do regarding department computers and systems?
unit11.answer: Use them in a professional, ethical, and lawful manner.
options: Use them for personal tasks during breaks.
Install any software they deem necessary for their job.
Use them in a professional, ethical, and lawful manner.
Share their login credentials with their partners.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.3.3 SYSTEM USERS: All system users are expected to use department computers and systems in a professional, ethical and lawful manner.

unit11.question: What is the department's policy regarding expectation of privacy on its computer systems?
unit11.answer: No member shall have any expectation of privacy in any communication or information created, sent or received on any department system.
options: Personal emails are considered private.
There is a full expectation of privacy.
No member shall have any expectation of privacy in any communication or information created, sent or received on any department system.
Privacy is guaranteed if a file is marked 'Personal'.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.4 NO EXPECTATION OF PRIVACY: No member shall have any expectation of privacy in any communication or information created, sent or received on any department computer system.

unit11.question: What can the department do to ensure compliance with its IT policies?
unit11.answer: Monitor any member's use of department computers and inspect any data.
options: Only conduct monitoring if a crime is suspected.
Require a warrant to inspect a member's data.
Monitor any member's use of department computers and inspect any data.
Only inspect data with the member's written consent.
unit11.reference: GO 1100.4 NO EXPECTATION OF PRIVACY: To ensure compliance with department policies, the Denton Police Department reserves the right to monitor any member's use of department computers and inspect any data created, sent or received on any department computer system.

unit11.question: What defines a 'strong password' according to this policy?
unit11.answer: A password that contains a combination of letters, numbers, and symbols.
options: Any password over six characters.
A password that is easy to remember, like a pet's name.
A password that contains a combination of letters, numbers, and symbols.
A password that is written down and stored securely.
unit11.reference: GO 1101.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Strong password - A password that contains a combination of letters, numbers and symbols.

unit11.question: What is the policy regarding passwords for department systems?
unit11.answer: Members shall use strong passwords and not share them with anyone.
options: Passwords should be simple and easy to remember.
Members should share passwords with their supervisor for backup purposes.
Members shall use strong passwords and not share them with anyone.
Passwords should be changed only if they are compromised.
unit11.reference: GO 1101.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to require members to use strong passwords for all department computer systems and applications. Members shall not share their passwords with anyone.

unit11.question: Who must approve the installation of any new software on department computers?
unit11.answer: The IT Administrator.
options: The individual user.
The user's direct supervisor.
The IT Administrator.
The Chief of Police.
unit11.reference: GO 1101.3 SOFTWARE: No software may be installed on any department computer without the prior approval of the IT Administrator.

unit11.question: What should a member do if they suspect their computer has been infected with a virus or malware?
unit11.answer: Immediately notify the IT Administrator and their supervisor.
options: Try to remove the virus themselves.
Disconnect the computer from the network and continue working.
Immediately notify the IT Administrator and their supervisor.
Wait to see if the problem resolves itself.
unit11.reference: GO 1101.4 VIRUS AND MALWARE PROTECTION: Any member who suspects that a department computer has been infected with a virus or malware shall immediately notify the IT Administrator and their supervisor.

unit11.question: What is a computer security incident?
unit11.answer: Any event that threatens the security, confidentiality, or integrity of department data or computer systems.
options: A software glitch.
Forgetting a password.
Any event that threatens the security, confidentiality, or integrity of department data or computer systems.
A power outage.
unit11.reference: GO 1101.5.1 REPORTING: A computer security incident is any event that threatens the security, confidentiality or integrity of department data or computer systems.

unit11.question: What is the policy regarding internet use on department computers?
unit11.answer: Internet use is for department business only.
options: Unlimited personal use is allowed during breaks.
Internet use is for department business only.
Personal use is allowed as long as it is not excessive.
Internet access is prohibited for all members.
unit11.reference: GO 1102.2 POLICY: Internet use on department computers is for department business only. All other use is prohibited.

unit11.question: Which of the following is a prohibited use of the department's internet access?
unit11.answer: Conducting personal or private business.
options: Accessing law enforcement databases.
Conducting research for an investigation.
Conducting personal or private business.
Communicating with other government agencies.
unit11.reference: GO 1102.3 PROHIBITED USES: Prohibited uses of the department's internet access include, but are not limited to: (a) Conducting personal or private business.

unit11.question: Is viewing or downloading obscene or sexually explicit material a prohibited use of the department's internet?
unit11.answer: Yes, unless it is for a criminal investigation with supervisor approval.
options: No, as long as it is done during a break.
Yes, unless it is for a criminal investigation with supervisor approval.
It is allowed but discouraged.
Only if it results in a virus.
unit11.reference: GO 1102.3(d): Prohibited uses of the department's internet access include... (d) Viewing, downloading or transmitting any obscene, sexually explicit or pornographic material, unless it is for the purpose of a criminal investigation and has been approved by a supervisor.

unit11.question: What is the definition of 'social media' in this policy?
unit11.answer: Any web-based service that provides a medium for members to communicate with other users.
options: Only Facebook and Twitter.
Any department-sanctioned website.
Any web-based service that provides a medium for members to communicate with other users.
Only platforms that allow video sharing.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.1.1 DEFINITIONS: Social media - Any web-based service that provides a medium for members to communicate with other users of the same service. This includes, but is not limited to, social networking sites, blogs, forums and wikis.

unit11.question: What is the department's policy on members' personal use of social media?
unit11.answer: Members are cautioned that their speech and actions on social media reflect upon the department and are subject to public scrutiny.
options: The department has no policy on personal social media use.
Members are prohibited from using social media.
Members are cautioned that their speech and actions on social media reflect upon the department and are subject to public scrutiny.
Personal use of social media is encouraged to promote the department.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.3.1 PERSONAL USE: The Denton Police Department respects the right of members to use social media as a medium of self-expression. Members are cautioned, however, that their speech and actions on social media reflect upon the department and are subject to public scrutiny.

unit11.question: What type of speech by a member is NOT protected by the First Amendment and may be subject to discipline?
unit11.answer: Speech that negatively impacts the department's ability to provide services to the public.
options: Any criticism of department policy.
Speech made as a private citizen on a matter of public concern.
Speech that negatively impacts the department's ability to provide services to the public.
All speech made while off-duty.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.3.2(a): As public employees, members' speech is not protected by the First Amendment if it is made pursuant to their official duties... Members' speech may also not be protected if it negatively impacts the efficient operation of the department or the department's ability to provide services to the public.

unit11.question: Are members permitted to post photos of themselves in uniform on their personal social media sites?
unit11.answer: Yes, but they should not post any department logos or trademarks without permission.
options: No, it is strictly prohibited.
Yes, but they should not post any department logos or trademarks without permission.
Yes, there are no restrictions.
Only if their face is obscured.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.3.3(b): Members should not post any department logos, uniforms, or other department trademarks or property on any social media without the express permission of the Chief of Police or the authorized designee.

unit11.question: Which of the following is listed as prohibited content on social media for department members?
unit11.answer: Information that could be used to compromise the safety of any person.
options: Photos from a family vacation.
A post endorsing a political candidate.
Information that could be used to compromise the safety of any person.
A link to a news article about the department.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.4 PROHIBITED CONTENT: Members are prohibited from posting any content on social media that violates any law or department policy. This includes, but is not limited to... Information that could be used to compromise the safety or security of any person, department member, or the public.

unit11.question: Who must approve any department-authorized social media page?
unit11.answer: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
options: The IT Administrator.
The Public Information Officer.
The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
Any Bureau Chief.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.5 DEPARTMENT-AUTHORIZED SOCIAL MEDIA: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee must approve any department-authorized social media page.

unit11.question: What must be included on any department-authorized social media page?
unit11.answer: A statement that the page is maintained by the department and that user posts are not endorsed.
options: A list of all members who have access to the page.
The personal phone number of the Public Information Officer.
A statement that the page is maintained by the department and that user posts are not endorsed.
A link to the city's main website.
unit11.reference: GO 1103.5(b): Any department-authorized social media page shall include: ... (b) A statement that the page is maintained by the department and that any user posts do not necessarily reflect the opinions or policies of the department.

unit11.question: Who is responsible for appointing a Public Information Officer (PIO)?
unit11.answer: The Chief of Police.
options: The City Manager.
The Public Information Officer (PIO).
The Chief of Police.
The Mayor.
unit11.reference: GO 310.4 PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICER: The Chief of Police is responsible for appointing a Public Information Officer (PIO) who is responsible for the overall supervision of the public information function.

unit11.question: What is the policy regarding releasing information on a case under investigation?
unit11.answer: Information will not be released if it could reasonably be expected to interfere with the investigation.
options: All information is released to ensure transparency.
Only the suspect's name can be released.
Information will not be released if it could reasonably be expected to interfere with the investigation.
Information can only be released after a conviction.
unit11.reference: GO 310.5.1 RELEASE OF INFORMATION: The Denton Police Department will not release information related to a case under investigation if the release could reasonably be expected to interfere with the detection, investigation or prosecution of a crime.

unit11.question: Can the home address of a peace officer be released to the public?
unit11.answer: No, it is confidential and not subject to disclosure.
options: Yes, upon request.
No, it is confidential and not subject to disclosure.
Only if the officer consents.
Only to other law enforcement agencies.
unit11.reference: GO 310.5.1(a)1.: Certain information maintained by this department is confidential by law and is not subject to release to the public. Such information includes, but is not limited to: The home address, home telephone number... of a peace officer.

unit11.question: What is the policy for responding to media inquiries at the scene of an incident?
unit11.answer: Members should refer media inquiries to a supervisor, the Incident Commander, or the PIO.
options: Any officer can give a full statement to the media.
Officers should provide a 'no comment' response.
Members should refer media inquiries to a supervisor, the Incident Commander, or the PIO.
Officers are prohibited from speaking to the media.
unit11.reference: GO 310.6 MEDIA RELATIONS: Members of the media at the scene of an incident should be referred to a supervisor, the Incident Commander or the PIO.

unit11.question: Who must approve the release of a photograph of a suspect in custody?
unit11.answer: The on-duty shift commander or a supervisor from the Investigations Bureau.
options: The arresting officer.
The PIO.
The on-duty shift commander or a supervisor from the Investigations Bureau.
The records clerk.
unit11.reference: GO 310.7 RELEASE OF PHOTOGRAPHS: The release of a photograph of a suspect in custody or a booking photograph requires the approval of the on-duty shift commander or a supervisor from the Investigations Bureau.

unit11.question: What is the primary mission of the Public Information Officer?
unit11.answer: To foster cooperation and mutual respect between the department and the media.
options: To limit the amount of information released to the media.
To write speeches for the Chief of Police.
To foster cooperation and mutual respect between the department and the media.
To manage the department's social media accounts.
unit11.reference: GO 310.4 PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICER: The mission of the Public Information Officer is to foster cooperation and mutual respect between the department and the media.

unit11.question: Who must approve all department press releases?
unit11.answer: The Chief of Police or a Bureau Chief.
options: The Public Information Officer.
The City's Communications Director.
The Chief of Police or a Bureau Chief.
The on-duty Lieutenant.
unit11.reference: GO 310.9 PRESS RELEASES: The Chief of Police or a Bureau Chief must approve all department press releases.

unit11.question: What should an officer do if they receive a subpoena for records?
unit11.answer: Immediately forward it to the Records Custodian.
options: Comply with the subpoena immediately.
Ignore the subpoena unless served in person.
Immediately forward it to the Records Custodian.
Contact the attorney who issued the subpoena.
unit11.reference: GO 903.4.3 SUBPOENAS: Any member who receives a subpoena requesting department records shall immediately forward the subpoena to the Records Custodian.

unit11.question: What is the purpose of the '9-1-1 for Kids' program?
unit11.answer: To educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 system.
options: To provide a separate 9-1-1 line for children.
To give tours of the dispatch center to children.
To educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 system.
To recruit future dispatchers.
unit11.reference: GO 1205.8.1 '9-1-1 FOR KIDS' PROGRAM: The '9-1-1 for Kids' program is an educational program designed to educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 emergency telephone system.

unit11.question: What is the policy regarding an officer's appearance in court?
unit11.answer: To be punctual and dress in the appropriate attire.
options: To arrive whenever is convenient.
To wear civilian clothes to be less intimidating.
To be punctual and dress in the appropriate attire.
To have another officer testify on their behalf.
unit11.reference: GO 1502.3 COURTROOM APPEARANCE AND DEMEANOR: Officers appearing in court or at any hearing as a representative of this department will be punctual and dress in the appropriate attire.

unit11.question: What should an officer do upon discovering a clandestine laboratory?
unit11.answer: Immediately exit the area, secure the scene, and request specialized assistance.
options: Attempt to dismantle the lab.
Collect samples of the chemicals for evidence.
Immediately exit the area, secure the scene, and request specialized assistance.
Ventilate the area by opening windows.
unit11.reference: GO 805.9 CLANDESTINE LABORATORIES: Officers who discover a clandestine laboratory should immediately exit the area and secure the scene. Officers should not touch or handle any of the chemicals or equipment. Specialized assistance should be requested to handle the processing and cleanup of the scene.

unit11.question: What is the purpose of the Ride-Along Program?
unit11.answer: To provide an opportunity for citizens to observe law enforcement activities and foster positive community relations.
options: To provide extra security for patrol officers.
To recruit new officers.
To provide an opportunity for citizens to observe law enforcement activities and foster positive community relations.
To allow citizens to assist in law enforcement duties.
unit11.reference: GO 1208.2 POLICY: The Ride-Along Program provides an opportunity for citizens to observe law enforcement activities and is intended to foster positive community relations.

unit11.question: What is the minimum age for a person to participate in the Ride-Along Program?
unit11.answer: 18 years of age.
options: 16 years of age.
21 years of age.
18 years of age.
There is no minimum age.
unit11.reference: GO 1208.4.1 APPLICANT REQUIREMENTS: Applicants for the Ride-Along Program must be at least 18 years of age.

unit11.question: Who must approve a ride-along request?
unit11.answer: The on-duty shift commander.
options: The officer the person will be riding with.
The Chief of Police.
The on-duty shift commander.
The Records Division.
unit11.reference: GO 1208.4.2 APPROVAL: All ride-along requests must be approved by the on-duty shift commander.

unit11.question: What must a participant in the Ride-Along program do before their ride-along?
unit11.answer: Sign a waiver of liability.
options: Undergo a physical fitness test.
Sign a waiver of liability.
Provide their own body armor.
Pay a participation fee.
unit11.reference: GO 1208.5 WAIVER: All participants in the Ride-Along Program must sign a waiver of liability prior to their ride-along.

unit11.question: What can an officer do if a ride-along participant's presence would jeopardize safety?
unit11.answer: The officer may terminate the ride-along or relocate the participant to a safe location.
options: Continue with the call and have the participant wait in the car.
Allow the participant to assist in the call.
The officer may terminate the ride-along or relocate the participant to a safe location.
The officer must terminate the ride-along and return to the station.
unit11.reference: GO 1208.6 PARTICIPANT CONDUCT: If the officer determines that the participant's presence would jeopardize the safety of the officer, the participant or the public, the officer may terminate the ride-along or relocate the participant to a safe location.

unit11.question: What is the policy for using the Mobile Command Post (MCP)?
unit11.answer: To provide an on-scene command and communications center for major incidents and planned events.
options: To use as a secondary booking facility.
To provide transportation for large numbers of officers.
To provide an on-scene command and communications center for major incidents and planned events.
To serve as a mobile office for the Chief of Police.
unit11.reference: GO 403.5(b): When appropriate, a supervisor should: ... (b) Establish a command post. This may include requesting the response of the Mobile Command Post (MCP).

unit11.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the Records function?
unit11.answer: The Records Custodian.
options: The Support Bureau Chief.
The Records Custodian.
The IT Administrator.
The Administrative Lieutenant.
unit11.reference: GO 903.3 RECORDS CUSTODIAN: The Records Custodian is responsible for the overall supervision of the Records function.

unit11.question: When can an officer seize property under the plain view doctrine?
unit11.answer: When the officer is lawfully present and the item is immediately apparent as contraband or evidence.
options: Any time an officer sees something suspicious.
Only if they have a search warrant for the premises.
When the officer is lawfully present and the item is immediately apparent as contraband or evidence.
Only if the property is in a vehicle.
unit11.reference: GO 905.6 PLAIN VIEW: An officer may seize any contraband or evidence of a crime that is in plain view while executing a warrant.

unit11.question: What is the purpose of the Honor Guard?
unit11.answer: To represent the department at ceremonial functions.
options: To provide security for the Chief of Police.
To serve as a tactical entry team.
To represent the department at ceremonial functions.
To conduct all departmental inspections.
unit11.reference: GO 1504.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: This order sets forth guidelines for the Denton Police Department Honor Guard. The Honor Guard is established to represent the department at ceremonial functions.

unit11.question: Who is eligible to be a member of the Honor Guard?
unit11.answer: Any sworn or non-sworn member of the department in good standing.
options: Only sworn officers with at least 10 years of service.
Only members of the command staff.
Any sworn or non-sworn member of the department in good standing.
Only members who have received a life-saving award.
unit11.reference: GO 1504.3.1 ELIGIBILITY: Any sworn or non-sworn member of the department who is in good standing is eligible to be a member of the Honor Guard.

unit11.question: How often does the Honor Guard conduct training?
unit11.answer: At least quarterly.
options: Weekly.
Monthly.
At least quarterly.
Annually.
unit11.reference: GO 1504.4 TRAINING: The Honor Guard will conduct training at least quarterly to maintain proficiency in ceremonial duties.

unit11.question: What is the policy regarding department members accepting rewards or gratuities?
unit11.answer: Members shall not accept any reward, gift, or gratuity for the performance of their duties.
options: It is allowed if the value is less than $50.
It is allowed if it is offered by a citizen.
Members shall not accept any reward, gift, or gratuity for the performance of their duties.
It is allowed with supervisor approval.
unit11.reference: GO 1601.3.1 GRATUITIES: Members shall not, under any circumstances, solicit or accept from any person, business or organization any gift, gratuity, loan, or fee when it may be reasonably inferred that the gift is intended to influence the member in the performance of their duties or as a reward for any official action.

unit11.question: What must an officer do if they discharge a firearm, accidentally or intentionally, while on-duty?
unit11.answer: Immediately report the incident to a supervisor.
options: Only report it if someone is injured.
Wait until the end of the shift to file a report.
Immediately report the incident to a supervisor.
Have the firearm inspected before reporting it.
unit11.reference: GO 305.8 DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS: Any member who discharges a firearm, other than for training, recreational use or to euthanize an animal, shall immediately report the incident to a supervisor.

unit11.question: What is the department's policy on nepotism?
unit11.answer: A member shall not be hired, promoted or transferred to a position where they would supervise or be supervised by a relative.
options: The department encourages hiring relatives of current employees.
There is no policy on nepotism.
A member shall not be hired, promoted or transferred to a position where they would supervise or be supervised by a relative.
Relatives are allowed to supervise each other with the Chief's approval.
unit11.reference: GO 1301.7 NEPOTISM: To avoid a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest, no member shall be hired, promoted or transferred to a position where they would supervise or be supervised by a relative.

unit11.question: What is the department's policy on members testifying as an expert witness?
unit11.answer: They shall not testify as an expert witness in any case unless approved by the Chief of Police.
options: They can testify in any case they choose.
They shall not testify as an expert witness in any case unless approved by the Chief of Police.
They can only testify in civil cases.
They are encouraged to testify as expert witnesses to generate income.
unit11.reference: GO 1502.5 EXPERT WITNESS: Members shall not testify as an expert witness in any case unless approved by the Chief of Police.

unit11.question: What is the procedure for an officer who becomes aware of a hate crime?
unit11.answer: They should notify a supervisor and clearly mark all reports 'Hate Crime'.
options: Treat it as a standard offense.
They should notify a supervisor and clearly mark all reports 'Hate Crime'.
Refer the victim to a community group.
Contact the FBI directly.
unit11.reference: GO 606.4 INVESTIGATIONS: Assigned officers should... (b) All related offense or supplemental reports should be clearly marked 'Hate Crime' or 'Hate Incident' in the first line of the narrative.

unit11.question: What is one of the primary responsibilities of the Detention Services Supervisor?
unit11.answer: To ensure the overall health, safety and welfare of all persons in custody.
options: To conduct all prisoner transports.
To approve all bail amounts.
To ensure the overall health, safety and welfare of all persons in custody.
To interview all new arrestees.
unit11.reference: GO 1201.3 DETENTION SERVICES SUPERVISOR: The Detention Services Supervisor is responsible for the overall supervision of the detention services function. A primary responsibility of the Detention Services Supervisor is to ensure the overall health, safety and welfare of all persons in custody.

unit11.question: How often must a visual check be performed on a person in custody who is known to be suicidal?
unit11.answer: At least every 15 minutes.
options: Every hour.
Every 30 minutes.
At least every 15 minutes.
At the beginning and end of each shift.
unit11.reference: GO 1201.6 SUICIDE RISK: A visual check of any person in custody known to be suicidal shall be made at least every 15 minutes.

unit11.question: What is the policy for processing a person arrested on an out-of-county warrant?
unit11.answer: Detention staff shall confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if they will extradite.
options: The person must be released if the agency is more than 100 miles away.
The person can be held for a maximum of 24 hours.
Detention staff shall confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if they will extradite.
The person must be immediately transported to the issuing county.
unit11.reference: GO 1201.7 ARRESTS ON OUTSIDE WARRANTS: When a person is arrested on an out-of-county warrant, detention staff shall confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if that agency will extradite the prisoner.

unit11.question: Who can authorize a visit to a person in custody outside of normal visitation hours?
unit11.answer: The Detention Services Supervisor.
options: Any officer.
The arresting officer.
The Detention Services Supervisor.
The person's attorney.
unit11.reference: GO 1201.8 VISITATION: All visits must be approved by the Detention Services Supervisor.

unit11.question: What does PREA stand for?
unit11.answer: Prison Rape Elimination Act.
options: Property and Records Evidence Act.
Prisoner Rights and Equity Association.
Prison Rape Elimination Act.
Police Response and Enforcement Administration.
unit11.reference: GO 1203.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The purpose of this general order is to establish guidelines for the prevention, detection and response to sexual abuse and sexual harassment in accordance with the federal Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA).

unit11.question: What is the department's policy on sexual abuse and harassment in its detention facilities?
unit11.answer: It has a zero-tolerance policy.
options: It is handled on a case-by-case basis.
It is only investigated if an injury occurs.
It has a zero-tolerance policy.
It is referred to an outside agency for investigation.
unit11.reference: GO 1203.2 POLICY: The Denton Police Department has a zero-tolerance policy for sexual abuse and sexual harassment in its detention facilities.

unit11.question: Who is responsible for the overall implementation and coordination of PREA?
unit11.answer: The PREA Coordinator.
options: The Detention Services Supervisor.
The Chief of Police.
The PREA Coordinator.
The Professional Standards Lieutenant.
unit11.reference: GO 1203.3 PREA COORDINATOR: The Support Bureau Chief shall appoint a PREA Coordinator who is responsible for the overall implementation and coordination of the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA).

unit11.question: How often must PREA training be provided to all department members who have contact with persons in custody?
unit11.answer: At least every two years.
options: Annually.
Every five years.
At least every two years.
Only upon initial hiring.
unit11.reference: GO 1203.7 TRAINING: Training on PREA shall be provided to all department members who may have contact with persons in custody. This training shall be provided at least every two years.

unit12.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding its detention facility?
unit12.answer: To operate a safe, secure and humane detention facility in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.
options: To operate the most high-tech facility in the state.
To provide a rehabilitative environment for all persons in custody.
To operate a safe, secure and humane detention facility in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.
To ensure the facility generates revenue for the city.
unit12.reference: GO 1200.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to operate a safe, secure and humane detention facility in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.

unit12.question: Who is responsible for ensuring the overall health, safety, and welfare of all persons in custody?
unit12.answer: The Detention Services Supervisor.
options: The arresting officer.
The on-duty shift commander.
The Detention Services Supervisor.
Each individual detention officer.
unit12.reference: GO 1200.3 DETENTION SERVICES SUPERVISOR: The Detention Services Supervisor is responsible for the overall supervision of the detention services function. A primary responsibility of the Detention Services Supervisor is to ensure the overall health, safety and welfare of all persons in custody.

unit12.question: Under what circumstance may a person arrested for Public Intoxication be released without being taken to the jail?
unit12.answer: If they can be released into the care of a responsible adult who agrees to assume responsibility.
options: If they promise not to drink anymore.
After they have been in custody for at least four hours.
If they can be released into the care of a responsible adult who agrees to assume responsibility.
They can never be released without going to jail first.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.3.1 RELEASE: A person arrested for public intoxication may be released into the care of an adult who agrees to assume responsibility for the person.

unit12.question: What must occur before a person is placed in a detention cell?
unit12.answer: They must be screened for any medical or mental health conditions.
options: They must be provided with a meal.
They must be allowed to make a phone call.
They must be screened for any medical or mental health conditions.
They must be photographed and fingerprinted.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.4 INTAKE AND MEDICAL SCREENING: Prior to being placed in a detention cell, all persons shall be screened for any medical or mental health conditions that may require special handling or medical attention.

unit12.question: What is the procedure for handling a person's personal property during booking?
unit12.answer: All personal property will be inventoried and secured.
options: The property is placed in a bag with the person's name on it.
The person is allowed to keep their property with them in the cell.
All personal property will be inventoried and secured.
Property is immediately sent to the department's lost and found.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.5 PROPERTY AND MONEY: All personal property will be inventoried and secured. All money will be counted in the presence of the person in custody and a receipt will be provided.

unit12.question: How often must a visual check be performed on a person in custody who is identified as a suicide risk?
unit12.answer: At least every 15 minutes.
options: Every hour.
Every 30 minutes.
At least every 15 minutes.
Twice per shift.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.6 SUICIDE RISK: A visual check of any person in custody known to be suicidal shall be made at least every 15 minutes.

unit12.question: What must detention staff do when a person is arrested on an out-of-county warrant?
unit12.answer: Confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if they will extradite.
options: Immediately release the person if the agency is over 100 miles away.
Hold the person for a maximum of 24 hours.
Confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if they will extradite.
Require the person to post a local bond.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.7 ARRESTS ON OUTSIDE WARRANTS: When a person is arrested on an out-of-county warrant, detention staff shall confirm the warrant with the issuing agency and determine if that agency will extradite the prisoner.

unit12.question: Who must approve a personal visit to a person in custody?
unit12.answer: The Detention Services Supervisor.
options: The arresting officer.
Any detention officer.
The Detention Services Supervisor.
The on-duty patrol lieutenant.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.8.2 PERSONAL VISITS: All personal visits must be approved by the Detention Services Supervisor.

unit12.question: When is a person in custody permitted to make telephone calls?
unit12.answer: After the booking process is complete.
options: Immediately upon arrival at the detention facility.
Only after they have seen a magistrate.
After the booking process is complete.
They are not permitted to make calls.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.10 TELEPHONE ACCESS: A person in custody may be permitted to make a reasonable number of telephone calls after the booking process is complete.

unit12.question: What is the minimum type of search to be conducted on all persons being placed in a detention cell?
unit12.answer: A pat-down search.
options: A strip search.
A visual body cavity search.
A pat-down search.
No search is required if they were searched in the field.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.3 SEARCHES: All persons being placed in a detention cell will be subject to, at a minimum, a pat-down search.

unit12.question: When can a strip search be conducted?
unit12.answer: Upon reasonable suspicion the person is concealing a weapon, contraband or evidence.
options: For any felony arrest.
Upon the person's consent.
Upon reasonable suspicion the person is concealing a weapon, contraband or evidence.
As a routine part of the booking process.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.4.1 STRIP SEARCHES: A strip search may be conducted only upon reasonable suspicion that the person in custody is concealing a weapon, contraband or other evidence.

unit12.question: Who must provide written authorization for a strip search?
unit12.answer: The on-duty Lieutenant.
options: The arresting officer.
The Detention Services Supervisor.
The on-duty Lieutenant.
The Chief of Police.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.4.1(a): Strip searches at Denton Police Department facilities shall be conducted as follows: (a) Written authorization from the on-duty Lieutenant shall be obtained prior to the strip search.

unit12.question: Who may conduct a body cavity search?
unit12.answer: Only a qualified medical professional.
options: Any two officers of the same sex.
A supervisor.
Only a qualified medical professional.
A specially trained detention officer.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.5 BODY CAVITY SEARCHES: A body cavity search may only be conducted by a qualified medical professional.

unit12.question: What is the department's stance on sexual abuse and harassment in its detention facilities?
unit12.answer: A zero-tolerance policy.
options: It is investigated by an outside agency.
Minor incidents are handled informally.
A zero-tolerance policy.
It is addressed only if a formal lawsuit is filed.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.2 POLICY: The Denton Police Department has a zero-tolerance policy for sexual abuse and sexual harassment in its detention facilities.

unit12.question: Who is responsible for the overall implementation and coordination of the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA)?
unit12.answer: The PREA Coordinator.
options: The Detention Services Supervisor.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The PREA Coordinator.
The Professional Standards Lieutenant.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.3 PREA COORDINATOR: The Support Bureau Chief shall appoint a PREA Coordinator who is responsible for the overall implementation and coordination of the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA).

unit12.question: What is one of the duties of the PREA Coordinator?
unit12.answer: Ensuring all allegations of sexual abuse or harassment are promptly and thoroughly investigated.
options: Conducting all strip searches.
Approving all personal visits to inmates.
Ensuring all allegations of sexual abuse or harassment are promptly and thoroughly investigated.
Providing medical care to persons in custody.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.3(b): The responsibilities of the PREA Coordinator include... (b) Ensuring that all allegations of sexual abuse or sexual harassment are promptly and thoroughly investigated.

unit12.question: What must be done for every person admitted to the detention facility to assess their risk of sexual victimization?
unit12.answer: A screening for risk shall be conducted.
options: They must be interviewed by a counselor.
Their criminal history must be reviewed.
A screening for risk shall be conducted.
They must be placed in isolation for 24 hours.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.4.1 SCREENING FOR RISK: A screening for risk of sexual victimization or abusiveness shall be conducted for every person admitted to the detention facility.

unit12.question: Can transgender or intersex persons in custody be housed based solely on their external anatomy?
unit12.answer: No, they shall not be placed in housing based solely on their external anatomy.
options: Yes, it is the primary factor.
No, they shall not be placed in housing based solely on their external anatomy.
Yes, unless they object.
The policy does not address this issue.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.4.2 HOUSING ASSIGNMENTS: Transgender or intersex persons in custody shall not be placed in housing based solely on their external anatomy.

unit12.question: Which of the following is a way a person in custody can report sexual abuse?
unit12.answer: By telling any staff member, contractor, or volunteer.
options: Only by writing a letter to the Chief of Police.
Only during their court appearance.
By telling any staff member, contractor, or volunteer.
Only through their attorney.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.5.1 REPORTING: A person in custody may report sexual abuse or sexual harassment by: (a) Telling any staff member, contractor or volunteer.

unit12.question: What is the policy for investigating an allegation of sexual abuse made by a person formerly in custody?
unit12.answer: The department shall accept and investigate reports filed on behalf of a person formerly in custody.
options: Such reports are not accepted.
The person must file the report within 24 hours of release.
The department shall accept and investigate reports filed on behalf of a person formerly in custody.
The person must report it in person at the facility.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.5.2 THIRD-PARTY REPORTING: The Denton Police Department shall accept and investigate reports of sexual abuse or sexual harassment filed on behalf of a person formerly in custody.

unit12.question: How often is PREA-related training provided to members who have contact with persons in custody?
unit12.answer: At least every two years.
options: Annually.
Every three years.
At least every two years.
Only at the time of initial hiring.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.7 TRAINING: Training on PREA shall be provided to all department members who may have contact with persons in custody. This training shall be provided at least every two years.

unit12.question: What is the purpose of the grievance and review process for persons in custody?
unit12.answer: To provide a process for persons in custody to report complaints or concerns.
options: To allow persons in custody to appeal their criminal charges.
To provide a forum for legal advice.
To provide a process for persons in custody to report complaints or concerns.
To handle requests for special meals.
unit12.reference: GO 1204.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to provide a process for persons in custody to report complaints or concerns regarding their treatment or conditions of confinement.

unit12.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the Public Safety Communications function?
unit12.answer: The Communications Supervisor.
options: The Support Bureau Chief.
The on-duty dispatcher.
The Communications Supervisor.
The IT Administrator.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.3 COMMUNICATIONS SUPERVISOR: The Communications Supervisor is responsible for the overall supervision of the Public Safety Communications function.

unit12.question: What is the primary responsibility of a public safety dispatcher when processing calls?
unit12.answer: To obtain essential information in a timely and professional manner.
options: To provide legal advice to callers.
To keep the caller on the line for as long as possible.
To obtain essential information in a timely and professional manner.
To determine the caller's identity before dispatching help.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.4 CALL PROCESSING: The primary responsibility of a public safety dispatcher is to obtain essential information in a timely and professional manner.

unit12.question: What is Emergency Medical Dispatch (EMD)?
unit12.answer: A system that provides pre-arrival medical instructions to callers.
options: A special radio channel for medical emergencies.
A team of paramedics stationed at the dispatch center.
A system that provides pre-arrival medical instructions to callers.
A computer program that diagnoses medical conditions.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.5 EMERGENCY MEDICAL DISPATCH: The Denton Police Department has adopted the Emergency Medical Dispatch (EMD) program to provide pre-arrival medical instructions to callers.

unit12.question: What is the procedure for handling a TTY (teletypewriter) call?
unit12.answer: The dispatcher should use the TTY to communicate with the caller.
options: The dispatcher should hang up and call back on a voice line.
The dispatcher should use the TTY to communicate with the caller.
The dispatcher should send a text message to the caller's number.
The dispatcher should immediately dispatch an officer without gathering information.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.6 TELETYPEWRITER (TTY) CALLS: When a TTY call is received, the dispatcher should use the TTY to communicate with the caller.

unit12.question: What is the policy for transporting persons in custody?
unit12.answer: To transport them in a safe, secure, and professional manner.
options: To use the fastest route possible, regardless of traffic laws.
