To have the person sit in the front seat for better monitoring.
To transport them in a safe, secure, and professional manner.
To allow the person to use their cell phone during transport.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to transport persons in custody in a safe, secure and professional manner.

unit12.question: What must an officer do before placing any person in a vehicle?
unit12.answer: Conduct a search of the person for weapons and contraband.
options: Read them their Miranda rights.
Offer them food and water.
Conduct a search of the person for weapons and contraband.
Verify their identity.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.3 SEARCHING PRIOR TO TRANSPORT: Prior to placing any person in a vehicle, the officer shall conduct a search of the person for weapons and contraband.

unit12.question: How often should an officer make a verbal welfare check on a person in custody during transport?
unit12.answer: At least every 10 minutes.
options: Every 5 minutes.
Every 30 minutes.
At least every 10 minutes.
Only when the person complains.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.4(h): Officers transporting a person in custody should: ... (h) Make a verbal welfare check with a person in custody at least every 10 minutes.

unit12.question: What is the policy regarding restraining juveniles during transport?
unit12.answer: They should be restrained in the least restrictive manner necessary for safety.
options: They should always be placed in full restraints.
They should not be restrained.
They should be restrained in the least restrictive manner necessary for safety.
Only juveniles over 14 can be restrained.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.6 TRANSPORTING JUVENILES: Juveniles should be restrained in the least restrictive manner necessary to ensure the safety of the juvenile and the officer.

unit12.question: What is the primary purpose of the Chaplain Program?
unit12.answer: To provide spiritual guidance and counseling to department members and their families.
options: To conduct religious services for persons in custody.
To act as a liaison with local churches.
To provide spiritual guidance and counseling to department members and their families.
To investigate hate crimes.
unit12.reference: GO 1207.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to provide for the spiritual guidance and counseling of its members and their families through the services of a department chaplain or chaplains.

unit12.question: Are communications with a department chaplain considered confidential?
unit12.answer: Yes, they are considered confidential communications.
options: No, they can be shared with supervisors.
Yes, they are considered confidential communications.
Only if the communication does not involve a policy violation.
Only if the chaplain is an ordained minister.
unit12.reference: GO 1207.5 CONFIDENTIALITY: All communications with a department chaplain are considered confidential communications.

unit12.question: What is a requirement for a person to participate in the Ride-Along Program?
unit12.answer: They must be at least 18 years of age.
options: They must be a resident of Denton.
They must have a valid driver's license.
They must be at least 18 years of age.
They must be a student in a criminal justice program.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.4.1 APPLICANT REQUIREMENTS: Applicants for the Ride-Along Program must be at least 18 years of age.

unit12.question: What are ride-along participants prohibited from doing?
unit12.answer: Carrying any weapon or taking any enforcement action.
options: Asking questions.
Taking notes.
Carrying any weapon or taking any enforcement action.
Operating the police radio.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.6 PARTICIPANT CONDUCT: Participants shall not be permitted to carry any weapon, including a firearm, or to take any enforcement action.

unit12.question: An officer may terminate a ride-along if the participant does what?
unit12.answer: Interferes with the officer's duties.
options: Falls asleep.
Asks too many questions.
Interferes with the officer's duties.
Requests to end the ride-along early.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.6 PARTICIPANT CONDUCT: An officer may terminate a ride-along at any time if the participant interferes with the officer's duties or otherwise fails to comply with the rules of the program.

unit12.question: A person arrested for PI who is being released to an adult must be what?
unit12.answer: In a condition in which they would not be a danger to themself or others.
options: Completely sober.
Able to walk a straight line.
In a condition in which they would not be a danger to themself or others.
Able to sign a legal waiver.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.3.1 RELEASE: When a person is arrested for public intoxication... the arresting officer may release the person if: ... The person may be released to the care of an adult who agrees in writing to assume responsibility for the person... and the person is in a condition in which they would not be a danger to themself or others.

unit12.question: What information should be documented regarding an arrestee's property?
unit12.answer: A detailed description of the property and its condition.
options: Only items of high value.
Only cash and credit cards.
A detailed description of the property and its condition.
The estimated value of each item.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.5 PROPERTY AND MONEY: All personal property will be inventoried and secured... The inventory should include a detailed description of the property and its condition.

unit12.question: A strip search must be conducted by whom?
unit12.answer: Two officers of the same sex as the person being searched.
options: Any two available officers.
A supervisor and an officer.
Two officers of the same sex as the person being searched.
A male and a female officer for impartiality.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.4.1(c): Strip searches... shall be conducted as follows: ... (c) The search shall be conducted by two officers of the same sex as the person being searched.

unit12.question: Who must be notified immediately of any allegation of sexual abuse or harassment in the detention facility?
unit12.answer: The Detention Services Supervisor and the PREA Coordinator.
options: The Chief of Police.
The District Attorney's office.
The Detention Services Supervisor and the PREA Coordinator.
Internal Affairs.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.5.1(b): All allegations of sexual abuse or sexual harassment shall be immediately reported to the Detention Services Supervisor and the PREA Coordinator.

unit12.question: What is the policy for a person in custody who submits a grievance?
unit12.answer: They will receive a written response.
options: They will receive a verbal response only.
Grievances are logged but not responded to.
They will receive a written response.
The grievance is forwarded to the city manager's office.
unit12.reference: GO 1204.4 GRIEVANCE REVIEW: The Detention Services Supervisor shall review the grievance and provide a written response to the person in custody.

unit12.question: What is a primary task of the Communications Supervisor?
unit12.answer: Ensuring compliance with all applicable FCC rules and regulations.
options: Repairing radio equipment.
Hiring all new dispatchers.
Ensuring compliance with all applicable FCC rules and regulations.
Developing patrol beat assignments.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.3(b): The Communications Supervisor is responsible for... (b) Ensuring compliance with all applicable Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rules and regulations.

unit12.question: When transporting a person in custody, what should an officer do with their firearm?
unit12.answer: Ensure it is secured and not accessible to the person being transported.
options: Place it in the trunk.
Allow the person to see it as a deterrent.
Ensure it is secured and not accessible to the person being transported.
It should be unloaded during transport.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.4(g): Officers transporting a person in custody should: ... (g) Ensure that their firearm is secured and not accessible to the person being transported.

unit12.question: What is one of the qualifications for a person to serve as a department chaplain?
unit12.answer: Be an ordained, licensed or certified clergy in good standing with their religious body.
options: Be a retired police officer.
Have a degree in psychology.
Be an ordained, licensed or certified clergy in good standing with their religious body.
Be a resident of the City of Denton.
unit12.reference: GO 1207.3 QUALIFICATIONS: Any person serving as a department chaplain must: (a) Be an ordained, licensed or certified clergy in good standing with their religious body.

unit12.question: When can an applicant for the Ride-Along Program be disqualified?
unit12.answer: If they have a prior felony conviction.
options: If they have received a parking ticket.
If they are not a US citizen.
If they have a prior felony conviction.
If they are over the age of 65.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.4.1 APPLICANT REQUIREMENTS: An applicant may be disqualified if they have a prior felony conviction or any other criminal history that would indicate they are not suitable for participation in the program.

unit12.question: When can an officer make an arrest for a violation of a protective order not witnessed by the officer?
unit12.answer: When the officer has probable cause to believe the violation has occurred.
options: Never, the violation must be witnessed.
Only if the victim has visible injuries.
When the officer has probable cause to believe the violation has occurred.
Only if the suspect admits to the violation.
unit12.reference: GO 901.9(b): An officer may make a warrantless arrest when the officer has probable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense under Tex. Penal Code § 25.07... regardless of whether the offense occurs within the presence of the officer.

unit12.question: How often does the Detention Services Supervisor conduct inspections of the facility?
unit12.answer: At least weekly.
options: Daily.
Monthly.
At least weekly.
Annually.
unit12.reference: GO 1200.3(d): The responsibilities of the Detention Services Supervisor include... (d) Conducting inspections of the detention facility at least weekly.

unit12.question: What is the policy for strip searching a juvenile?
unit12.answer: It is prohibited unless there is probable cause to believe the juvenile is concealing a weapon.
options: It is allowed for any felony offense.
It requires parental consent.
It is prohibited unless there is probable cause to believe the juvenile is concealing a weapon.
It can be authorized by any supervisor.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.4.2 JUVENILES: A juvenile shall not be strip-searched unless there is probable cause to believe that the juvenile is concealing a weapon that could be used to harm themself or others.

unit12.question: If a person alleges sexual abuse by another person in custody, what is a primary response?
unit12.answer: To separate the alleged victim and abuser.
options: To interview both parties together.
To require a polygraph test for the victim.
To separate the alleged victim and abuser.
To move the alleged abuser to a different facility.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.5.3 INVESTIGATIONS: Upon receiving an allegation of sexual abuse or sexual harassment, the department will take immediate steps to protect the person in custody, including, but not limited to... separating the alleged victim and abuser.

unit12.question: Can a person in custody file a grievance on behalf of another person?
unit12.answer: No, a grievance must be filed by the person who is directly affected.
options: Yes, at any time.
No, a grievance must be filed by the person who is directly affected.
Yes, but only if the other person is unable to.
Only if they are related.
unit12.reference: GO 1204.3 GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE: A grievance must be filed by the person in custody who is directly affected by the action or condition.

unit12.question: What must a dispatcher do if they receive a 9-1-1 call that is disconnected?
unit12.answer: Attempt to call the number back.
options: Assume it was a prank call and disregard it.
Immediately dispatch a full emergency response.
Attempt to call the number back.
Send a text message to the number.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.4.1 DISCONNECTED CALLS: If a 9-1-1 call is disconnected, the dispatcher will attempt to call the number back. If there is no answer or the line is busy, the dispatcher will dispatch an officer to the location.

unit12.question: When transporting a person in custody, what should be searched after the transport is complete?
unit12.answer: The transport area of the vehicle.
options: The officer's duty bag.
The entire vehicle exterior.
The transport area of the vehicle.
The trunk of the vehicle.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.3 SEARCHING PRIOR TO TRANSPORT: Prior to and after each transport, the officer shall thoroughly search the transport area of the vehicle for weapons and contraband.

unit12.question: Who must approve the appointment of a department chaplain?
unit12.answer: The Chief of Police.
options: The Support Bureau Chief.
The Chaplain Coordinator.
The Chief of Police.
A committee of department members.
unit12.reference: GO 1207.4 APPOINTMENT: The Chief of Police must approve the appointment of any department chaplain.

unit12.question: A person may be disqualified from the Ride-Along Program if they have a conviction for what type of offense?
unit12.answer: Any offense involving moral turpitude.
options: Any traffic violation.
A Class C misdemeanor.
Any offense involving moral turpitude.
An offense committed as a juvenile.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.4.1 APPLICANT REQUIREMENTS: An applicant may be disqualified if they have a prior felony conviction, a conviction for any offense involving moral turpitude, or any other criminal history that would indicate they are not suitable for participation in the program.

unit12.question: What is the policy for releasing a person who was arrested on an out-of-county warrant if the other agency will not extradite?
unit12.answer: The person shall be released.
options: They must be held for 48 hours.
They must post a local bond.
The person shall be released.
They are transferred to the custody of the county sheriff.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.7 ARRESTS ON OUTSIDE WARRANTS: If the issuing agency will not extradite, the person shall be released.

unit12.question: What is required before a body cavity search can be conducted?
unit12.answer: A search warrant.
options: Reasonable suspicion.
Probable cause.
A search warrant.
The consent of the person.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.5 BODY CAVITY SEARCHES: A body cavity search may only be conducted under the authority of a search warrant.

unit12.question: Are anonymous reports of sexual abuse accepted by the department?
unit12.answer: Yes.
options: No, the reporter must identify themself.
Yes.
Only if the report is in writing.
Only if there is corroborating evidence.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.5.2 THIRD-PARTY REPORTING: The Denton Police Department shall accept reports of sexual abuse or sexual harassment filed anonymously.

unit12.question: How should an officer handle a situation where a person in custody is having a medical emergency?
unit12.answer: Immediately provide aid and request EMS.
options: Complete the booking process first.
Transport them to the hospital in the patrol car.
Immediately provide aid and request EMS.
Wait for a supervisor to arrive.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.4.1 MEDICAL EMERGENCIES: If a person in custody appears to be having a medical emergency, the officer should immediately provide aid and request EMS.

unit12.question: What is a 'Level I' detention facility?
unit12.answer: A facility that houses persons for up to 72 hours.
options: A facility for long-term incarceration.
A temporary holding cell.
A facility that houses persons for up to 72 hours.
A juvenile detention center.
unit12.reference: This is based on Texas Commission on Jail Standards (TCJS) classifications, which GO 1200.2 states the facility will comply with. A Level I facility is a common classification.

unit12.question: How often are visual checks required for persons in custody who are not a known suicide risk?
unit12.answer: At least every 30 minutes.
options: Every 15 minutes.
Every hour.
At least every 30 minutes.
Once per shift.
unit12.reference: This is a standard based on Texas Commission on Jail Standards (TCJS) rules, which GO 1200.2 references as the standard for compliance.

unit12.question: What is the policy for transporting a sick or injured person in custody?
unit12.answer: They should generally be transported by EMS.
options: They can be transported in a patrol car if the hospital is close.
They should generally be transported by EMS.
The officer must wait for a supervisor to approve transport.
The person must sign a waiver to be transported.
unit12.reference: GO 1206.7 SICK OR INJURED PERSONS: A sick or injured person in custody should generally be transported by EMS.

unit12.question: Can a chaplain be asked to divulge a confidential communication?
unit12.answer: No, unless it involves a threat of harm to self or others.
options: Yes, by the Chief of Police.
Yes, with a court order.
No, unless it involves a threat of harm to self or others.
No, under any circumstances.
unit12.reference: GO 1207.5 CONFIDENTIALITY: All communications with a department chaplain are considered confidential communications. This confidentiality does not apply to any communication that involves a threat of harm to self or others.

unit12.question: What is the policy regarding the demeanor of a ride-along participant?
unit12.answer: They must remain neutral and not express any views on the officer's actions.
options: They are encouraged to offer suggestions.
They must agree with all of the officer's actions.
They must remain neutral and not express any views on the officer's actions.
They can act as a witness in court for the officer.
unit12.reference: GO 1208.6 PARTICIPANT CONDUCT: Participants must remain neutral and shall not express any views on the officer's actions.

unit12.question: When can a person in custody be denied telephone access?
unit12.answer: If it would jeopardize a legitimate law enforcement interest.
options: If they have already made one call.
If they are being uncooperative.
If it would jeopardize a legitimate law enforcement interest.
Never, it is a guaranteed right.
unit12.reference: GO 1201.10 TELEPHONE ACCESS: Telephone access may be denied if it would jeopardize a legitimate law enforcement interest.

unit12.question: What should be documented in a strip search report?
unit12.answer: The names of the searching officers, the person searched, and the reason for the search.
options: Only the items found.
The names of the searching officers, the person searched, and the reason for the search.
Only the date and time.
A photograph of the search.
unit12.reference: GO 1202.4.1(f): A written report shall be completed for every strip search. The report shall include... the names of the searching officers, the person searched and the reason for the search.

unit12.question: What is one of the key elements of PREA training?
unit12.answer: The department's zero-tolerance policy for sexual abuse and harassment.
options: Proper firearm handling.
Defensive driving techniques.
The department's zero-tolerance policy for sexual abuse and harassment.
Report writing.
unit12.reference: GO 1203.7 TRAINING: Training on PREA shall include... the department's zero-tolerance policy for sexual abuse and sexual harassment.

unit12.question: What is the time frame for a person in custody to file an appeal to a grievance response?
unit12.answer: Within five days of receiving the response.
options: 24 hours.
48 hours.
Within five days of receiving the response.
There is no time limit.
unit12.reference: GO 1204.5 APPEALS: A person in custody may appeal the response to a grievance within five days of receiving the response.

unit12.question: What is the purpose of the '9-1-1 for Kids' program?
unit12.answer: To educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 system.
options: To provide a separate 9-1-1 line for children.
To give tours of the dispatch center to children.
To educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 system.
To recruit future dispatchers.
unit12.reference: GO 1205.8.1 '9-1-1 FOR KIDS' PROGRAM: The '9-1-1 for Kids' program is an educational program designed to educate children on the proper use of the 9-1-1 emergency telephone system.

unit13.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding recruitment and selection?
unit13.answer: To strive to recruit and select the most qualified candidates for positions within the department.
options: To prioritize candidates who are residents of Denton.
To exclusively hire candidates with prior law enforcement experience.
To strive to recruit and select the most qualified candidates for positions within the department.
To meet a specific quota for diversity hires, regardless of qualifications.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to strive to recruit and select the most qualified candidates for positions within the department.

unit13.question: Who is responsible for developing and implementing the department's recruitment plan?
unit13.answer: The recruiting supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
The City's Human Resources Director.
The recruiting supervisor.
A committee of senior officers.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.3 RECRUITMENT PLAN: The recruiting supervisor shall be responsible for developing and implementing the department's recruitment plan.

unit13.question: What is the minimum age requirement to be a peace officer with the Denton Police Department?
unit13.answer: 21 years of age.
options: 18 years of age.
20 years of age.
21 years of age.
25 years of age.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.4 MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS FOR PEACE OFFICERS: Each applicant for a peace officer position must meet the following minimum qualifications: ... (b) Be at least 21 years of age.

unit13.question: An applicant for a peace officer position must not have been convicted of what type of offense?
unit13.answer: An offense involving family violence.
options: Any traffic violation.
A Class C misdemeanor.
An offense involving family violence.
Any offense committed as a juvenile.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.4(e): Each applicant for a peace officer position must... (e) Not have been convicted of an offense involving family violence.

unit13.question: Which of the following is a step in the selection process for peace officer candidates?
unit13.answer: A polygraph examination.
options: A public speaking test.
An essay on community policing.
A polygraph examination.
A review of the applicant's social media history.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.5 SELECTION PROCESS: The selection process for peace officer candidates shall include: ... (g) A polygraph examination.

unit13.question: What does the background investigation of a candidate include?
unit13.answer: A review of the applicant's criminal history, credit history, and employment history.
options: Only a review of their driving record.
Only an interview with their provided references.
A review of the applicant's criminal history, credit history, and employment history.
A review of their medical history.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.6 BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION: The background investigation shall include a review of the applicant's criminal history, credit history, education, employment history, and references.

unit13.question: What is the department's policy on discrimination and harassment?
unit13.answer: It has a zero-tolerance policy and will not tolerate such behavior.
options: It is handled on a case-by-case basis.
Minor incidents are handled with a verbal warning.
It has a zero-tolerance policy and will not tolerate such behavior.
It is only a violation if a citizen complains.
unit13.reference: GO 1301.2 POLICY: The Denton Police Department has a zero-tolerance policy for discrimination, harassment and retaliation and will not tolerate such behavior.

unit13.question: What is defined as 'harassment' in the anti-discrimination policy?
unit13.answer: Unwelcome conduct that is based on a protected characteristic.
options: Any disagreement between employees.
A supervisor giving a direct order.
Unwelcome conduct that is based on a protected characteristic.
A negative performance evaluation.
unit13.reference: GO 1301.2.1 DEFINITIONS: Harassment - Unwelcome conduct that is based on a protected characteristic.

unit13.question: What should an employee do if they believe they have been subjected to discrimination or harassment?
unit13.answer: Promptly report the incident to a supervisor, the Professional Standards Lieutenant, or the City HR Director.
options: Confront the person directly.
Wait to see if the behavior stops on its own.
Promptly report the incident to a supervisor, the Professional Standards Lieutenant, or the City HR Director.
File a lawsuit immediately.
unit13.reference: GO 1301.4 REPORTING PROCEDURES: Any employee who believes they have been subjected to discrimination, harassment or retaliation is encouraged to promptly report the incident to a supervisor, the Professional Standards Lieutenant or the City Human Resources Director.

unit13.question: What is the policy regarding an officer's courtroom attire when not in uniform?
unit13.answer: They shall wear appropriate business attire.
options: They can wear casual civilian clothes.
They must wear their full duty uniform.
They shall wear appropriate business attire.
They must wear a suit and tie.
unit13.reference: GO 1302.3.2 NON-UNIFORMED PERSONNEL: Non-uniformed personnel shall wear appropriate business attire when appearing in court.

unit13.question: What should an officer do before testifying in court?
unit13.answer: Review all reports and evidence related to the case.
options: Discuss the case with the defense attorney.
Memorize a prepared script.
Review all reports and evidence related to the case.
Avoid looking at any case materials to ensure a fresh recollection.
unit13.reference: GO 1302.4.1 PREPARATION: Officers should review all reports and evidence related to the case prior to testifying.

unit13.question: Can a member of the department testify as an expert witness in a case?
unit13.answer: Not unless approved by the Chief of Police.
options: Yes, in any case they are knowledgeable about.
Yes, but only in civil cases.
Not unless approved by the Chief of Police.
Only if they are testifying for the prosecution.
unit13.reference: GO 1302.5 EXPERT WITNESS: Members shall not testify as an expert witness in any case unless approved by the Chief of Police.

unit13.question: What does the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) require the department to do?
unit13.answer: Provide reasonable accommodation for qualified individuals with a disability.
options: Hire any individual with a disability who applies.
Lower performance standards for individuals with disabilities.
Provide reasonable accommodation for qualified individuals with a disability.
Create special, less demanding jobs for individuals with disabilities.
unit13.reference: GO 1303.4 REASONABLE ACCOMMODATION: The Denton Police Department will make reasonable accommodation for the known physical or mental limitations of a qualified individual with a disability, unless doing so would cause an undue hardship.

unit13.question: When can the department require a medical examination of an employee?
unit13.answer: When it is job-related and consistent with business necessity.
options: At any time, for any reason.
Only as part of the initial hiring process.
When it is job-related and consistent with business necessity.
Only if the employee has used excessive sick leave.
unit13.reference: GO 1303.5 MEDICAL EXAMINATIONS: The department may require a medical examination of an employee when it is job-related and consistent with business necessity.

unit13.question: How often do regular employees receive a written performance evaluation?
unit13.answer: Annually.
options: Monthly.
Quarterly.
Annually.
Every two years.
unit13.reference: GO 1400.3 ANNUAL EVALUATIONS: All regular employees will receive a written performance evaluation annually.

unit13.question: What is the employee's signature on a performance evaluation meant to signify?
unit13.answer: That they have received and reviewed the evaluation.
options: Their agreement with the entire evaluation.
That they waive their right to appeal.
That they have received and reviewed the evaluation.
Their promise to improve in all rated areas.
unit13.reference: GO 1400.4.1 EMPLOYEE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT: The employee's signature indicates that the employee has received and reviewed the evaluation, not that the employee agrees with the evaluation.

unit13.question: What is the purpose of the Honor Guard?
unit13.answer: To represent the department at ceremonial functions.
options: To serve as a special tactical unit.
To conduct internal affairs investigations.
To represent the department at ceremonial functions.
To provide security at city council meetings.
unit13.reference: GO 1504.1 PURPOSE AND SCOPE: The Honor Guard is established to represent the department at ceremonial functions.

unit13.question: Who is eligible to be a member of the Honor Guard?
unit13.answer: Any sworn or non-sworn member in good standing.
options: Only sworn officers.
Only members with military experience.
Any sworn or non-sworn member in good standing.
Only members of command staff.
unit13.reference: GO 1504.3.1 ELIGIBILITY: Any sworn or non-sworn member of the department who is in good standing is eligible to be a member of the Honor Guard.

unit13.question: What must a member do before engaging in any outside employment?
unit13.answer: Obtain approval from their Bureau Chief.
options: Notify the Chief of Police in writing.
Obtain approval from their Bureau Chief.
Post about it on social media.
No approval is necessary.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.3 APPROVAL: Members shall not engage in any outside employment without first obtaining approval from their Bureau Chief.

unit13.question: Which of the following is a prohibited type of outside employment for a department member?
unit13.answer: Working as a bail bondsman.
options: Working as a retail cashier.
Coaching a youth sports team.
Working as a bail bondsman.
Working as a security guard at a bank.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.4 PROHIBITED EMPLOYMENT: Prohibited outside employment includes, but is not limited to: ... (d) Working as a bail bondsman.

unit13.question: When working in a police-related outside employment capacity, what are officers required to do?
unit13.answer: Take appropriate action on any criminal activity they observe.
options: Ignore minor violations.
Act as a representative of their secondary employer only.
Take appropriate action on any criminal activity they observe.
Call an on-duty officer to handle all incidents.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.5 POLICE-RELATED OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT: Officers working in a police-related outside employment capacity are required to take appropriate action on any criminal activity they observe.

unit13.question: What is the department's policy on gratuities?
unit13.answer: Members shall not solicit or accept any gift or gratuity intended to influence their judgment.
options: Gifts under $20 are acceptable.
Members can accept gifts as long as they report them.
Members shall not solicit or accept any gift or gratuity intended to influence their judgment.
Only gifts of cash are prohibited.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.1 GRATUITIES: Members shall not, under any circumstances, solicit or accept from any person, business or organization any gift, gratuity, loan, or fee when it may be reasonably inferred that the gift is intended to influence the member in the performance of their duties or as a reward for any official action.

unit13.question: What is the standard for an employee's on-duty and off-duty personal conduct?
unit13.answer: They must behave in a manner that does not bring discredit to the department.
options: Off-duty conduct is not regulated.
They must behave in a manner that does not bring discredit to the department.
On-duty conduct is the only concern.
Their conduct must only be lawful.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.5 PERSONAL CONDUCT: Members shall conduct themselves, whether on- or off-duty, in a manner that does not bring discredit to the department or the City of Denton.

unit13.question: What is the department's policy on truthfulness?
unit13.answer: Members are required to be truthful and candid at all times.
options: Truthfulness is only required when under oath.
Minor omissions are permissible.
Members are required to be truthful and candid at all times.
It is acceptable to be untruthful to protect another member.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.10 TRUTHFULNESS: Members are required to be truthful and candid at all times in all matters relating to their employment and official duties.

unit13.question: What constitutes 'Insubordination'?
unit13.answer: The failure or refusal to promptly obey any lawful order from a supervisor.
options: Questioning an order to understand it better.
A disagreement with a supervisor's opinion.
The failure or refusal to promptly obey any lawful order from a supervisor.
Requesting an order in writing.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.12 INSUBORDINATION: Members shall promptly obey any lawful order from a supervisor. The failure or refusal to promptly obey any lawful order from a supervisor shall constitute insubordination.

unit13.question: What type of speech is prohibited on social media for department members?
unit13.answer: Speech that discloses confidential information obtained through their employment.
options: Any speech critical of the department.
Speech endorsing a political candidate.
Speech that discloses confidential information obtained through their employment.
All speech related to law enforcement.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.22(a)3.: Members are prohibited from posting or disseminating any... speech that discloses confidential information obtained through their employment.

unit13.question: Which of the following is a form of disciplinary action?
unit13.answer: Written reprimand.
options: A verbal warning.
Peer counseling.
Written reprimand.
A performance improvement plan.
unit13.reference: GO 1602.3 FORMS OF DISCIPLINE: The following forms of discipline may be imposed... (b) Written reprimand.

unit13.question: What is a factor that may mitigate the level of discipline imposed?
unit13.answer: The member's past performance and disciplinary history.
options: The member's popularity within the department.
The member's past performance and disciplinary history.
The time of day the misconduct occurred.
The fact that other members have done the same thing.
unit13.reference: GO 1602.4 MITIGATING AND AGGRAVATING FACTORS: The following factors may be considered in determining the appropriate level of discipline: ... (a) The member's past performance and disciplinary history.

unit13.question: When can the department order a fitness for duty evaluation?
unit13.answer: When there is a reasonable belief that an employee is unable to perform the essential functions of their job due to a medical or psychological condition.
options: After any use of force incident.
As part of a random screening program.
When there is a reasonable belief that an employee is unable to perform the essential functions of their job due to a medical or psychological condition.
If an employee requests a promotion.
unit13.reference: GO 1704.3 FITNESS FOR DUTY EVALUATION: The Chief of Police may order a fitness for duty evaluation when there is a reasonable belief, based on objective evidence, that an employee is unable to perform the essential functions of their job due to a medical or psychological condition.

unit13.question: What is the policy regarding hair color for uniformed personnel?
unit13.answer: It must be of a natural color.
options: Any color is permitted as long as it is neat.
Only black, brown, or blonde hair is allowed.
It must be of a natural color.
Bright, unnatural colors are allowed with supervisor approval.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.4 HAIR: Hair shall be of a natural color. Unnatural colors... are prohibited for all uniformed personnel.

unit13.question: What is the general policy on beards for uniformed officers?
unit13.answer: Beards are generally not permitted.
options: Beards of any length are permitted.
Beards are only allowed in November.
Beards are generally not permitted.
Beards must be less than one inch in length.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.5 FACIAL HAIR: Beards are generally not permitted for uniformed officers.

unit13.question: Are tattoos on the hands, neck, or face permitted for sworn personnel?
unit13.answer: No, they are prohibited.
options: Yes, if they are not offensive.
Yes, if they can be covered by makeup.
No, they are prohibited.
Yes, with the Chief's written permission.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.7 TATTOOS AND BODY ART: Tattoos, brands or other body art on the hands, neck or face are prohibited for all sworn personnel.

unit13.question: A candidate for peace officer must not have been discharged from the military under what conditions?
unit13.answer: Dishonorable or other discharge based on misconduct.
options: A general discharge.
An uncharacterized discharge.
Dishonorable or other discharge based on misconduct.
Any discharge other than honorable.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.4(g): Each applicant... must not have been discharged from any military service under dishonorable or other discharge based on misconduct which bars future military service.

unit13.question: What is 'retaliation' in the context of the anti-discrimination policy?
unit13.answer: An adverse action taken against an employee for making a protected complaint.
options: A disagreement with a supervisor.
An adverse action taken against an employee for making a protected complaint.
A transfer to a different shift.
A negative performance review that is deserved.
unit13.reference: GO 1301.2.1 DEFINITIONS: Retaliation - An adverse action taken against an employee because the employee made a complaint of discrimination or harassment... or participated in an investigation of such a complaint.

unit13.question: What is the primary purpose of a performance evaluation?
unit13.answer: To provide feedback to the employee and identify areas for improvement.
options: To justify disciplinary action.
To determine pay raises.
To provide feedback to the employee and identify areas for improvement.
To rank employees against each other.
unit13.reference: GO 1400.2 POLICY: The purpose of the performance evaluation process is to provide feedback to the employee, to identify areas for improvement and to set goals for future performance.

unit13.question: When can an employee appeal their performance evaluation?
unit13.answer: If they believe the evaluation is inaccurate or unfair.
options: For any reason.
Only if they receive an overall 'unsatisfactory' rating.
If they believe the evaluation is inaccurate or unfair.
An employee cannot appeal a performance evaluation.
unit13.reference: GO 1400.6 APPEALS: An employee who believes their performance evaluation is inaccurate or unfair may appeal the evaluation to the next level of supervision.

unit13.question: What is the policy for engaging in outside employment that might create a conflict of interest?
unit13.answer: It is prohibited.
options: It is allowed with the Chief's approval.
It is allowed if the employee signs a waiver.
It is prohibited.
It is handled on a case-by-case basis.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.4 PROHIBITED EMPLOYMENT: Prohibited outside employment includes, but is not limited to: ... Any employment that would create a conflict of interest with the member's duties.

unit13.question: What is the department's policy on cowardice?
unit13.answer: Members shall not display cowardice.
options: It is grounds for retraining.
It is not addressed in policy.
Members shall not display cowardice.
It is only a violation if it results in injury.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.6 COURAGE: Members shall not display cowardice.

unit13.question: What is an aggravating factor that may be considered in determining discipline?
unit13.answer: A pattern of misconduct.
options: The employee's long tenure.
The employee's apology.
A pattern of misconduct.
The absence of any actual harm.
unit13.reference: GO 1602.4 MITIGATING AND AGGRAVATING FACTORS: (b) Aggravating factors may include, but are not limited to: ... 2. A pattern of misconduct.

unit13.question: Are mustaches permitted for uniformed officers?
unit13.answer: Yes, if they are neatly trimmed and do not extend below the corners of the mouth.
options: No, no facial hair is permitted.
Yes, of any style or length.
Yes, if they are neatly trimmed and do not extend below the corners of the mouth.
Only for non-uniformed personnel.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.5 FACIAL HAIR: Mustaches are permitted for all personnel. Mustaches shall be neatly trimmed and shall not extend below the corners of the mouth.

unit13.question: What is the policy on wearing earrings for male uniformed personnel?
unit13.answer: It is prohibited while on duty.
options: One small stud per ear is allowed.
It is prohibited while on duty.
It is allowed if the earrings are department-issued.
It is at the supervisor's discretion.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.8 JEWELRY: Male uniformed personnel are prohibited from wearing earrings or other body-piercing ornaments while on duty.

unit13.question: Which of these is NOT a minimum qualification for a peace officer?
unit13.answer: Being a resident of the City of Denton.
options: Being a U.S. citizen.
Having a valid driver's license.
Being a resident of the City of Denton.
Being a high school graduate or having a GED.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.4: This section lists citizenship, driver's license, and education, but does not list residency as a requirement.

unit13.question: If an employee makes a complaint of harassment, what will happen?
unit13.answer: The complaint will be promptly and thoroughly investigated.
options: The employee will be transferred to a different shift.
The complaint will be kept on file for one year.
The employee will have to undergo a polygraph test.
The complaint will be promptly and thoroughly investigated.
unit13.reference: GO 1301.2 POLICY: All complaints of discrimination or harassment will be taken seriously, and will be promptly and thoroughly investigated.

unit13.question: Who is responsible for coordinating the appearance of members in court?
unit13.answer: The Court Liaison Officer.
options: The on-duty shift commander.
Each individual officer.
The Court Liaison Officer.
The prosecutor's office.
unit13.reference: GO 1302.2 POLICY: The Court Liaison Officer is responsible for coordinating the appearance of members in court and for providing information to members regarding court appearances.

unit13.question: What is the purpose of the employee performance evaluation system?
unit13.answer: To provide a fair and objective assessment of an employee's performance.
options: To force underperforming employees to resign.
To provide a fair and objective assessment of an employee's performance.
To create competition among employees.
To satisfy a city-wide administrative requirement only.
unit13.reference: GO 1400.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to maintain a performance evaluation system that provides a fair and objective assessment of an employee's performance.

unit13.question: A member of the Honor Guard is expected to maintain what?
unit13.answer: The highest standards of professionalism and appearance.
options: A certain score on the physical fitness test.
A separate, ceremonial uniform at their own expense.
The highest standards of professionalism and appearance.
Perfect attendance at all training.
unit13.reference: GO 1504.3.2 EXPECTATIONS: Members of the Honor Guard are expected to maintain the highest standards of professionalism and appearance.

unit13.question: Can an officer work outside employment at a business that sells alcohol?
unit13.answer: Yes, but they cannot be involved in the sale of alcohol or check identification for alcohol service.
options: No, any employment at an establishment that serves alcohol is prohibited.
Yes, there are no restrictions.
Yes, but they cannot be involved in the sale of alcohol or check identification for alcohol service.
Only if they are working in a security capacity.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.4 PROHIBITED EMPLOYMENT: Prohibited outside employment includes... Working in any capacity at a business where the primary purpose is the sale or service of alcohol. ... This does not prohibit working in a security capacity at such a business, provided the officer is not involved in the sale of alcohol or checking identification for the purpose of alcohol service.

unit13.question: What is the department's stance on members associating with persons known to be involved in criminal activity?
unit13.answer: It is prohibited, except as necessary for official duties or in personal relationships that predate employment.
options: It is encouraged for intelligence gathering.
It is prohibited, except as necessary for official duties or in personal relationships that predate employment.
It is not addressed in policy.
It is allowed as long as the member does not participate in criminal activity.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.7 ASSOCIATIONS: Members shall not knowingly associate with any person who is known to be involved in criminal activity, except as necessary for the performance of official duties or in the course of personal relationships that predate employment.

unit13.question: What can happen to an employee who is not fit for duty?
unit13.answer: They may be placed on leave or in a temporary alternative duty assignment.
options: They are immediately terminated.
They must use their own sick leave until they are fit.
They may be placed on leave or in a temporary alternative duty assignment.
They are required to see a department-selected doctor.
unit13.reference: GO 1704.5 ACTION: Based on the results of the evaluation, the Chief of Police may take appropriate action, including, but not limited to... Placing the employee on leave or in a temporary alternative duty assignment.

unit13.question: What is the policy for sideburns?
unit13.answer: They shall be neatly trimmed and shall not extend below the bottom of the earlobe.
options: They are not permitted.
They can be of any length as long as they are neat.
They shall be neatly trimmed and shall not extend below the bottom of the earlobe.
They must be connected to a mustache.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.5 FACIAL HAIR: Sideburns shall be neatly trimmed and shall not extend below the bottom of the earlobe.

unit13.question: Can a uniformed female officer wear eyeshadow?
unit13.answer: Yes, but it must be of a conservative color and applied in moderation.
options: No, no cosmetics are permitted in uniform.
Yes, any color or style is acceptable.
Yes, but it must be of a conservative color and applied in moderation.
Only if it matches the color of her eyes.
unit13.reference: GO 1705.6 COSMETICS: Female personnel in uniform may wear a minimal amount of cosmetics. Eyeshadow, if worn, shall be of a conservative color and applied in moderation.

unit13.question: What is the department's policy on failing to comply with a lawful order?
unit13.answer: It constitutes insubordination and may result in disciplinary action.
options: It is acceptable if the officer disagrees with the order.
It results in an automatic suspension.
It constitutes insubordination and may result in disciplinary action.
It is only a violation if the order is in writing.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.12 INSUBORDINATION: The failure or refusal to promptly obey any lawful order from a supervisor shall constitute insubordination and may be grounds for disciplinary action.

unit13.question: Can an officer appeal a disciplinary suspension?
unit13.answer: Yes, in accordance with Civil Service law.
options: No, all disciplinary actions are final.
Yes, but only to the Chief of Police.
Yes, in accordance with Civil Service law.
Only if the suspension is for more than three days.
unit13.reference: GO 1603.3 APPEAL PROCESS: A member may appeal a disciplinary suspension, demotion or termination in accordance with Civil Service law (Tex. Local Gov't. Code § 143.052; Tex. Local Gov't. Code § 143.053).

unit13.question: What is required of an applicant for a peace officer position regarding their discharge from the military?
unit13.answer: It must not have been dishonorable or based on misconduct.
options: They must have served a minimum of four years.
They must have been honorably discharged.
It must not have been dishonorable or based on misconduct.
They must provide a letter of recommendation from their commanding officer.
unit13.reference: GO 1300.4(g): Each applicant for a peace officer position must... not have been discharged from any military service under dishonorable or other discharge based on misconduct which bars future military service.

unit13.question: When can an employee use department letterhead?
unit13.answer: For official department business only.
options: For personal correspondence.
For outside employment business.
For official department business only.
To endorse a political candidate.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.21 USE OF DEPARTMENT NAME AND PROPERTY: Members shall not use the department name, logo or letterhead for any personal or unofficial purpose.

unit13.question: What is the policy on providing false or misleading statements during an internal investigation?
unit13.answer: It is strictly prohibited and will result in disciplinary action.
options: It is allowed to protect another officer.
It is not addressed in policy.
It is strictly prohibited and will result in disciplinary action.
It is only a violation if the statement is made under oath.
unit13.reference: GO 1601.3.10 TRUTHFULNESS: Members are required to be truthful and candid at all times... Providing false or misleading statements... may be grounds for disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

unit13.question: How should an officer behave when testifying in court?
unit13.answer: They shall be professional, courteous, and respectful.
options: They should be argumentative with the defense attorney.
They should be stoic and show no emotion.
They shall be professional, courteous, and respectful.
They should direct their answers to the jury only.
unit13.reference: GO 1302.4 COURTROOM CONDUCT: Officers shall be professional, courteous and respectful to the court, the prosecutor, the defense attorney and all other persons in the courtroom.

unit13.question: Can an employee have a financial interest in a business that would create a conflict of interest with their duties?
unit13.answer: No, it is prohibited.
options: Yes, if it is disclosed to their supervisor.
No, it is prohibited.
Yes, if the business is located outside the city.
It is determined on a case-by-case basis.
unit13.reference: GO 1505.4 PROHIBITED EMPLOYMENT: Prohibited outside employment includes, but is not limited to: ... (g) Any employment or financial interest in a business that would create a conflict of interest with the member's duties.

unit13.question: Is an officer required to take action when witnessing a minor traffic violation while off-duty?
unit13.answer: No, there is no legal requirement to take enforcement action.
options: Yes, they must take action.
No, there is no legal requirement to take enforcement action.
They must report it to an on-duty officer.
Only if it occurs within the city limits.
unit13.reference: GO 521.3 DECISION TO INTERVENE: There is no legal requirement for a peace officer to take enforcement action while off-duty.

unit14.question: What is the policy of the Denton Police Department regarding uniforms and equipment?
unit14.answer: To provide members with the necessary uniforms and equipment to perform their duties.
options: To require members to purchase their own uniforms and equipment.
To issue uniforms only to sworn officers.
To provide members with the necessary uniforms and equipment to perform their duties.
To allow members to choose their own style of uniform.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.2 POLICY: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to provide members with the necessary uniforms and equipment to perform their duties.

unit14.question: Who is responsible for the care and maintenance of department-issued uniforms and equipment?
unit14.answer: The individual member.
options: The Quartermaster.
The member's supervisor.
The individual member.
A contracted cleaning service.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.3 UNIFORMS AND EQUIPMENT: Members are responsible for the care and maintenance of their department-issued uniforms and equipment.

unit14.question: When is the Class A uniform typically worn?
unit14.answer: For funerals, ceremonies, and other special events.
options: For daily patrol duties.
During tactical operations.
For funerals, ceremonies, and other special events.
For court appearances.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.4 CLASS A UNIFORM: The Class A uniform is the department's dress uniform and is worn for funerals, ceremonies and other special events as directed by a supervisor.

unit14.question: What does the Class A uniform consist of for sworn officers?
unit14.answer: A long-sleeve shirt, tie, felt hat, and uniform trousers.
options: A short-sleeve shirt and cargo pants.
A polo shirt and tactical pants.
A long-sleeve shirt, tie, felt hat, and uniform trousers.
A t-shirt and jeans.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.4 CLASS A UNIFORM: The Class A uniform consists of a long-sleeve shirt, tie, felt hat, and uniform trousers.

unit14.question: What is the standard daily uniform for patrol operations?
unit14.answer: The Class B uniform.
options: The Class A uniform.
The Class B uniform.
The Class C uniform.
The Class D uniform.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.5 CLASS B UNIFORM: The Class B uniform is the standard daily uniform for patrol operations.

unit14.question: The Class C uniform is considered what type of uniform?
unit14.answer: A tactical uniform.
options: A dress uniform.
A utility uniform.
A tactical uniform.
An administrative uniform.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.6 CLASS C UNIFORM: The Class C uniform is the department's tactical uniform.

unit14.question: Which personnel are authorized to wear the Class D utility uniform?
unit14.answer: Detention services, animal services, and fleet services personnel.
options: All sworn officers.
Patrol sergeants and lieutenants.
Detention services, animal services, and fleet services personnel.
Detectives and investigators.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.7 CLASS D UNIFORM: The Class D uniform is the department's utility uniform and is worn by detention services, animal services and fleet services personnel.

unit14.question: What is the policy regarding the wearing of the department badge?
unit14.answer: It shall be worn over the left breast pocket of the uniform shirt.
options: It can be worn on the belt.
It is optional for uniformed personnel.
It shall be worn over the left breast pocket of the uniform shirt.
It should be concealed from public view.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.9.1 BADGES: The department badge shall be worn over the left breast pocket of the uniform shirt.

unit14.question: When are mourning bands worn on the badge?
unit14.answer: Upon the death of a law enforcement officer.
options: On all national holidays.
During the entire month of May.
Upon the death of a law enforcement officer.
Whenever an officer feels it is appropriate.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.10 MOURNING BANDS: A mourning band may be worn on the department badge upon the death of a law enforcement officer.

unit14.question: Who must authorize the wearing of mourning bands?
unit14.answer: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
options: Any supervisor.
The Honor Guard Commander.
The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
It is at the discretion of the individual officer.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.10 MOURNING BANDS: The wearing of mourning bands must be authorized by the Chief of Police or the authorized designee.

unit14.question: What is the policy regarding personal protective equipment (PPE)?
unit14.answer: The department will provide members with the necessary PPE to perform their duties safely.
options: Members must purchase their own PPE.
The use of PPE is optional.
The department will provide members with the necessary PPE to perform their duties safely.
PPE is only issued to tactical team members.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.3 PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT: It is the policy of the Denton Police Department to provide members with the necessary personal protective equipment (PPE) to perform their duties in a safe manner.

unit14.question: Who is responsible for the care and maintenance of issued PPE?
unit14.answer: The individual member.
options: The Quartermaster.
The member's supervisor.
The individual member.
A designated safety officer.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.3 PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT: Members are responsible for the care and maintenance of their department-issued PPE.

unit14.question: Is the wearing of department-issued body armor mandatory for uniformed officers?
unit14.answer: Yes, during their tour of duty.
options: No, it is at the officer's discretion.
Yes, during their tour of duty.
Only when responding to high-risk calls.
Only for probationary officers.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.4 BODY ARMOR: The wearing of department-issued body armor is mandatory for all uniformed officers during their tour of duty.

unit14.question: How often should body armor be inspected by the member?
unit14.answer: Prior to each use.
options: Weekly.
Monthly.
Annually.
Prior to each use.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.4.1 INSPECTION: Members shall inspect their body armor prior to each use.

unit14.question: When must a reflective vest be worn?
unit14.answer: When directing traffic or working a traffic collision on a roadway open to traffic.
options: During all daylight hours.
When it is raining.
When directing traffic or working a traffic collision on a roadway open to traffic.
At all times while on patrol.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.5 REFLECTIVE VESTS: A reflective vest shall be worn by any member directing traffic or working a traffic collision on a roadway that is open to traffic.

unit14.question: What should a member do if their issued PPE is damaged or needs replacement?
unit14.answer: Promptly report it to their supervisor.
options: Continue using it until it fails completely.
Attempt to repair it themselves.
Promptly report it to their supervisor.
Purchase a replacement online.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.3 PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT: Any PPE that is damaged or otherwise in need of replacement should be promptly reported to the member's supervisor.

unit14.question: Who is authorized to operate a department vehicle?
unit14.answer: Only authorized employees of the department.
options: Any city employee.
Volunteers and interns.
Only authorized employees of the department.
Family members of employees in an emergency.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.3 VEHICLE OPERATION: Only authorized employees of this department may operate a department vehicle.

unit14.question: What must an officer do at the beginning of each shift regarding their assigned vehicle?
unit14.answer: Conduct a thorough inspection of the vehicle.
options: Wash and wax the vehicle.
Refuel the vehicle.
Conduct a thorough inspection of the vehicle.
Check the oil level.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.4 VEHICLE INSPECTIONS: Officers shall inspect their assigned vehicle at the beginning of each shift.

unit14.question: What is one of the items to be checked during a vehicle inspection?
unit14.answer: The proper functioning of all emergency equipment.
options: The brand of the tires.
The cleanliness of the engine.
The proper functioning of all emergency equipment.
The radio station presets.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.4 VEHICLE INSPECTIONS: The inspection shall include... the proper functioning of all emergency equipment.

unit14.question: What should an officer do if they discover any damage or mechanical problems with their vehicle?
unit14.answer: Promptly report it to their supervisor and Fleet Services.
options: Note it in their log and continue using the vehicle.
Attempt to make the repair themselves.
Promptly report it to their supervisor and Fleet Services.
Wait until the end of the shift to report it.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.5 VEHICLE MAINTENANCE: Any damage or mechanical problems with a department vehicle shall be promptly reported to the officer's supervisor and Fleet Services.

unit14.question: What is the policy regarding the use of seatbelts in department vehicles?
unit14.answer: Seatbelts shall be worn by all occupants at all times.
options: It is at the discretion of the driver.
Only the driver is required to wear a seatbelt.
Seatbelts shall be worn by all occupants at all times.
Seatbelts are not required for short trips.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.10 USE OF SEATBELTS: Seatbelts shall be worn by all occupants of a department vehicle at all times.

unit14.question: Can an officer install unauthorized equipment in their assigned vehicle?
unit14.answer: No, it is prohibited.
options: Yes, if it improves performance.
Yes, with supervisor approval.
No, it is prohibited.
Only if the officer pays for the equipment.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.8 EQUIPMENT: No unauthorized equipment shall be installed in any department vehicle.

unit14.question: What must be done after a department vehicle is involved in a collision?
unit14.answer: The collision must be reported to a supervisor and investigated.
options: The officer must pay for the damages.
The collision must be reported to a supervisor and investigated.
The vehicle is immediately taken out of service permanently.
A report is only required if there are injuries.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.9 VEHICLE COLLISIONS: Any collision involving a department vehicle shall be reported to a supervisor and shall be investigated in accordance with the Traffic Collisions General Order.

unit14.question: What is required before a member is permitted to operate a specialized vehicle like a motorcycle?
unit14.answer: They must successfully complete a prescribed training course.
options: They must have a personal motorcycle license.
They must have at least five years of patrol experience.
They must successfully complete a prescribed training course.
They must pass a written examination.
unit14.reference: GO 1403.3 TRAINING: No member shall be permitted to operate a specialized vehicle until they have successfully completed a prescribed training course.

unit14.question: What should a member do with their issued uniform upon separation from the department?
unit14.answer: Return all department-issued uniforms and equipment to the Quartermaster.
options: Keep it as a souvenir.
Sell it online.
Return all department-issued uniforms and equipment to the Quartermaster.
Donate it to a charity.
unit14.reference: GO 1005.4.4 SEPARATION FROM EMPLOYMENT: Upon separation from employment, members shall return all department-issued uniforms and equipment to the Quartermaster.

unit14.question: A mourning band should be what width?
unit14.answer: One-half inch wide.
options: One-quarter inch wide.
One-half inch wide.
Three-quarters of an inch wide.
One inch wide.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.10 MOURNING BANDS: The mourning band should be one-half inch wide and made of a black elastic material.

unit14.question: For how long is a mourning band typically worn for the death of a DPD officer?
unit14.answer: From the time of death until 2400 hours on the day of the funeral.
options: For 24 hours.
For one week.
From the time of death until 2400 hours on the day of the funeral.
For 30 days.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.10(a): Upon the death of a Denton Police Department officer, the mourning band shall be worn from the time of death until 2400 hours on the day of the funeral.

unit14.question: What is the policy for detectives and other plainclothes assignments regarding body armor?
unit14.answer: They shall have department-issued body armor readily available.
options: They are not required to have body armor.
They must wear it at all times while on duty.
They shall have department-issued body armor readily available.
They can use their own personally purchased body armor.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.4 BODY ARMOR: Detectives and other members assigned to plainclothes assignments shall have department-issued body armor readily available.

unit14.question: Who must approve the use of any personally owned equipment for duty use?
unit14.answer: The Support Bureau Chief.
options: The officer's direct supervisor.
The Quartermaster.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The Training Supervisor.
unit14.reference: GO 1005.4.5 PERSONALLY OWNED EQUIPMENT: The use of any personally owned equipment for duty use must be approved by the Support Bureau Chief.

unit14.question: Is it permissible to transport a person in custody in the front seat of a patrol vehicle?
unit14.answer: No, unless exigent circumstances exist.
options: Yes, if the back seat is full.
No, unless exigent circumstances exist.
Yes, if the person is a juvenile.
No, under any circumstances.
unit14.reference: GO 1206.4(d): Officers transporting a person in custody should: ... (d) Not transport a person in custody in the front seat of a patrol vehicle unless exigent circumstances exist.

unit14.question: What should an officer do with their assigned vehicle at the end of their shift?
unit14.answer: Ensure it has at least a half tank of fuel.
options: Leave it with an empty tank for the next shift.
Take it home.
Ensure it has at least a half tank of fuel.
Park it in any available spot.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.6 FUELING: Officers shall ensure that their assigned vehicle has at least a half tank of fuel at the end of their shift.

unit14.question: The operation of a specialized vehicle like an ATV requires authorization from whom?
unit14.answer: The Support Bureau Chief.
options: Any on-duty supervisor.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The fleet manager.
The Chief of Police.
unit14.reference: GO 1403.2 POLICY: The use of specialized vehicles must be authorized by the Support Bureau Chief.

unit14.question: When wearing a tie with the Class A uniform, what is required?
unit14.answer: A department-approved tie tack or tie bar.
options: The tie must be a clip-on.
The tie can be of any color.
A department-approved tie tack or tie bar.
No tie is required.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.4 CLASS A UNIFORM: The Class A uniform consists of a long-sleeve shirt, tie, felt hat, and uniform trousers. A department-approved tie tack or tie bar shall be worn.

unit14.question: Are members responsible for the cost of replacing lost or damaged equipment due to negligence?
unit14.answer: Yes, they may be required to bear the cost.
options: No, the department covers all replacements.
Yes, they may be required to bear the cost.
Only if the item costs more than $100.
No, but they will receive a written reprimand.
unit14.reference: GO 1005.4.2 REPORTING LOSS OR DAMAGE: An employee who loses or damages department property due to negligence may be required to bear the cost of repair or replacement.

unit14.question: What must an officer do if they discover contraband or evidence in their patrol vehicle after a transport?
unit14.answer: Report it to a supervisor and process it as evidence.
options: Discard the item.
Report it to a supervisor and process it as evidence.
Place it in the lost and found.
Ask the previous arrestee if it belongs to them.
unit14.reference: GO 1206.3 SEARCHING PRIOR TO TRANSPORT: Prior to and after each transport, the officer shall thoroughly search the transport area of the vehicle for weapons and contraband. Any contraband or evidence found in the vehicle shall be reported to a supervisor and processed as evidence.

unit14.question: The use of a department vehicle for personal business is what?
unit14.answer: Strictly prohibited.
options: Allowed on weekends.
Allowed with supervisor permission.
Strictly prohibited.
Allowed if the employee pays for the fuel.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.3.1 PERSONAL USE: The use of a department vehicle for personal business is strictly prohibited.

unit14.question: What does a supervisor's inspection of personnel typically include?
unit14.answer: The member's appearance, uniform, and equipment.
options: A review of their recent reports.
A check of their physical fitness level.
The member's appearance, uniform, and equipment.
A quiz on department policy.
unit14.reference: GO 1006.4 SUPERVISOR RESPONSIBILITY: A supervisor's inspection of personnel should include the member's appearance, uniform and equipment.

unit14.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the volunteer program?
unit14.answer: The Volunteer Coordinator.
options: The Human Resources Director.
The Support Bureau Chief.
The Volunteer Coordinator.
A designated Lieutenant.
unit14.reference: GO 1009.3 VOLUNTEER COORDINATOR: The Support Bureau Chief shall appoint a Volunteer Coordinator who is responsible for the overall supervision of the volunteer program.

unit14.question: What is the policy for notifying next of kin in a death investigation?
unit14.answer: It should be done in person whenever possible and in a sensitive manner.
options: It should be done by telephone to be efficient.
It should be delegated to a hospital chaplain.
It should be done in person whenever possible and in a sensitive manner.
It should be delayed until the investigation is complete.
unit14.reference: GO 1010.6 NOTIFICATION OF NEXT OF KIN: The notification of the next of kin should be made in person whenever possible and in a sensitive and compassionate manner.

unit14.question: Can a volunteer be used to direct traffic?
unit14.answer: No, it is a prohibited activity.
options: Yes, if they have completed a training course.
No, it is a prohibited activity.
Yes, but only under the direct supervision of an officer.
Only for special events.
unit14.reference: GO 1009.4 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES: Volunteers shall not be permitted to perform any task or take any action that would normally require a peace officer. This includes... directing traffic.

unit14.question: The uniform of the day is determined by whom?
unit14.answer: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
options: The individual officer.
The on-duty supervisor.
The Chief of Police or the authorized designee.
The weather forecast.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.3 UNIFORMS AND EQUIPMENT: The Chief of Police or the authorized designee shall determine the uniform of the day.

unit14.question: What is the policy on wearing a nameplate on the uniform?
unit14.answer: It shall be worn over the right breast pocket.
options: It is optional.
It shall be worn over the right breast pocket.
It can be worn on the collar.
It is only required for supervisors.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.9.2 NAMEPLATES: The department nameplate shall be worn over the right breast pocket of the uniform shirt.

unit14.question: Any damage to body armor should be reported when?
unit14.answer: Immediately.
options: During the annual inspection.
At the end of the shift.
Immediately.
When it is convenient.
unit14.reference: GO 1401.4.1 INSPECTION: Any damage to the body armor should be immediately reported to the member's supervisor.

unit14.question: What is the policy for transporting a person in custody who is known to be ill or injured?
unit14.answer: They should generally be transported by EMS.
options: The officer can transport them to the hospital.
They should generally be transported by EMS.
They must be cleared by a doctor before transport.
The officer must get a refusal of care signature first.
unit14.reference: GO 1206.7 SICK OR INJURED PERSONS: A sick or injured person in custody should generally be transported by EMS.

unit14.question: The use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) requires what?
unit14.answer: The member to be trained and certified in its use.
options: A supervisor's approval.
The consent of the person.
The member to be trained and certified in its use.
The presence of two officers.
unit14.reference: GO 518.4 AUTOMATED EXTERNAL DEFIBRILLATOR: No member shall be permitted to use an AED until they have successfully completed a prescribed training course and are certified in its use.

unit14.question: How often are inspections of the property and evidence room conducted by the Property Officer's supervisor?
unit14.answer: At least quarterly.
options: Daily.
Weekly.
Monthly.
At least quarterly.
unit14.reference: GO 904.6.1 INSPECTIONS: The Property Officer's supervisor shall conduct an inspection of the property and evidence room at least quarterly.

unit14.question: When can an officer use their personal vehicle for police business?
unit14.answer: Only when authorized by a supervisor.
options: At any time.
Only in an emergency.
Only when authorized by a supervisor.
Never.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.3.2 PERSONAL VEHICLES: The use of a personal vehicle for police business is prohibited unless authorized by a supervisor.

unit14.question: Who must be notified if a department vehicle is involved in a collision?
unit14.answer: A supervisor.
options: The Chief of Police.
Fleet Services.
The City Attorney.
A supervisor.
unit14.reference: GO 1402.9 VEHICLE COLLISIONS: Any collision involving a department vehicle shall be reported to a supervisor...

unit14.question: When may a patrol rifle be carried in a department vehicle?
unit14.answer: When it is secured in a department-approved weapons rack.
options: It can be placed on the front seat.
In the trunk, unsecured.
When it is secured in a department-approved weapons rack.
It can be carried by any officer.
unit14.reference: GO 305.3.3 PATROL RIFLES: Patrol rifles shall be carried in a department-approved weapons rack in the department vehicle.

unit14.question: What should an officer do if a person in custody requires medication?
unit14.answer: Contact the Detention Services Supervisor for guidance.
options: Administer the medication themselves.
Refuse to allow the person to take it.
Contact the Detention Services Supervisor for guidance.
Transport the person to a hospital.
unit14.reference: GO 1201.4.1 MEDICAL EMERGENCIES: If a person in custody requires medication, the officer should contact the Detention Services Supervisor, who will determine the appropriate course of action.

unit14.question: How is a strip search required to be conducted?
unit14.answer: In a private location, out of view of others.
options: In the booking area.
In the back of a patrol car.
In a private location, out of view of others.
In the presence of a supervisor.
unit14.reference: GO 1202.4.1(d): Strip searches... shall be conducted as follows: ... (d) The search shall be conducted in a private location, out of view of any other person except the searching officers.

unit14.question: Who is responsible for the overall supervision of the Chaplain Program?
unit14.answer: The Chaplain Coordinator.
options: The Support Bureau Chief.
The Chief of Police.
The Chaplain Coordinator.
The most senior chaplain.
unit14.reference: GO 1207.3 CHAPLAIN COORDINATOR: The Support Bureau Chief shall appoint a Chaplain Coordinator who is responsible for the overall supervision of the Chaplain Program.

unit14.question: Who is responsible for maintaining all training records for the department?
unit14.answer: The Training Supervisor.
options: Each individual member.
The Records Division.
The Training Supervisor.
The Human Resources Department.
unit14.reference: GO 203.8 TRAINING RECORDS: The Training Supervisor is responsible for the creation, filing and storage of all training records in compliance with TCOLE standards...

unit14.question: What is the policy for reporting a work-related injury or illness?
unit14.answer: It must be reported to a supervisor as soon as practicable.
options: It only needs to be reported if it requires hospitalization.
The employee can wait until the end of the week to report it.
It must be reported to a supervisor as soon as practicable.
The employee must file a report directly with the city's HR department.
unit14.reference: GO 1604.3 REPORTING: Any employee who sustains a work-related injury or illness shall report the incident to their supervisor as soon as practicable.

unit14.question: When wearing the Class B uniform, can an officer wear a t-shirt as an undershirt?
unit14.answer: Yes, but it must be a department-approved, plain white or black t-shirt.
options: No, undershirts are not permitted.
Yes, any color t-shirt is acceptable.
Yes, but it must be a department-approved, plain white or black t-shirt.
Yes, a t-shirt with any logo is acceptable.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.5 CLASS B UNIFORM: A department-approved, plain white or black t-shirt may be worn as an undershirt.

unit14.question: A mourning band should be placed where on the badge?
unit14.answer: Horizontally across the center of the badge.
options: Vertically on the right side.
Diagonally from top-left to bottom-right.
Horizontally across the center of the badge.
On the top edge of the badge.
unit14.reference: GO 1400.10 MOURNING BANDS: The mourning band should be worn horizontally across the center of the badge.

unit14.question: What must a member do if their personally owned equipment, approved for duty, becomes unsafe?
unit14.answer: Immediately report it to their supervisor and cease using it.
options: Continue using it until it can be repaired.
Immediately report it to their supervisor and cease using it.
Attempt to repair it themselves.
Quietly replace it with a new item.
unit14.reference: GO 1005.4.5 PERSONALLY OWNED EQUIPMENT: If the equipment becomes unsafe or otherwise unsuitable for use, the member shall immediately report the circumstances to their supervisor and shall cease using the equipment.

unit14.question: When can a volunteer operate a department vehicle?
unit14.answer: Only with the express permission of the Volunteer Coordinator and the vehicle is for non-enforcement purposes.
options: At any time, if they have a valid driver's license.
Never, under any circumstances.
Only with the express permission of the Volunteer Coordinator and the vehicle is for non-enforcement purposes.
If they are accompanied by a sworn officer.
unit14.reference: GO 1009.4 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES: Volunteers shall not be permitted to operate a department vehicle unless they have a valid driver's license and the express permission of the Volunteer Coordinator. Volunteers shall only operate vehicles for non-enforcement purposes.

unit14.question: When must an officer report the disposition of a traffic citation?
unit14.answer: They are not responsible for reporting the disposition.
options: Within 24 hours of the court date.
After they receive notice from the court.
They are not responsible for reporting the disposition.
At the end of each month.
unit14.reference: General knowledge of court/police procedure. The disposition is a court function, not a reporting requirement for the officer who issued the citation.

unit14.question: The annual department inspection will include a review of what?
unit14.answer: Department records and reports.
options: The department's budget.
Individual officer's personal finances.
Department records and reports.
The city's disaster preparedness plan.
unit14.reference: GO 1006.3 ANNUAL INSPECTION: The annual inspection will include a review of department records and reports.

unit14.question: Who must approve a volunteer's assignment?
